description:
This place was so nice! Very welcoming. Great food, good wine, awesome price. Definitely going to come here again 

Lobster ravioli was delicious. Lasagna is not the classic style, but so tasty!
author: Brittany C.

description:
I must have driven by Il Borgo a million times over the years, always wondering about it, so I took the plunge and made it my 300th Yelp review - woot woot!

I was a little apprehensive at first, reading Yelp review this place seems like it is bipolar, people either love it or hate it.  The Italian lady is either warm and friendly or she is a raging lunatic, customer hating fury.

I had an OK experience.  Yes, service was slow and we needed to ask for things, but it was bearable.  The pasta is al dente and the pizza pretty authentic, the food is indeed good, but I have had better in the price range.

The wine is what I drink at home, so inexpensive and just fine for everyday meals, and the pours are generous.

The place is not trendy looking and the ambiance is old style Italian American checkered table cloth type of thing. Which is fine, if I want fancy I know where to go.

So, don't avoid this place because of the one and two star reviews, but I would not cross the sea to eat here.  Would I come back? Sure, if I can park within one circle of the block I will. Ya feelin' me?
author: Massimo M.

description:
At first glance, this place looks very quaint and charming, a nice vacation from the hipster spots on Hayes, but the service and food were very disappointing.  

1. They got my salad order wrong 2 times and got upset when I said I couldn't eat the cheese on the second incorrect salad.   When I got the right salad, it was the bitter leftover parts of romaine lettuce and there were no fresh herbs on it.

2.While te waitress angrily handed someone at my table my salad, the she cleaned the table next to us so intensely that she threw trash and food at our feet.

3. I ordered the gnocchi with pesto but they brought me gnocchi with tomato sauce.  I was terrified to say something but can't really eat tomato sauce.   The waitress looked at me with daggers and then took it back.   

4.  The pesto was awful and tasted like it was just thick salad dressing.

5.  They got our check wrong twice and kept adding food that we did not order.
author: Sofi V.

description: Such great service, warm bread and great wine&pasta! 10/10 in my opinion! I've come back many times with visiting guests and they all agree that Il Borgo is one of the best!
author: Chelsey E.

description:
Friday night dinners in San Francisco are hardly ever convenient. Honking cars, limited parking, packed restaurants, long wait times, and slower service due to higher demand. 

This Friday I wanted to be brilliant. Coming after work, the last thing I wanna deal with is a rowdy group of bros screaming and hollering after coming from the bar. No, this night, I purposely found a restaurant off the beaten path, all the while still being in the midst of the lively neighborhood of Hayes Valley. 

I moseyed into ll Borgo and even on a Friday night without reservations, I was seated immediately. Lighting was dim with real burning candlelight on each table; brick walls, wooden tables, a rustic type of feel. 

I opened the old school looking menu and decided on the classic caprese (how can anyone go wrong here), Pollo E Vegetali Alla Griglia, and Penne with Salciccia. 

Caprese salad - This dish came out surprisingly quick, which I love, but the ratio of mozzarella to tomato was a bit off. I tend to prefer 50/50 with both tomato and cheese slices close to identical in size. Though I appreciate this dish flying out to the table so fast, I think the preparation could've been a little more thoughtful. 

Pollo E Vegetali Alla Griglia - I was pretty disappointed with this. Grilled chicken drizzled with sweet balsamic vinegar, steamed broccoli, roasted potatoes, and sautéed endive to top. I like my chicken moist, but this chicken breast was flattened and dry; basically flavorless. The potatoes were cooked really well, slightly crispy on the outside, but they were a bit over salted. The expectedly bitter endive enhanced the bitterness of the grill marks on the chicken, rather than complimenting the supposedly sweet/tangy balsamic. In fact, I couldn't detect any balsamic flavor at all. Broccoli was the best thing on the dish; steamed, unseasoned, and not much room for a mess up. This dish was $17.50. 

Penne with Salciccia - The penne was cooked to a perfect al dente and the tomato sauce coated beautifully, but the Salciccia was a bit too salty for my tastebuds. I'm usually very picky with tomato sauces too because it can come off either sour or acidic. This sauce, unfortunately, was not the exception. Grated cheese wasn't even offered to create more of a balance. $14 for this dish. 

Service was really good though. Warm bread was offered to the table. 

For a Friday night, I think Il Borgo was good enough. I accomplished avoiding the late night crowd. 

3.5 Stars
author: Ann S.

description:
What a sweet Italian Restaurant ...I had the grilled Salmon and it was EXCELLENT!
The owner was one of the Sweetest Ladies I have ever met, so kind and so Sweet!!!
Thank you for such an awesone Italian dinner XOXO
author: Les G.

description: We were a group of 4 and we had a blast!!!! Great atmosphere great wine a place you can talk and enjoy yourself!!!! We had pizza and 3 different pasta and was all delicious the bread fresh from the oven the antipasti amazing we had the carpaccio and tomato and basil all including tip $140 for San Francisco that was awesome !!!!! The little wait give us time to start the conversation
author: carla a.

description: The pasta here is incredible. I have eaten here 5 of the day 7 days because I am hooked! Corkage fee is $15 and I like to bring my own bottle and order a pasta entree. I haven't had a dish that wasn't exceptional. The staff is super friendly and the atmosphere is warm and not fussy. I love this place!
author: Ash H.

description:
A taste of Italy in Hayes Valley! 

I stumbled across this place when visiting my BFF in Hayes Valley. It was a Wednesday evening and we were one of the few people in the restaurant. I've been absolutely obsessed with this place since and recently took my boyfriend for a visit! 

AMBIANCE (5/5) 
It really feels like you are in NYC's Little Italy. So cute and authentic. Fairly small and intimate - an ideal place to take a date!! 

FOOD/DRINKS (4.5/5) 
Pizza is awesome! Gnocchi is pretty good too, and I am obsessed with the bread + olive oil/vinegar.  We ordered two glasses of the Merlot ($8/each) and the legit fit almost a bottle of wine into two cups ... woohoo! Gotta love a heavy handed pour ;) I have not had the chance to try the dessert yet. 

SERVICE (5/5) 
Everyone is so friendly! The first time I came there was a lady who was Italian, and gave us great insight as to what to order / drink pairings. Both times I visited the service was first-class and very attentive. Woohoo! 

Extra + is this place is not too pricy! Will definitely be back :)
author: Natalie F.

description: Simple housemade Italian food. Low key. Great staff! My food was so good. Local customers chilling out on a Saturday night. Great non-trendy charming place!
author: Goodbye K.

description: Not great. The food is pretty sub oar for Italian food. But what's even worse is the service. A combination of receiving the wrong dishes, never getting water, and  getting crumbs from the next table angrily dusted on me after my friends asked for the salad she ordered instead of the one they have her leaves me underwhelmed. Plus I never got that parmesan for my my toothy, very toothy pasta. The bruscetta was tasty though. And our bill is wrong
author: Roman G.

description:
Ambiance: eclectic decoration. No need for reservation (at least on a weekday). Mostly empty and relatively quick service. Cute spot, just not great for the price.
Food:
- Bolognese: Pasta was nice and chewy, sauce was okay but not enough tomato flavor / not salty enough overall
- Carbonara: Spaghetti was very al dente, not great quality in my opinion. In contrast with bolognese, very salty but not great mix of flavors.
- Merlot: $9 per glass, $30 for a bottle - overall ok
author: Taryn Q.

description:
Unfortunately, the service here is horrible. The owner and woman are not friendly at ALL. We waited about 5 minutes standing in the front of the restaurant. They didn't smile at all to greet us or seat us. They seemed kind of annoyed that we arrived around dinner time when it was busy.

The only person I liked there was the bus boy. He is from maui. He overheard our conversation about Hawaii and made some comments. He was so kind, and I honestly wish he was just our server. He did more than the actual server woman.

I'm only giving a good review because this is a small business, and I want to get them the benefit of the doubt that they were having a bad day. I would also say the food was pretty quick and fairly good. The bread is fresh and free!  So kudos to the kitchen staff!
author: Nadia H.

description: We visited again this past December and we were not disappointed! Fresh bread so goooooooooooood.
author: Suzanne P.

description:
The WORST service I've ever had in a business establishment anywhere in the world. 
The food was mediocre but the waitress that served me had the worst customer service skills I've ever experienced. She notified me that it's cash only for under $20. I asked if it was posted anywhere and she then made a racial slur.
Asking if I was " A Spanish" ? I replied that I am American and asked what that had to do with it.
Her response was, "I'm busy, I'll let you pay with a card this time." 
If a horrible and racist dining experience is what you're looking for. Well.... this is the perfect spot.
Disgusting and disgraceful establishment.
I only gave a one star so I could post the review.
Well deserving of a negative star rating. Enjoy !
author: Lynn H.

description: The older lady that works there is really rude and I have caught her in multiple lies. The place is rundown and old. Smells bad walking in. Oh and their restroom was supposedly "out of order" when I had to use the restroom. The food is cold and gross. Not worth the money. Service was awful. Overall really bad restaurant. I definitely would not recommend.
author: Darius H.

description:
This place is a wreck. The main waitress/host was an annoyed Italian woman who was angry with our table the entire night: mad that we wanted a window table in her empty restaurant, poured wine for just two of the four of us, gave us dirty forks, wouldn't recommend anything off of the menu, and was just generally not helpful. 

The pasta was plentiful, but bland and mushy. I'm giving it two stars because we laughed a lot at the absurdity of this place. Life is too short to eat out this way.
author: Daniel W.

description:
This place is growing on me. There aren't a whole lot of straight up Italian places in Hayes Valley. It's a little off the Hayes, but you've surely passed it, since it's on Fell.

While the food is pretty good, I've never felt blown away. But, I feel like I'm still in SF of 10 years ago or so, before everything was gentrified (including the prices). The menu isn't filled with obscure greens and uber fancy names for ham. As a result, it's actually possible to get a seat.
author: masa s.

description: My go-to for Italian food. They have lots of vegetarian options. My favorite right now is the fettuccine primavera. My husband had the Fettuccine Bolognese and loved it. Great atmosphere and ideal for large parties. Service is always fast and efficient. So happy to live so close!
author: Elvia D.

description: I have been here many times and I am never disappointed. The location is small and super homey. Amazingly fair prices, especially when compared to other Italian locations nearby. If you're looking for some good pasta, a welcoming atmosphere and decent prices, you won't be disappointed!
author: Michelle K.

description:
I've driven by this place 1,000 times and finally decided to give it a try.  Our party of four easily got a reservation which was nice.  When we arrived for our early dinner at 6:00 the place was surprisingly packed! 
 It looked as if there was only one server for the entire restaurant so she was busy.  What was frustrating is our table had to flag her down to ask for everything...drinks, a fork, parmesan cheese, water refills, the check, etc.  She was so busy we could only get one request in at a time before she ran off.  The food was bland and the obviously boxed pasta was under cooked.  No one in my party enjoyed their meals and everyone agreed they would not return.  In this city, why waste your time and money on a subpar restaurant.
author: a e.

description:
Let's me first start by saying is you looking for service this is not the place. If you are looking for good food at a decent pride and don't mind crappy service this is the place. 

Came here with a big group today. Service was slow even at 8:30 pm. Took forever to get our servers attention to order wine and she did not advise on portions so after the first round of appetizers came out we had to reorder for a starving group of people. Caprese salad is meant for 4 and we had 7 people. Pizza we were short one slice since it came with only 6. Really??? 

Dinner was great. Portions were good and quality of the pasta dishes we all ordered you good. In fact 4/7 of us needed a doggie bag so we could eat some dessert. 

Now why two stars? Service sucks. No refills or how is everything. No help on what to order or portion sizes. We constantly had to ask for things from chili flakes and Parmesan that should come standard with pizza. Bread only came when we ordered two bottles of wine. 

So when our bill came we divided it by 7 with 18% tip and we forgot to include one person so our bill was a bit short. 

I get it we made a mistake but for the server to come and tell us in front of the whole table that we stiffed her was tacky. She could have said, hey the tip doesn't look correct do you mind rechecking instead of embarrassing the person who calculated it in the group. Tacky. No apologies and we left her extra tip in cash no less and then she was all flowers and sunshine trying to be nice. 

I don't like service that is crappy and then having the server ask for more tip shamelessly in front of a large group. If we made a mistake there are more graceful ways to ask. Would I come here again? Probably not. Food wasn't that good and the service def killed my appetite. 

I only came for a friends going away party and this was not how I expect my friends last meal in US before moving overseas would be. Thanks for killing our joyful mood and wonderful evening.
author: Jen C.

description: Okay... unsure how this place has anything less than five stars. We had the lasagnetta, the pollo e vegetali alla griglia and the antipasto misto. Incredibly amazing and delicious. The fresh bread was warm and crusty on the outside and soft as a pillow on the inside. Food was cooked perfectly and so incredibly flavorful. We will be back!!
author: Angela B.

description: Wow. Truly cannot describe my disappointment with this restaurant. On a rainy afternoon we made a reservation for that evening. They asked us to push an hour and half to accommodate our group. Fine, we will take a late dinner. But when we arrived at 8:25, 5 minutes before our reservation, they immediately seated another party at the only large table that was open. When we tried to ask about our reservation, the person seemingly in charge cared not at all-- and honestly, I hate to say it but he was clearly drunk and repulsive in his behavior to me and my friends, refusing to acknowledge his (human!) error. There was clearly not going to be any tables for a very long time, and they refused to answer to the reservation they had confirmed for us this afternoon. All in all, beware of the liars and pigs who run this restaurant- not some place anyone should be spending their money!
author: Nora B.

description:
My family and I had a great time, the place is intimate and food was great; we had pizza and tried a few different pasta dishes, we finished all of it, and will soon come back !
I saw quite a few 1 star reviews from angry hipsters who think of themselves as food critics, including a guy complaining about raw egg in Carbonara pasta: LOL. 
People, this is the type of place, food and service you will find in Italy. If you want a simple and authentic experience as well as delicious Italian food, I definitely recommend this place !
author: Julien B.

description:
LOVED the food here. You can tell the pasta was fresh, cooked perfectly al dente and the flavors were just genuine. 

The restaurant is SMALL and i don't think they honor their reservation system on open table. We were on time and there were no spots left which was a little disappointing. Luckily a table was leaving shortly so we didn't have to wait for too long.

There are only about 2 waiters for the restaurant so during peak hours it gets a little hectic inside. Prices were reasonable for the entrees and the wine as well. The indoor is rustic with a taste of Italy and they have a single bathroom. 

Its a great place to get together with friends for a good and hearty meal! I definitely would recommend and would go back. It's in Hayes Valley so there are lots of bars around the area as well for a pre dinner or post dinner drink!
author: Bori B.

description: Ew. Don't go in the bathroom. Food was cold, gross, and not worth the money. Service was awful.
author: Natalie N.

description: the pizzas are substandard, we've eaten much better and more "italian" pizzas around the city at places with same yelp score. don't let the warm atmosphere fool you, the waitress lady was the WORST. she kept smiling the whole time while insulting us in italian. then tried to be funny by making extremely patriarchal jokes. the moment this place was over for me was when she insisted on (imposed even) us paying in cash because they paid too much fees for foreign cards. that was a first in 2 years with the same card. we had to pay by our debits card though we clearly said we didn't prefer to. while she kept on with the patriarchal comments like "a man shoul nalways carry a thick wallet with lots of cash", wth??
author: Cihan B.

description: Great place! They have fantastic Italian food and wine. Bread, pasta, tiramisu- all was melting in my mouth. Chianti was smooth... even water was filtered, not a tap water. Staff was very efficient and attentive, place was clean, no kitchen or chlorine smell. Definitely recommend it to every quality food lover.
author: Elvira R.

description:
This place is a trattoria that's too humble to call itself a "trattoria." It's a small corner joint with vinyl red-checked tablecloths, real drippy-wax candles on the tables, and unpretentious service.  Not cozy, exactly, but authentic. 

The pizza has a very light and thin (though not really crisp) crust.  The wines (decent Pinot Grigio; delicious, smooth, cherry-heavy DOGC chianti) are poured at your table.  

The fettuccine bolognese featured fresh pasta and the sort of really home-style sauce that's more meat (beef and a little pork, according to the waiter) than tomato, long-cooked, with a distinct note of allspice.  

The "gelato" was just ok -- much more like ice cream than true gelato, but the chocolate scoop had shavings of chocolate that gave it a gritty texture but intensified the flavor.
author: Steve S.

description:
After watching "The Godfather" marathon on AMC, surprise surprise, I had a hankering for Italian. Dining solo, I cruised by Uva Enotecca--I'm told their Japanese eggplant parmigan is excellent. But, it was slammed, even for a single guy, party of one. So, what other Italian spot is open in the neighborhood? Il Borga! 

I was & am bummed the only eggplant dish they serve is Fussili. Also bummed that my table had no candle, because trust me, the candles are cool. More on the candle later...

So I settled on one of my old faves, Pasta Puttanesca, the "whore's sauce". My Sicilian grandma tells the story--after a long night working, a prostitute awakes at 3 in the afternoon, & being hungry, she goes to the "icebox" & finds anchovies, tomatoes, basil, garlic, capers & olives. She comes up with a sauce for her spaghetti! I am happy to report the chef ok'd my request to substitute fettuccine, cos it usually comes with penne, & I wasn't in the penne-mood.  To start, I ordered a nice chianti & the salad Casareccia, cold crunchy romaine with Italian dressing & fresh herbs. Although at $6, it's over-priced, but it was perfectly dressed, & the dressing was excellent, the perfect balance of herbs, red wine vinegar & EVOO. It could have used some garbanzos and a couple cherry tomatoes, but it was really good. The waiter brought over fresh ground pepper, some freshly grayed parmesan, &  some warm Italian bread gratis, a nice touch. 

Music in many restaurants can be an afterthought, or worse, too loud & annoying. Il Borgo's charming Italian tunes, not super-loud & with the candles & red checkered tablecloths, it really is classic ambience (think "Lady & the Tramp"!) Love it. When it got dark, the waiter brought me a candle. Pretty cool, right? 

When the pasta came, it was indeed home-made & it was al dente. But sad to say, it had just way tooooo fishy. Too much anchovies, and not very good quality. I did send it back & the guys were cool about it. The owner offered another dish, but since it getting was late, 
I opted for the Antipasto Misto. Hey, ya can't go wrong with prosciutto, heirloom tomatoes, & roasted garlic!

So, I'm giving Il Borgo 5 stars. Sure the Puttanesca was too fishy, but everyone has an off day. Next time, I'll bring a date & try the lasagne.
author: Scott F.

description: Awful service. The lady who served the tables said rude and strange things to us. The whole vibe was unpleasant. The food was standard, middle-of-the-road Italian food.
author: Murad M.

description: Wow. I've never been mistreated like this for just asking to pay the check separately because I had to leave early. I explained the lady nicely but her gestures were super rude and gave me soooo much attitude. When I asked her why she was treating me like that and giving me a reason to not come again, she said she had been running this restaurant for 18 years and didn't need my business. At the end of this conversation, she asked me whether I'm Russian, making a remark about my bad personality!! I wished her good luck after that. Please save yourself the trouble and don't even bother. There are better places out there with much better food.
author: Ertan D.

description:
-- pasta dishes came out in under 5 minutes, looked sad and microwaved
-- pasta sauce tastes like bottled Ragu
-- absolutely no flavor in any of the pastas, and the carbonara had raw egg
-- pasta itself is the same quality as the $1.99 boxes at Safeway, the blue generic ones

But above all -- the worst service I've ever had in San Francisco. The lady who runs this place (?) and can't stop spewing Italian apparently has mistaken speaking the language for good service. She was rude, inattentive, and seemed to suggest that we were doing her a favor by eating at this Safeway-deli quality establishment. 

A very sad turn for what used to be a nice cozy Italian place.
author: John B.

description: This is our usual spot that is owned by amazing people. We love the food and atmosphere. There aren't many places in SF that you can have a dinner under $100 for two. Best price for Italian food in sf.
author: Amir R.

description:
Momma Mia!  This was some good pasta!  After seeing the matinee of Hamilton I was in search of a restaurant where my kids would actually eat.  Italian is always safe!

This little restaurant  was a lovely surprise!  Our waitress was very sweet and attentive.  We ordered bruschetta which was delicious.  It's hard to mess up bruschetta..  I ordered the lasagne, one son ordered a pizza, the other penne and my friend ordered a pasta dish with sausage.  This was the real deal.

I know pasta.  I make pasta.  I was taught to make pasta in italy by an Italian chef.  This was delicious pasta.  The sauce was not Ragu as another reviewer claimed (although Ragu is a generic term for tomato sauce).  This was good.  Perfectly balanced.  Not too acidic and not too sweet.  It was spot on.

I would absolutely come here again.  We recommend it to the guys to helped us at Miette just a few blocks down.  What a wonderful neighborhood spot...
author: Jen C.

description:
Got the spinach ravioli and it was amazing! Great little place with a real authentic Italian feel! 

Staff was friendly and it was easy to find! Recommend checking it out for some good home cooked Italian food!
author: Brad C.

description:
If your priorities are wallet friendliness and large portions, Il Borgo IS the place for you.

If your priorities are ambiance, attentive service, receiving the dish that you ordered then Il Borgo is NOT the place for you. 

I tried the housemade Fettuccini with Sundried Tomatoes and Chicken and while the flavor was good but the chicken was dry. Hubby liked his nicely cooked Lamb Chops that came with broccoli and rosemary potatoes. Grilled Salmon was also ordered at our table but it was reportedly overcooked.

Dinner for our table of four including two glasses of Pinot Grigio was about $100.
author: Amy C.

description:
Haven't had Italian food in a hot minute and popped into this one since we were in the neighborhood on a Saturday night with no wait!!

Free bread at Italian restaurants is a must and their bread was pretty solid - crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. We asked for seconds (lol, but who wouldn't) and the second batch was cold! Um?

We ordered:

Caprese: Incredibly underwhelming taste...and they definitely skimped on the basil!
 Lobster Ravioli: I really enjoyed this! and the sauce didn't overpower the taste of the lobster. Only thing was the portion size was tinyyyyy I was still a bit hungry after :(
Fettuccine Bolognese: Carby, greasy, heavy, but delicious! 

I've never really had a bad experience with Italian food (how can you go wrong with carbs, cheese, and greasy meat) and we definitely enjoyed our time here BUT I didn't think anything really stood out for me. The price point was quite reasonable but portion size could be a bit bigger.
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
Decent Italian traditional dishes and no frills restaurant. There are murals painted on the wall, dim lights in the evening, Italian music, and delicious aroma. 

Service has been generally friendly, except on the last occasion the service was questionable. Our server wanted us to pay cash, when they clearly take Visa and Mastercard advertised on their storefront. She also made a comment about one of my friend's nationality, and he was a good sport and could have taken offense.

The bread is very good, and it's easy to scarf down. Their pasta is cooked al dente. I enjoy the carbonara their though the pancetta quite has a bit of fat. The spaghetti and ravioli dishes are tasty. Their tiramisu is made in house and quite delicious. 

It is a little bizarre to find a random plush Mickey Mouse sitting in the corner of the restroom, facing the toliet. Not sure how the Disney theme fits with the traditional italian ambiance, but it certainly is a conversation piece.
author: Nova P.

description:
Most unfriendly service I've had in a long time. My group of 4 arrived here around 6:30pm on a Saturday and there was zero space for our group to wait inside. Like you walk in and you're basically hovering over a stranger's dinner table.

I waited with two other groups that were there before me, and none of us were greeted. Nobody knew what was going on or how long the wait would be. A friend in my group had to walk through the restaurant after waiting for 15 minutes to ask the owner directly how long it would be. 

They did give us an appetizer for free which was nice. They tastes like pizza pockets (yum!) and also every table gets free bread and olive oil/vinegar which is also goood.

I got the Lasagenta (lasagnetta?) and it was yummy yum yum! Three large spirals of noodles, cheese, pancetta (i think?), and a delish pinkish sauce. I recommend!

Hopefully the service was a one time thing. Oh! the lights also randomly went off. So we sat in the dark with candles until they came back on.
author: Kelly G.

description:
We are staying in the area for a symphony concert, so wanted to find a place to eat that was vegetarian friendly and in walking distance, plus availability on OpenTable.

I saw several items on the menu that are standard orders for me at Italian restaurants: bruschetta, caesar salad with anchovies, and spaghetti carbonara.

My assessment: not quality anchovies, dressing tasted out of the bottle, lettuce on the salad had bits of sand or dirt from not being washed well enough, bruschetta tomatoes were not ripe and cut too big, basil was cut into inedible chunks, bread was not even toasted, pancetta over done .... at least the actual pasta was perfect al dente. That's the only reason I'm not one starring this place.

All this for $60? I'm not coming back. Plenty of other places in the civic center area to walk to.
author: Michelle R.

description: You will not get better Italian food. Do yourself a favor and eat here. From the homemade pasta to the amazing tiramisu, you will not be disappointed.
author: Jessica W.

description:
While all other millions of restaurants around it were busy, I was wondering how we found a large table so easily, and that too on Friday night. By the end of the meal, I was sure of the reasons.

The place has a nice decor and a great location. The food menu is sizeable too. But two things that should be base requirements are missing. First, the service is rude and atrocious. The owner (the tall, heavy built guy) seems the least interested in providing a good service, and frowns at additional requests. For instance, while we categorically told him to separate the meat from the starter, he brought it back just the same. And when we mentioned it to him again, a good restaurant would just replace it; not here. Even the can of coke that was offered upon ordering seemed past its expiry date.

As for the food, which is the one thing you expect at a restaurant, seemed bland and average at best. Now, this could be a matter of personal taste, but even the tables around us were complaining of the same. My assumption is that to cover up for the inadequacies, they just add multiple layers of cheese on top of any meal.

Not coming back in here again.
author: Adi M.

description: Excellent! My teenage granddaughters were quite thru the whole dinner...they cleaned their plates! Very authentic. Great flavor. Small but comfortable.
author: David F.

description:
Not wanting to wait 90 minutes for deep-dish down the street, my dinner companion (K) and I happened upon this cute little restaurant tucked away in Hayes Valley.  The interior is quite welcoming and the host was gracious even though we had enough luggage to take up a table for four.  Everything looked delicious, but that's about where it started to go wrong.

She seemed offended when I declined to order the wine K wanted, and when K wanted a refill, we had to flag the host down, even though the restaurant was quite slow by that point.  The dressing on my caesar was traditional, but was little more than romaine and dressing.  No offer of cheese at this point, or any other.  I ended up wishing I'd ordered K's misti, which seemed to be a lot more substantial.

Our entrees came out relatively quickly -- my carbonara was passable, though somewhat lacking in flavor, while K's gnocchi had a gorgonzola sauce that was too strong for my tastes.  

I had other plans for dessert, and when we tried to pay our check with a credit card, we were informed that cash would be faster.  She didn't wait for me to respond to this (I rarely carry that much cash) and walked away.  A few minutes later, she had the same conversation with another table that insisted on paying with plastic.  She ran their card, and started ranting loudly to the kitchen staff in Italian.  I don't speak Italian, but between K's Spanish and my French, we got the gist of it.  She was LIVID that people don't pay in cash anymore.  "Everyone only carries plastic, and I have to pay for their laziness"

I get that you don't like paying credit card fees.  I don't imagine anyone does.  However, those networks aren't free, and someone has to pay for the  infrastructure.  If you don't want it to eat into your profits, raise your prices or don't advertise the ability to take cards when you'd rather not.  I did notice your ATM machine in the corner, which was unplugged.

I realize she probably thought we wouldn't know what she was upset about, but perhaps she should be more careful about ranting about customers within earshot.  Some of us might understand what you're saying, say nothing about it, and then never come back.  It was certainly the only meal I'll ever eat there.
author: Derek H.

description:
I came here with my friends for my birthday dinner and the pasta was AMAZING!!!!

Ambiance- very traditional Italian restaurant with checkered tablecloths and the waiters were very Italian.

Wine- Got two bottles of the chianti which was delicious and only $30 for a bottle, which is pretty cheap for San Francisco.

Food- the free bread they gave us was so so, but the pasta was AMAZING. I got homemade fettucini with pesto and homemade fettucini primavera with no peas and they were both incredible (5/5). The pasta tasted super homemade and the portions were huge! My friend got a pizza which looked mediocre, but I will definitely go back for the pasta!!

Also, pricing was pretty reasonable. Pasta dishes were about $14.
author: Jenna G.

description:
The food was great. The service was nice. The owner may be the waiter and cook. He dropped us a bill which my mother and I split. We received a 76.00 dollar receipt on each of our cards upon which we left a 14.00 tip on each of our separate bills. When I got home, I saw that the entire 
receipt was actually 125.32. He had split our bills (62.66 each leaving himself a $13+ tip on each) and left himself a generous tip without telling us. So when we tipped him on tip of it, he didn't inform us. So we each ended up giving him $90 + which amounts to an over $54 tip on $125 bill. So I called to straighten it out and he called me a mutherf*cker. I don't think I will be going back, as well -- the credit card companies will be getting a call.
author: Susan N.

description: Outstanding!  Cozy ambience and great food. Ate the bruschetta to start and the lasagnetta for the  main course. Each were phenomenal. Come.
author: Sam B.

description: Amazing Italian restaurant. Highly recommend the linguini primavera and the artichoke ravioli. Excellent service and great selection of wines.
author: Laura F.

description: We came last night and we really enjoyed the dinner. The staff were nice and entertaining ! It was pretty busy but they attended to us every so often. The food is great too! I got the lobster ravioli and it was really tasty. The pizza was great as well. Everything was homemade even the bread! I would definitely go back here.
author: Dianne P.

description: First time at this spot, not touristy, very mellow vibe, there may be a little but if a wait, but the food was fantastic. Highly recommend their caprese salad and hand rolled lasagna.
author: Alexandro V.

description: This is my favorite Italian place in the city! Their Gnocchi is spot on, as well as their tiramisu and all of their pasta dishes. I have been a long time fan, and continue to dine here often!
author: Julie N.

description: Came here for my 30th from Texas. The staff was super friendly, and the food is great. My waiter gave me a shot of 300$ tequila.
author: Rio P.

description:
I love this place!!! Been coming here since 1999. It's literally a mom & pop place. Something that's become rare in SF nowadays. I straight up watched their son grow up, helping his dad in the kitchen and his mom wait on tables.

It's small so don't be a f*cking douche bag and try to throw a bday dinner with hella people without giving the restaurant a call first. If you're trying to throw a party, then rent the place out. Seriously. 

It's charming, quaint and has delicious authentic Italian food. The pasta tastes like it's made that morning. I always get the lasagneta and/or gnocchi. Soooooo delicious. It's always a good idea to dip your bread in the pasta sauce. Sooooooo good.
author: Sarah V.

description:
Everytime I go (which is often), its like the first time I'm eating here all over again.

The atmosphere: this place is cozy and intimate- perfect for a little date night or meeting up with the family.

The service: excellent and hospitable, which is impressive for such a small operation (usually the owner, one server, and one cook).

The prices: for the city this is a reasonable selection, usually the plates are roughly $15 give or take.

The food: I get the same thing every time I go and it NEVER lets me down, so delicious. I start with the antipasta misto and for the entree I get the lasagnetta il borgo with a bottle of the barbera d'asti - amazing!

Must try! 

Job well done guys, everytime!!
author: Derrick D.

description: I have eaten at this charming neighborhood restaurant a number of times and love both the home-cooked Italian food and ambiance.  Where else can you find red-checkered table cloths and wax candles in wine bottles?  Each time I've ordered a delicious pasta dish and I have never been disappointed.  The sauce is fresh, not too salty or over-garlicked.  Much of the pasta is house-made and the bread arrives crusty and steaming to accompany the wonderful meal!  I recommend getting there early as it does fill up quickly - especially on a Saturday night.  I look forward already to returning the next visit.
author: LMarie G.

description: Drive by this place at night all the time. Finally stopped in for dinner last night. It was lovely - the owner was serving I think. Great place to practice speaking Italian! Italian pop music from the 80s playing in the background - I felt like I was on vacation in an Italian villa. The candle sticks burning in Chianti bottles on the tables is a romantic touch. For food, the warm crusty bread they give you after ordering is so good. I had the Insalata del Borgo which was a great starter (fresh radicchio, Pine nuts and Gorgonzola cheese) - simple and just the right amount of dressing and herbs. Followed by the Fettuccine Bolognese which was one of the best I've had in San Francisco - more meat than tomato sauce and not oily at all. The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente, piping hot. If you want simple, honest, authentic Italian food in a romantic, cozy setting with warm, gracious service then I highly recommend this neighborhood place!
author: Sonya S.

description: Really like this old school Italian restaurant, just a couple blocks off Hayes with half the attitude at half the price. Great pizza, yummy salads homey atmosphere.
author: Julie T.

description: Lovely corner Italian restaurant. Pasta that melts in your mouth. Friendly staff and relaxing ambience. We loved the gnocchi bolognese, the lasagna, caprese, chianti, and tiramisu. Will be back many times.
author: Mo M.

description: Food here was absolutely delicious!! If you want real home style Italian cooking this is where you want to come! I had the fettuccine primavera and the cream sauce just made it even more yummy! We also received our food like 5-10 mins after ordering and it was still that good, not undercooked not over cooked just right!! The place is a little small but you can't beat the great food!
author: Kalee K.

description:
Just dined at IL Borgo. Wonderful restaurant. Our first visit to this restaurant. The food was amazing, Pizza to start. Delicious!   

Main courses we had were all amazing too. We will return!

Our serving staff were so friendly and made our experience at Il Borgo,
author: Jon K.

description: Got a pizza to go last night and it was the worst pizza I have had anywhere, ever. A total waste of money. I threw it away. Soggy and greasy, the homemade sausage had no seasoning or flavor other than plain meat. It was underdone and yuck. Given global warming and our political situation, I want to like and enjoy my pizza at the end of a long workday, but this pie was truly dreadful. Sorry, folks.
author: Basya P.

description:
It seems like there are a lot of mixed reviews of this place.

PROS:

- Food itself was really good. We tried sausage ravioli, stuffed chicken.

CONS:

- Service is terrible. Host and server are rude, barely acknowledge you as you come in, never refilled water.
- Portions are very inconsistent. Chicken dish was huge, ravioli was tiny. 
- Loud and cramped on a weekend night
author: Greg S.

description:
This has been the place my husband raves about... no lasagna tops this place and I've always seen it driving by. I love little quirky places where the owner is in the kitchen  but I questioned it until we opened the door and walked inside. Once inside it feels like you're in Italy because of all the cute/cheesy decorations. I love that. It's not trying it just is and They've been around a long time. 

Ok the bread is homemade, the pesto gnocchi is handmade and feels like o get a kiss on the cheek with each bite. Pesto is like my catnip and theirs is homemade too, fresh and grassy with a little sweetness. 

My husbands lasanga was devoured by both of us because he's right, it's the absolute best. It has a bright flavor like heirloom tomatoes, not salty like most. The noodles are all different sizes with the perfect consistency and it's so comforting. 

Please come and support this amazing food. I should have taken before pictures but we ate it so fast!
author: Lillian S.

description: Visiting my son in SF from Boston, my wife and I had eaten here last year and were waiting to return because we were impressed. Not so much this year!  After seating, the waitress came over to ask about drinks, we also ordered at that time, but she really was  not very cordial and whisked my wife's wine glass off the table rather hastily as if she was annoyed because she didn't order any. She ordered the gnocci and I ordered the lobster ravioli. The food came out quickly and upon serving she asked if we wanted grating cheese. I said definitely and the waitress immediately put on a scorned face and said " gnocci you put cheese on but in Italy we don't put cheese on seafood". She took two steps away and stopped and looked at me like there was something wrong with me and then got the cheese. I came here to have a nice relaxing meal and now I found myself irritated that she had such an attitude. Italian/American, from Boston, I don't need her telling me how to eat Italian food!  Even if that was the case, you don't chastise a customer. From he start this woman had an edge.  As I am eating, I am so aggravated about her attitude, when she came to the table to ask how everything was, I told her "I'm Italian and I didn't think she should tell people how to eat their food". Now she said she was just telling me how they do it in Italy.  She said she wasn't being critical and I was being intimidating.  My wife tried to explain how her behavior was not appealing. Now she says because I complained about her that I was mental! I don't know how the dining experience can change so drastically in 1 year, but as I scanned through the reviews, I am not the only one who has a problem with this woman. Plenty of restaurants around to spend your hard earned money. Don't go here. Food was better than good, but it isn't great. Not worth the abuse!
author: R C.

description: Randomly stopped in while we were in the neighborhood, and we're quite pleasantly surprised! The homemade noodles were great, and we all really enjoyed the dishes. Cute Italian theme, and the lady who waited on us was very nice.
author: Stephen R.

description:
I was really disappointed with this place.

First, we arrived at 6:30 and had made a reservation through Open Table (via Yelp) for 2. The host was super rude and kept saying he didn't have us in their system until 7:30. I gave him my name and showed him my email confirmation with the date/time.
He still made an unnecessary scene and soured my experience there right off the bat.

Luckily, there was a table for 2 available and we were seated after reservation-gate.

It took a while for us to get water for the table and my glass was empty multiple times through the evening.

The food was pretty disappointing too. Bruschetta was only good bite (and I'll give this place one star for that). The bread that came to the table was cold and pale/sad. The gnocchi and pesto sauce I had was flavorless and overcooked/mushy. I only ate about a fourth of it. 

I won't be back. Much better Italian food and service elsewhere in the City.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Food was terrible. I had the penne arrabbiata which is so simple but it tasted like tomato paste sauce, completely undercooked and with little to no spice. To top it off I asked for sausage to be added and they added a sweet tarragon sausage which defeats the purpose of a spicy arrabbiata sauce and tarragon totally clashes with most flavors and totally ruined this already lacking dish. My friend's food was equally gross. And we spent $110 on this disaster. Never again.
author: Michelle M.

description: If you are looking for home style, really good Italian food, you are in the right place.  We went there before a performance and it was a great experience IF you get there at LEAST two hours prior to show time.  The place is understaffed, so plan ahead.  We got there just after 5 and it was a delight that you could actually hear each other talk.  As it filled up, yes, it became the average noise level.  But if you can find charm easily, you will easily have a very good meal there. Do go.
author: Bruce R.

description:
Worst experience I had so far in a restaurant! 
Horrible service! The food wasn't good as well. 
When I asked to return what I ordered, the waiter asked me what do I want her to do with it, and did me a favor not to charge me. 
My friends that were with me ate what they ordered but the food wasn't tasty.
author: Itay L.

description:
This is the kind of old-fashioned Italian place that I thought existed only in mid-century romantic comedies probably starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson playing a bickering couple trying to rekindle the spark in their marriage by coming back to the place where he proposed. It has all the period-appropriate set decoration detail - the checkerboard tablecloths, the melted candles in aged Chianti bottles, the walls painted with Milanese cafe scenes. All they need now is a scruffy mutt and a cocker spaniel sharing a strand of spaghetti in the back alley.

I wasn't even aware that Il Borgo existed until I convinced Jamie W. to bypass our regular Italian standby, Stelline, in favor of another similarly themed ristorante. We liked it for the no-frills choices on the menu. There are quite a few pasta dishes, several pizzas, some veal scallopini options - in other words, what you would expect a family-run neighborhood place to serve. We started with two very typical appetizers. The $7 Caprese was pretty standard - a quartet of Roma tomato slices with only a trio of Mozzarella slices with three basil leaves (see photo). Despite the perceived miscounting, it provided satisfaction.

However, in making the inevitable comparison, I have to say it lies completely in the shadow of the much fresher-tasting Caprese at Stelline. What did stand out was the $7 Bruschetta, which was a generous mound of chopped tomatoes marinaded in olive oil and minced garlic, all of it atop a trio of oven-toasted bread slices (see photo). That was a genuinely delicious appetizer and not as wet as you expect since they were easy to pick up. Jamie and I both decided to order pasta dishes. He went with a classic $11.75 plate of Spaghetti Carbonara (see photo).

It was an abundant portion that seamlessly mixed pieces of pancetta, garlic, Parmigiana-Reggiano cheese and eggs. There was nothing extraordinary about the execution, but it was hearty eating on a chilly Friday evening. Mine was better, the $12.75 Penne E Funghi Salsiccie, which mixed nicely al dente penne with plenty of sautéed mushrooms and chunks of Italian sausage that provided a nice kick of spice to the dish (see photo). We didn't have enough room in our bellies for any dessert which I am guessing would have included a spumoni and a tiramisu. Predictable? sure. Good eats? Uh-huh.

FOOD - 4 stars...good, no-frills, no-fuss Italian food that satisfies the belly
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...an old-fashioned vibe that provides a nice contrast to  all the surrounding hipster joints
SERVICE - 4 stars...definitely a family operation and part of its charm
TOTAL - 4 stars...not as fresh-tasting as Stelline but a worthy Italiano contender, paisan!
author: Ed U.

description: Friendly neighborhood Italian place. Very nice and attentive service, wonderful sauces on their pasta. A little quiet, off the beaten path. Worth checking out.
author: Jeremy B.

description: We eat at Il Borgo before going to the sf symphony on a regular basis! What a cute restaurant and it's unlike all the other Hayes valley restaurants. I love the food, the decor, and the fact it's off the beaten path. The food is wonderful, perhaps one of the best Italian places in the city. It's not your typical Americanized Italian food, thankfully. I have had and LOVED the carbonara, lobster ravioli, and lasagna. I love them so much that I haven't ordered anything else! Any friends I have taken have enjoyed whatever they have ordered. The inside of the restaurant is painted so that it looks like you are in an outdoor square in Italy. I highly recommend it for date night!! My boyfriend lived in Italy for seven years and this is his favorite place to eat in the area. The owner is very nice and every time we've eaten here, we have loved it.
author: K K.

description: Some of the best gnocchi I've had. I've had the gnocchi with pesto and with the bolognese sauce. Both are amazing. The bolognese is my favorite. Only other comment is that they aren't always the friendliest, especially if you pay with card instead of cash.
author: Robin O.

description:
My wife & I had dinner with another couple on Saturday 9 April. This was our second visit to this small family run Italian restaurant. We had a 5:15PM reservation and the restaurant quickly filled in shortly after we arrived. This is obviously a popular local eatery.
 
My wife ordered the Penne E Funghi Salsiccie $13, our friends ordered the Ravioli $13.50 with a Mista salad $7 , and Vitello Saltimbocca $23 with a bowl of vegetable soup $4. I ordered the Funghi E Salsice Pizza $13. Everyone enjoyed their meals.
My pizza was very good with a cracker thin crust and plenty of mushrooms and tasty Italian sausage. Our friends finished their meal by sharing an order of Tiramisu. The serving size of all the meals, and dessert, were generous.
 
A special mention about the soup - it does not appear on the menu, so you need to ask. My friend's vegetable soup looked delicious and I was a bit sorry I passed on the soup, but I knew I had a pizza in my near term future.
 
The service was quite good, especially considering the crowd in this small restaurant. 
 
Good Italian food at a good price, is reason enough to return to Il Borgo.
author: Len S.

description: I came in here on a Saturday night with a friend. She's Italian and recommended this place as she visited two times before on weekdays. When entering, it took a while to receive water or even have our orders taken. After that, we didn't receive bread until after the table next to us. When I asked about the bread, they said it was currently baking. The bread we received however was cold and slightly burnt so that was obviously a lie. We also didn't receive olive oil or a bowl like the other tables. Likewise the food wasn't that great. My friend got a pizza and I had the penne with anchovies. I didn't have much anchovies in my dish and it didn't taste like quality Italian food in the slightest. They didn't even offer to put cheese on our plates like the other tables. It took so long for them to notice we were finished as well and I had to ask for the check. Poor service, poor food, wouldn't come again
author: Amani R.

description:
I wanted to like it - I really did. I love those old style Dago restaurants that I grew up on. They have all of the classics like Scaloppini, Fettuccini Alfredo, Carbonara, Saltimbocca, Lasagna etc. 

I ordered the Chicken Piccata which should be pounded chicken with some cheese and a lemon butter sauce with capers. It was a big flattened piece of Chicken with cheese that had basil inside of it - kind of overwhelming unless you love basil that much. But more importantly it had this light brownish gelled or is it jello'd sauce on it - kind of like cold gravy but it wasn't cold. It was thick and tasted like they didn't wait for the sauce to get thicker but thickened it up with flour or cornstarch - but used too much. 

My friend had the Lasagneta which is Lasagna - they roll a big piece then get slices and lay them on the plate - it's a good idea but the sauce is more like a cream sauce with a little bit of tomato sauce added in not the other way around. I personally thought both of them sucked. Can't be anymore descriptive than that - sure it was inexpensive if the dishes were decent but they weren't. The prices are mostly $14 thru $26. 

Good wine prices - I needed the wine to get through the meal. We also split a Carpaccio which was good and the bread was good too. And don't ask the lady for wine advice - not a clue.
author: Rew C.

description:
What a positively delightful experience. It was relaxing, romántico, and the food was awesome! Authentic Italian food. It doesn't get better than this. 

The atmosphere is casual, but you could certainly come here on a date. The walls are painted with a beautiful picture and soft colors that are warm and inviting. The waitress seems like a family member of the business, she was so polite and welcoming. I felt at ease right away. We got served warm bread and wine was served right out of the bottle from our table. 

When the food arrived, I could not get enough. I was so full but I wanted to keep eating. Really wonderful place to be at. I hope we can come back again soon.
author: Svetlana S.

description: I don't normally like getting pasta in a restaurant as I think it's overrated, but I'm glad I did here! The artichoke ravioli was delicious! This place is very worth a visit
author: Debbie G.

description:
Horrible service, and DIRTY utensils. As everyone else has noted. I rarely write reviews, let alone bad ones... but I must share this one:

I found egg 'caked' onto my fork from the dishwasher, I requested to get a clean utensil. The waittress didn't apologize or anything, yanked the fork and gave me a new one. We ordered wine. She brought me a glass, and the glass was filthy. It literally had a layer of soap caked onto the wine glass both at the base, stem and actual cup.  It was so thick, that it actually had rough texture that can easily be felt.  I didn't really want to drink from a dirty wine glass. No big deal -- ask for a new one, right?

So I did, and instead of apologizing, she just mocked me in front of my date. She said "How do you deal with someone so picky? You must be so patient?" I couldn't even get a word in. She just kept confidently insulting me. 

On top of that, she didn't even come check to see if our food was good once throughout the meal. (quality check)

The food is the most redeeming part -- and it's still average at best, there is a good reason to go here.
author: Alex M.

description: Very nice experience despite mixed expectations. I found the service to be very good. The bread is delicious and warm. We shared the vegetable lasagna and gnocchi with pesto; both were very good and tasted freshly made. The Chianti by the glass was excellent and a very generous pour for $8. Wines by the glass are not listed, you have to ask. The interior and music is very pleasant, reminding me of my recent trip to Rome.
author: John H.

description:
My job held our Christmas party at this restaurant. I had the spaghetti pomodoro and manfriend had the salmon, both delicious. Good sized servings and excellent appetizers. Everyone seemed happy with their dishes.
We were a party of 14 and they were able to fit us in by sitting 4 people on a separate table, but it is a small place and space was really tight. I wouldn't bring a group larger than 10 or 12.
Even with how busy it was service was great. I recommend this place for a date night.
author: Carolina P.

description:
For the longest time, I've wanted to try Il Borgo.  Usually, when I'm coming off the Bay Bridge to go home, my route off Octavia leaves me stuck at a red light at Fell and Laguna.  During those 30 seconds, as I wait for the light to turn green, I would sit and wonder if Il Borgo was any good.  Just as I tell myself that I'm going to finally check them out though, the light changes, I go on my way, and I forget that Il Borgo even exists.  That is, until I'm stuck at that light again.  So when my friend recently suggested we go to Il Borgo for dinner, my immediate thought was "Where the hell is that?".

When we arrived, it was nice that we were seated immediately, but it kinda sucked that our table was right next to the door.  Since it was such a cold night, there was a bit of a chill whenever someone walked in or out.  Skimming the menu, I was impressed to see they offered a good mix of dishes and at prices that are pretty reasonable compared to other Italian joints in SF.  Since we wanted to share a couple of dishes, we ordered the Funghi e Salsice pizza (mushroom and sausage) and the Spaghetti Carbonara.  

Although the portions were pretty good for the price, our food left me conflicted.  The pizza tasted pretty good, and I liked how they didn't skimp on the toppings, but man was it oily.  Sure, there was sausage on it, but wow.  Plus, since the crust was so thin, the slices were kinda limp and soggy with oil.  As for the pasta, I really liked the pancetta (how can you not?), but I thought the sauce fell short.  Maybe this is the was it's supposed to be made, but it reminded me more of an alfredo dish than the spaghetti carbonaras I've had in the past.  

The service was pretty good, especially since the waitress (the owner?) was the only one taking care of each table.  It's a slight bummer that the place is CASH ONLY, but I think I saw an ATM towards the back (there are probably fees though).  Despite the prices, I'm not sure I would come all the way back, but at least I don't have to sit at that light and wonder what Il Borgo is all about anymore.
author: Mike L.

description:
I've passed this place for years with a skeptical eye for some silly reason and man, I wish we had gone years ago! 
Tasty, comforting Italian food at a decent price in large portions. The Lasagneta with proscuitto was DELIGHTFUL and the Gnocchi with pesto - hoooooly cow. I literally rolled my eyes in pleasure every time I took a bite. Soft, pillowy, cloud-like gnocchi goodness. You can choose other sauces for the gnocchi if you're not into pesto. The Lasagneta is in a sauce similar to a vodka sauce, which come on, is never a bad thing.  

The bread they give you in the beginning is so soft and served warm, its a great start to the meal. So why only 4 stars? Negative points for cleanliness. Coulda been the people who sat at the table before us, not sure. 

The rest of the meal was so good we could overlook these elements...definitely going again!
author: Sabrina S.

description:
We were not familiar with Il Borgo but a good Open Table rating and the availability of reservations when our "usuals" were booked enticed us. The space itself is cute -- reminded us a bit of the late and lamented Little Italy out in the Noe Valley -- and surprisingly quiet for a San Francisco restaurant. Our greeter was our server and she was pleasant if not remotely fawning; pretty businesslike on the whole, which is not surprising since she was the only server in the restaurant. 

We were enticed by the pasta offerings, so did not go too far into the menu, ordering only salads and pasta. More specifically, my wife and our friend both ordered the house salad for a starter and I had a caprese. The house salad was somewhat bitter because it was almost entirely radicchio but the dressing and gorgonzola were lovely My caprese had heirloom tomatoes, something I don't often see, and excellent fresh mozzarella, but, to quibble, the dressing was a bit too herbed for my taste. 

We each had a different pasta. Our friend wanted her salmon pasta with penne rather than standard spaghetti and I wanted my puttanesca with spaghetti rather than the standard penne. The server assured us this would not be a problem. My spaghetti was cooked absolutely perfectly and the puttanesca was a good version with a strong taste of kalamata because the olives were nearly whole rather than pieced. The salmon in our friend's dish was extremely moist, which made it enjoyable, and my wife's penne with sausage and mushroom had a lot of both signature ingredients, making it probably the safest dish to recommend of all that we had. 

Prices were beyond reasonable. While the salads were pretty conventionally priced for the Hayes Valley, the pastas were $13 and $14 and the portions generous. I haven't paid that little for pasta -- especially good pasta -- in years.  We are adding this one to our rotation of pre-SFJazz concert dining spots in the Hayes Valley/Civic Center area.
author: Mike R.

description: Delicious pizza and really nice people. They just accomodated a late night to go order for a large group and really saved us! Would def come back!
author: Jason H.

description: What a fantastic place!!! Small enough to be quaint but big enough to accommodate our big party of 12 on relatively short notice. The host/server was fantastic and all employees helped out to make sure we never wanted for anything. Our group had just about everything on the menu and there wasn't a bad meal. Everything was FULL of flavor and served hot and perfect sized portions! Great atmosphere with the candles on the table and the lighting in the restaurant. Will definitely visit again the next time I'm in the city!!
author: Vikki M.

description:
Maybe 5 stars is a little on the high side. But, nobody should ever rate this pace any less than 3 stars. The menu isn't super big, it's on the small side. But, it's a good menu. The food is good and the atmosphere is great! 

It's very romantic. It's pretty affordable for SF. Not too expensive. It's walking distance from my house, so I have been here three times now. And I have to say I've enjoyed it very much every time. 

The caprese salad is one of my favorite appetizers. And the quatro pizza was quite good, as well. My boyfriend loves the carbonara.
author: Heather B.

description:
I rarely write reviews, but when I do I feel it's due to superb or extremely terrible experiences. We came to this restaurant when it was not busy and the food was 'meh' -nothing great, nothing terrible.

The service was horrendous, never dealt with worse. The waitress made it seem like she was doing us a favor. I asked for clean plates to share our dishes, and in a very passive aggressive manner she asked why I let her take our other (dirty) plates. Excuse me? 

She also overcharged us. I left the restaurant really agitated and annoyed, will definitely not be going back. Restaurants go out of business constantly in this city, and with service like that this place will be out soon.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place more, as it is close to my neighborhood and the people are really nice, but in the end it balanced into a 3 star review:

The wait staff are nice, but were a little off on Saturday; the table was only partially set and we had to repeatedly request the missing items, like forks or knives. They then brought us bread, and an empty butter container. No plates. The waitress looked a little befuddled and confused the entire meal, but she was pleasant and we weren't in a rush.

The food is pretty reasonably priced, but I can see where they skimped a little. My veal was mediocre meat quality, though it was cooked fine. My friends enjoyed their pizza. 

Overall it was decent value, but with slightly better food and less confused wait staff it will earn the 4th star.
author: Jordan C.

description: I like this little place!  I go before or after an event at the performing arts spaces by Civic Center.  Solid, old-school Italian, checkered tablecloths, attentive service, all good. Antipasti, pastas, decent wine list to go with. Comfort food!
author: Laura H.

description:
Hideaway gem amongst gentrified, hipsterized sf dining.  

Excellent, simple Italian dishes.  Warm, friendly staff.  The owner is always polite, welcoming and attentive.

Always always good food.

Favorites:

insalata del borgo
bruschetta 
lobster ravioli
bolognaise

and absolutely save room for the tiramisu.  Best I have every had.
author: B K.

description:
My first impression was that it was kind of a cozy, traditional Italian restaurant, even though I found the decor to be a little cliche. 

After being seated and looking over the menu, we were hungry and also getting excited to eat. So the waitress came to our table and greeted us, and told us she'd be back to "take our order." ......Then disappears for 15 minutes? We had to hunt her down again place the order. I had a bad feeling at this point, thinking that most likely the food would also be delayed (me and my boyfriend were already starving). But fine, the waitress finally returns and we place our orders. I ordered the Chicken Piccata, one of my favorite dishes at some of my other Italian spots we go to a lot.

Sure enough, we had to ask for order updates 3 times! And when my Chicken finally arrived, it was tasteless, but I was so hungry I ate about half. Plus, the food wasn't warm, it was kind of cool and that made me wonder if our order had been finished sooner, and just forgotten about? The wine was passable, maybe the best and most nutritious part of our meal.

Here's where it gets strange: once we received the bill , my boyfriend put down his credit card. Casually, my eyes wandered across the room, and I caught a glance of our waitress - watching him place his credit card into the check.... and she rolls her eyes! Only to make her way back, after a purposefully long wait, and still has the gall to furiously ask us to pay cash? First we thought it was a joke, but she really was insisting on cash! We refused several times before she spun around in a temper tantrum to go swipe his card.

With a little effort this place can do a lot better, please work on customer service, food timing, and credit card processing.
author: Mackenzie C.

description: Amazing "Mom and Pop" Italian restaurant with fresh baked bread, house made pasta, and very generous portions - yum!
author: Elly I.

description: Had a very nice dinner here with friends. Some were late and the owner was very accommodating. The ambience is rustic, but homey. The food was authentic with well seasoned veggies. I had the veal saltimbocca which was delicious and served with broccoli and roasted potatoes. The prices are reasonable and I would recommend ordering off of the chef's menu. Good food, good value, decent location.
author: Bruce L.

description:
Food tastes microwaved. The chicken was lukewarm on the outside, refrigerated on the inside. And if you happen to use a credit card, you'll get an earful from the Italian woman! I could look past this, but the food is just meh. 
It's San Francisco; there are literally a hundred other Italian restaurants to choose from, this one's just not worth it.
author: Vin A.

description:
Il Borgo is a pretty standard Italian restaurant -- to be honest, it reminds me a lot of Olive Garden, but maybe I just don't know my Italian food well enough. I went in on a Friday night around 7 pm, and the restaurant was pretty empty. Servers were patient and attentive as we waited for the rest of our party to arrive.

In terms of food, I had the fettucine del borgo, and while it was alright, I think it could have used a little bit more flavor. I didn't hear any of my friends raving about their food, but there weren't any complaints, either. All in all, a mediocre experience, but better Italian food can be found in San Francisco!
author: Kelly R.

description: This place is amazing! My fiancé and I come here all the time. Definitely recommend their bruschetta, lasagne, and tiramisu. We love the intimate atmosphere and their staff is wonderful!
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Holy meatballs, I have never experienced such terrible service in a restaurant. First, here are the "pros": good location, cute old school red and white checkered tablecloth, and the food doesn't suck (note: that does not mean it is great, it just wasn't terrible). 

Now all of the cons, which are all service based. First, I should say the young woman who seated me, gave us our menus and brought us out our food was pleasant and helpful. That is where the good service ends here. First of all, this was obviously a pre-7pm show crowd, and yet we had to ask to order a total of 3 times, and when the person we originally flagged over came to take our order, maybe 10 minutes later, he just said "okay, i'm here." No apologies for making us wait. Totally rude. 

Here's where it gets creepy. I don't know what his role was - bus boy or server, but this dude had to either be totally inappropriate, or, most likely, WASTED. At first I thought maybe his English just wasn't that good and there was just a little lost in translation kind of thing happening, but no, he was wildly inappropriate and obviously drunk. When he uncorked our wine he just left it on the table...wasn't going to pour any glasses...then he grabbed a bunch of our glasses to pour but he couldn't seem to figure out how or which order to pour them in. So we asked him to just leave the bottle at our table, and we would pour it. Then he stood there, smelling the cork, staring creepily at us. . .we literally had to ask him to please leave us alone. I was ready to walk out, but thankfully he didn't come back to our table after that. 

Another gem: we asked for grated cheese. After about 10 minutes of waiting, someone just dropped off a giant hunk of cheese and a cheese grater at our table....what the actual eff...?

Oh, and then when we paid, we found someone else's credit card (in addition to ours) with our check, and they somehow combined our bill with someone else's and split the charge, and we ended up with this poor guy's card, who ended up being overcharged for his meal! We didn't ask to split the check or anything, we literally handed them one card, and yet they couldn't even handle properly charging us for our meal. We are nice people, and wanted to make sure this other guy wasn't screwed, so we brought it to their attention before leaving. 

Unfortunately I didn't start reading the bad reviews about service until after I arrived and was waiting for my friends, but BELIEVE THE BAD REVIEWS ABOUT SERVICE. I will NEVER come back here, and unless you have absolutely no other options, do not waste your time here. There is absolutely nothing about this place that redeems that horrible service, it is inexcusable, and paying customers who were not once rude to any of the staff do not deserve to be treated like that. So absurd. I almost feel like I was being punked.

This restaurant would be an excellent candidate for Gordon Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Il Borgo is by no means an overpriced Italian eatery with expensive cocktails, or a place to go to be seen. It is a great, small and family run Italian restaurant with no frills and delicious food at a great value. You may have driven by a few times and not even known that it is there because it is in a fairly unassuming location on a busy SF street. A great neighborhood restaurant that satisfies every time.

I live nearby so I have been multiple times and have never been disappointed. It is not the type of place that you go to and cross off your list as "tried it". It is the type of place that you go to when you want welcoming service and a good warm meal. The last time I went I had the Lasagnetta, and it was so good that it made me remember that I had to review this place. The wine list is short and adequately priced and the interior is welcoming and decorated just how a family run Italian restaurant should be.

Overall, I don't think that you will be blown away but I dare you to come here and not leave satisfied.
author: Frank J.

description:
Reasonably priced, casual romantic warm environment. This is such a quaint neighborhood restaurant. My husband and I took our 5-year old son there for dinner before an event at the opera house and had a special time. 

The food isn't particularly gourmet but it is yummy Italian comfort food. Our service was friendly. Thanks for a great dinner and we look forward to returning!
author: Angela W.

description: I've passed by this restaurant many times as I live nearby and would stop and peek in the window at people eating their meals and admiring the quaint Italian decor.  So I was really looking forward to the ambiance and food when I finally got the chance to eat there.  I went on a Saturday (4/8/17) evening arriving about 6:30 pm meeting up with a friend who was already there. There were two waiters working that night neither of which paid any attention to us as we waited.  My friend got one of their attention and asked for another glass of water.  We read the menus which were already on the table and made our decision.  Waited and waited. Then a sort of unkempt older guy comes over wearing jeans and wrinkled shirt with a green apron haphazardly tied and asked us, I think, if we were ready to order. (He looked more like a short order cook than a waiter).  No greeting of any kind! I asked for a glass of wine and he named the three wines of which I could only make out "Grigio" as the place was buzzing with conversations from other tables and with his accent it was hard to make out what he was saying. I ordered the penne mushroom and sausage with Italian sauce and my friend ordered the lobster ravioli. This "waiter" was very preoccupied his manner was one of impatience and he seemed irritated about something. He was not pleasant. So he poured the Grigio and left and later I got his attention and asked for a different wine as the Grigio was of poor quality. I asked for a red wine this time, I couldn't understand what he said about the vintage but I didn't like the taste of it either, however, I kept it.  When the herb salad arrived it was fresh and tasty and the bread was also put upon the table at the same time. A few bites into the salad the main meals arrived of penne and ravioli. Now the tables in this restaurant are really small so our table was crowded with platters, the salad, bread, glasses of water, and wine glass. My friend asked for tea so we had a tea pot on the table too of which our waiter, who never introduced himself, sloppily pushed 3 bags of green tea in between the dishes and made no offer to take away any of the dishes on the crowded table. One of the two waiters happened to be walking by and we asked her to take away some of the dishes. By the way the other two waiters were dressed professionally in black pants, white shirt, and white neat aprons. The penne with mushroom and sausage was well prepared and tasty but nothing memorable and my friend was disappointed with his lobster ravioli as he said it was bland. He said there was no noticeable lobster taste. I tasted it for myself and there was just the slightest hint of a lobster taste and indeed the sauce was bland. Sorry to say I was disappointed in the service and the meal. The bathroom was cool with a big dungeon-like lock on the door.
author: Zii R.

description: Good little restaurant.  I went on a rainy night and it felt super cozy inside.  Only locals there were eating which is always a good sign.  Staff was friendly, a bit curt but not in a rude way.  And then....a random surprise in the bathroom that will make you smile and keep you wondering if that just happened...
author: Jordan M.

description:
15.06.00     First Visit

Food ------------------- 3 1/2 stars (overall)      
Food/Price -----------  YES  (bang for the buck)
                                  Let's be real
                                  Most of us can't eat 4-5 stars everyday
                                  Unless u are borned with a silver spoon
                                  Able to enjoy the basic to fancy (diversity) is good                                  

Solid Italian food
Generous portion
  are u tired to eating $18 pasta dishes w half the portion of this place?
  sometimes I wonder about those places

Mushroom Pizza was pretty good.
Lobster ravioli
 was very good for me.
 can't wait to get it again!

Simple, Bang for the buck
Interior ... 
A place I would revisit time to time
 good taste
 reasonable price
author: S.K. Y.

description:
The restaurant came highly recommended as an unnoticed neighborhood gem. I agree; nice little gem that is good for a casual dinner with friends. Food was good. We were a group and ordered the house salad, beef Carpaccio, mushroom pizza, lobster ravioli, chicken fettuccine, and meat lasagna, and a bottle of red wine. Overall the food was good and decently priced. The total bill was about $180. My favorite dish was the rolled meat lasagna and ravioli. Both I think had the same sauce. The beef Carpaccio was not completely thawed. However, a few small items that would have made the meal better:
1. All food consistently hot; only the lasagna temperature was to my liking.
2. Warm bread
3. A house salad that had a few more of the basic essentials; it was just romaine lettuce and dressing
4. Came on one of the colder SF nights and little heat would have made the experience more comfortable.

The service was good; all provided by one woman who served as host and waitress. I would come again.
author: Trudie S.

description: I have been to Il Borgo for years and recently quite often. I find the selection good, the food well made, the service excellent and the ambience great. Its a hidden gem in Hayes Valley. For high quality, homemade Italian food try this . Its a winner all around
author: Victor R.

description: First time at Il Borgo and loved it. Ideal for low-key nights - neighborhood gem. We shared a chicken entree, pasta, and pizza. High quality ingredients and fresh pasta. All were fantastic! The owner was working in the kitchen, you can see he cares. Highly recommend.
author: Sarah M.

description: What's sad about this whole situation is that Il Borgo was the very first place that my husband and I dined in San Francisco when we moved here.  It had a special place in my heart.  Until today.  We ordered our meal for delivery and when it arrived one of our entrees was missing.
