I proceeded to call the restaurant to let them know that it was missing and the person who answered told me that it was not her fault and that she was too busy to care about my missing entree.  She told me to call the delivery driver and complain to him.  After not hearing from the delivery driver I called the restaurant again and again got treated completely unprofessionally.  The lady who answered the phone told me that I would again need to call the delivery driver.  At which point I asked for a refund.  She told me that she was not going to give me a refund.  She screamed f*** you and hung up the phone.  I would NOT recommend this place to anyone.  It is a disgrace.  The customer services is terrible and if there is an alternative place to eat, please go there.
author: Josh C.

description:
My husband and I have been to Il Borgo too many times to count. I love this place. The decor is pretty kitschy, but it's part of what I love about it (minus the mickey mouse in the bathroom, that is just unhygienic and strange). After all, if you've ever been to Italy, most of the restaurants actually look like this - super casual, no frills, some weird decor, cheap wine, the best simple pasta dishes ever, and, yes, even the slightly undersalted bread. Try to order their house-made pasta dishes, it really sets them apart. I can't even begin to tell you how amazing the vegetarian lasagnetta is, even if you're a meat eater. 

As for service, the same Italian woman is there almost every time we go - and always smiling. We've ordered takeout from there numerous times as well and she's literally smiling through the phone, I can hear it. Plus the food is always done in 10 minutes. Bonus!

So if you're in the mood to feel like you are at your Nonna's house, this place comes highly recommended.
author: Meg V.

description: Best Italian I have had in a long time!! Love the ambiance and the service was great. Can't wait to go back again.
author: Samita S.

description: Had dinner here this week with my brother and his wife. The menu has a nice variety of appetizers, soups, and entrees. I had the Caprese salad and the Prosciutto Lasagna and both were delicious. The Lasagna has spices, herbs and a touch of salt that made it taste different from the conventional Lasagnas. The restaurant is larger than most Thai restaurants I've been to, and it's very nicely decorated as well. Prices are much better than other Italian restaurants, but that's probably because this is a small family run restaurant. My entree was $13.75, while at most other Bay Area Italian restaurants, similar dishes are around $17-$20. Still, it was a pretty good experience
author: Cecilia C.

description:
The food was great, I took the carbonara and my friends had the ravioli and the lasagneta. All were great! We had the tiramisu for dessert. All were great.

Why is the score so low?

The service was painfully slow and bad. The lady have is a headache and broke conversation several times. Also she was not willing to take credit cards, mainly our American Express cards. Finally she took one card and made us pay the rest in cash.

As I travel mainly for business and this place is not in range best location I think I will go elsewhere next time.
author: Didi D.

description: I love pasta! This is the first time I've dined at a Italian place where I couldn't eat the pasta and the bread looked reused and old. The service was so so as well. Bummed cause it's cute little place.
author: Angela A.

description:
Worst restaurant experience in my life. The food was great but the service was terrible! I am never coming back. 
I came here for my parents to meet my boyfriends parents. The server was very rude to us and did not smile at all. Never repeated our order and walked away. She had a stick up her ass or something. When we asked for the check she asked if we wanted desserts or coffee, in which I replied "no" and then she rolled her eyes and walked away. When we were about to pay, she said that they only accept cash and not card, when it clearly says "we accept visa" outside of the building on their window. My boyfriend went up to her to tell her that and she said "my machine isn't working. Go get me cash or check" and then turned around. We were mortified because my boyfriend was paying for everything and she made him look bad. We eventually got cash from the ATM and gave her the money without tip because we wanted the check presenter back. She came to me and told me that she didn't include the tip and that we had to leave a tip. RUDE. We left a dollar. She can suck my ass. My advice for everyone out there: DO NOT COME TO EAT HERE. I am certain that you can find better Italian places in the city with GREAT customer service.
author: Marsha C.

description:
My review is a good three months late, but I couldn't let it slide and not write one because other people just had to be warned about this place. 

I came here with my friends back in September because the other restaurants we were by had a long wait and the wait here was much shorter. We had a larger party (about 7 or so people) which made it hard to find a table on a weekend night without a 30 minute wait. 

At first we thought the restaurant was pretty quaint and charming however no matter how cute a restaurant is at first glance, it's really irrelevant if that food and service are both awful. After we ordered, we asked the guy who took our order if we could get separate checks when we paid. As soon as we requested this he looked at us and groaned. I've worked in customer service for over year, and I know that this is no way to treat customers! Actually, I'm pretty sure working in customer service isn't even necessary to know that this isn't right. We were slightly put off by the way that he reacted to us asking for separate checks as we had requested it in advance rather than at the end when we're paying (because I understand that's more annoying). 

The food arrived and my friend's food was made incorrectly. She had asked multiple times for it to be made without chicken and, behold, there was chicken in her pasta. The food was nothing to rave about. The tomato sauces felt like they were lacking that little zing. In all honesty, the jarred Prego tomato sauces taste better than the ones from Il Borgo.

When we requested checks, he told us that all of our amounts, except for one dish, were the same even though all of our items were priced differently on the menu. Most of us were overcharged for the dish. Additionally, my friend was charged extra for not wanting meat in her pasta. When we asked him, he simply dismissed us and said that was how much we had to pay. The whole thing was simply confusing, and he was difficult to understand. Tips hadn't been added to our meal prices yet so it didn't make sense as to why we were being charged more and why all of our meals were coming out to the same price. 

All in all, we had an awful experience and would never come back. I'd advise you guys to the same. I had thought it would be a good meal, decent, at the very least, but boy was I wrong. Don't come here unless you enjoy bland, less than mediocre Italian food, rude service, and being overcharged for your meal.
author: Christy W.

description: Great people, great food. Be prepared to wait if you don't get there early. Pizza, pasta, wine, dessert, it's all good.
author: Tina L.

description:
Nice neighborhood spot!
Food...I say pretty good. 
Environment...pretty good. 
Friendliness...11 on a scale of 1 to 10. 
Price...very reasonable. 
Value...very good. (Generous portion sizes.)
author: Richard F.

description: I hate to give this place 2 stars, especially because the lasagna is just so ridiculously delicious, but the rest of the food is just whatever, the service is awful, and it's not that clean.  Despite the negatives, I've continued to go to this restaurant because the lasagna dish is just that good.  If you're craving a good lasagna, don't get annoyed by the rude waitress (I've always had the same one and can tolerate her), and can ignore some cleanliness issues, go here.
author: Negar A.

description:
Anticipated reunion.

Such good memories of the first time around. Lingered in such a way you very much want to do it again. Clearly better than most similar things encountered.

Ten plus years later made it back to what was and still might be my favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco. Fortunately now one can yelp to the world about the:

- Outstanding tomato-sauce based spaghetti with arguably more salmon than other restaurants will give as a main dish at an amazing $14 price

- Incredible in taste and quantity artichoke ravioli with more tomato sauce and the same amazing price of $14

- Deliciously rich homemade pistachio gelato with each bite almost worth the more than reasonable $6 price

- Hard to believe wine list where most bottles are ~$30 including the Rosso Di Torgiano blend which paired perfectly with all the above

Space remains small and intimate and not too crowded. Service was prompt and efficient though the lights on and music off made it clear they wanted us to leave around 10:30.

Understandable as it was past closing time but could have lingered a bit longer. After all it's hard to leave things that are better than you remember.
author: Jason B.

description: I was craving Italian and remember their lobster ravioli being decent. I don't know what happened but this place has gone down hill really fast. I asked for merlot, she gave me chianti. Everyone who came later got their food before us, and when I asked one of the workers about our food, the waitress yelled across the restaurant "it's coming!" When the food came, it was so bland I didn't want to waste the calories on it.... and I never skip on pasta. Never coming back.
author: Melanie S.

description: Lovely and quaint restaurant with great food and wine! They overheard that we were celebrating a birthday and brought over a wonderful chocolate dessert!
author: Roz G.

description:
CASH ONLY.  After Sebo we went to Il Borgo since it's nearby and B. wanted to eat more.  

We got:

FREE bread - just ok, but good w/ olive oil & balsamic oil

Antipasto misto $11.75 - mixed appetizer of artichoke hearts, olives, mozzarella & tomato.  Just ok.

Fettucine Del Borgo $13 - homemade pasta w/ sun dried tomatoes, chicken, & capers.  B. loved it.  I thought it was just ok.

B. got a glass of Chianti $7 - he loved it.

Subtotal $31.25 + $3 tax = $34.25 before tip.  CASH ONLY.
author: Ann L.

description:
Saw a symphony & wanted some Italian near the area. Other places more highly rated were packed so I came here, noticing that it was about a third empty. Found a seat near the door & waited for a menu. It took about five minutes for one to show up, with another 10 minute wait or so for my order to be taken. Asked the owner (I assumed--he spoke with a heavy accent) if they served bread & he answered abruptly that they did; some would be arriving from the oven soon enough. Ok....so I didn't order the bruschetta! Got the Lobster Raviolis (about $16) with a Caesar salad ($6) and a diet coke. 

The bread came in long, thin slices, absolutely boring. Then the salad arrived, unimpressively simple. No real flavor or pizazz; just romaine lettuce with croutons. The Raviolis were absolutely dreadful, long thin strips of bland pasta, with hardly any filling inside in a sauce that wasn't rich enough for my palate. However, the tiramisu I got for dessert was definitely delicious, if a little too soggy/mushy. My cappuccino was also well-done and worth the price, if only to get the taste of those terrible raviolis out of my mouth. 

I could easily give the dessert four stars, but the main course was some of the worst Italian food I've had out in years. So a "meh" for Il Borgo. 

P.S. $37 for the total meal.
author: Lew A.

description:
Food quality is inconsistent, I've been here three times and the first time the dishes were excellent, the second they were just OK and the last time I ordered the pasta was overcooked and sauces were a greasy mess.

But the fact that drove my experience down was the lady (owner or manager) attitude towards me. I walked in there for takeout and I didn't realize that there was a minimum for a credit card (it wasn't listed prominently on their website). When I took my credit card out - the lady very rudely told me that I should have gotten cash. 

It made me feel embarased and uncomfortable - so I decided to walk out to go to an ATM machine, but she called me back and ran my card, I was starting to feel better but then when my card got processed she ripped out the receipt from the machine angrily and slammed it down angrily on the table for me to sign - all the time giving a disapproving glaring look at me.

I signed, took my food and decided to avoid this place as much as I can. Very poor customer service. It's a shame because I live so close by, they could have made me a regular customer.
author: Nadeem K.

description:
A Co worker of my wife told her about this restuarant. We had a little trouble finding a parking spot but once we did everything else was great.

We ordered Pizza, gnocchi, Artichoke raviolis. My duaghters boy friend said it was the best Pizza he had every eaten. I had Pizza and I really liked it but would ask for the crust to be cooked just a little bit crisper. My daughter loved her gnocchi.

The italian Beer was very good.

We loved this place.
author: Mark M.

description: One of the best authentic Italian restaurant in San Francisco, complemented by best in class service!! We had Carpaccio and Bruschetta for appetizer and Lasangeta Al Vegetali, Lobster Ravioli and Fettuccine Del Borgo for main dish. All tested very good. The portion was good as well. Most of all, what a great environment!!
author: Mike N.

description:
Il Borgo is a nice little cozy Italian restaurant that makes you feel like you're eating just outside a restaurant in Italy.

We stumbled into this place by accident not 20 seconds after my girlfriend got a craving for gnocci. The hostess/waitress was really nice and took great care of us. We had the lobster ravioli and the gorgonzola gnocci. It was delicious and very reasonably priced.

Highlights: the decoration! Real candles, murals that make it seem like you're on an Italian street, the streetlight...
author: Hector R.

description:
Worst carbonara I had in a long time.  Red wine tasted funny. 

Avoid this place. There is a reason why it's empty. 

The wine tasted funny and when I told the server that $8 is very expensive for this wine she mentioned something the wine is special. I told her the wine is horrible - and guess what the server did??  She laughed. 


On other reviews:  if you never ate in Italy you might want to refrain from reviewing....
author: Flo B.

description:
Hands down one of the BEST & authentic Italian restaurants in SF (and thats saying a lot since there are so many amazing restaurants in SF). 

What to order: The lasagnetta and a glass of red wine!

I have take a lot of people to this location and everyone walking out thinking the same thing - AMAZING food. 

The host/owner is very friendly and helpful. Now that we are regulars offers always takes such good care of us.
author: Suki S.

description:
HORRIBLE! AVOID!!! Basically this "restaurant" is simply designed to rip people off. My wife and I had one of the most horrible experiences here. She came to visit for the weekend and it really tainted our time together in SF. If you want to eat in a dark, hot, stinking, worn-down dungeon environment then this is the restaurant for you. The proprietor Italian woman was really rude and nasty. The food was substandard and waaaay overpriced! The proprietor - who is also the sole waitress here - is basically trying to scam everyone for as much money as she can. Part of the tactic is to seem very busy so she doesn't spend too much time with you explaining anything. When we asked about if they have glasses of wine she rattled off a few and seemed really annoyed when I asked about the price. That's ludicrous. When we got the glasses of wine for eight dollars each, it was one of the worst I have ever tasted, rather like used dish-washing water.

Then, she tried to sneak onto our check a tip as part of the bill! WTF?!?! I believe this is illegal. It's up to me to leave a tip, not up to her to demand it!  We were a party of two (not a group - where some restaurants let you know in advance that a gratuity will be added to "parties of 6 or more) She tries to sneak a fast on on us by writing up a handwritten chicken scratch of a check where you can't really read anything. When I asked her to clearly write down and break out the charges she seemed very annoyed! As if I didn't have the right to ask and know exactly what I'm paying for! And, it's only because I asked for it to be broken down line by line I found out that she added a tip automatically onto the bill of about 15%! That is totally outrageous! When I questioned her about this scammy practice she said "her boss madkes her do it." SHE IS THE BOSS! Liar! I suspect if I would've just gone ahead and paid the final bill as per the chicken scratch paper and I would've gone ahead and tipped on that final amount she would've pocketed that money too (simply because it wasn't even disclosed to us that she added that the tip already!)

AVOID!! AVOID!!!
author: Miklos P.

description: I came here for Valentine's Day and my girlfriend and I loved it! From the outside, the place doesn't look like much, but the inside is so nice and cozy. Each table has a candle and the food is simply fantastic. Don't just walk by this place based on it's exterior. You will regret not checking it out. However, there is an eerie Mickey Mouse inside the restroom. It caught me off guard the first time I saw it, but I thought it was funny. Great place for dates.
author: Eric M.

description: First time and I really enjoyed it.  Very authentic Italian food and a great ambiance.  They say it's romantic which it is but I went with two other business colleges and it was fine, family seating at a long table.  The waitress might own it I forgot to ask but she speaks Italian to you to make you feel like your there.  I ordered a regular salad, which had quite a lot of garlic on it.  I like garlic but not quite that much.  The veal saltimbocca was fantastic and we got a side a spaghetti to share between us which was also unbelievable.  My colleges got chicken saltimbocca and a fettuccini which they both raved about.  We washed everything down with a cheap $8 glasses of Chianti and had a great evening.  Thank you for a great experience and a place we will return to.
author: Darold S.

description:
Came here last year with a party of over 10.  The food was alright.

Just a side note:

Be careful of where you park though. The area is not safe at night.
author: Forest S.

description: Classic old school Italian food - cute ambiance with checkered table cloths, candles, and Italian music. The owner was very kind to us ... And the food was delicious. I'd recommend this place.
author: Annie D.

description:
This is a little unassuming restaurant in Hayes Valley, run by a super friendly Italian woman and feels very homey.

I've ordered the Lasagnetta basically every time I've been and it's absolutely amazing! I've had bites of food from other people I've gone with, and while everything was good, nothing compared to the lasagnetta. Order that and you won't be disappointed!

It is cash only, but there's an ATM in the back.
author: Mallika M.

description:
We like to wander down when we have a craving for homemade pastas.  It's a cozy restaurant that's been around for years in a neighborhood with new places popping up seemingly every month.

It reminds me of little family owned place, I'd get to wander into when I've been lucky enough to be in Italy. Big plates of fresh pasta with good sauces, pizza cooked with a nice crispy crust and chewy dough. 'Mitra' our waitress always takes good care of us as she hops around the restaurant, taking orders in her big Italian accent. 

It's nice to have a mainstay with a good plate of fettuccine bolognese.
author: charles t.

description:
Il Borgo is one of my all time favorite places in San Francisco. It has a really nice, intimate, neighborhood/local vibe and the food is amazing. The owners are an Italian family who are always so incredibly nice and extremely hospitable. Everything is made fresh everyday, including the pasta. And boy can you tell! 

Highly recommend.
author: Evie A.

description: Delicious trattoria with a cute italian flair. The food is obviously authentic italian and the hostess, I want to say owner?, who was helping us out an absolute delight. In a cool little neighborhood, I'll def stop by here next time i'm in SF. And it doesn't hurt Smitten is right around the corner!
author: Laura P.

description:
I can't believe this place isn't five-stars across the board. My boyfriend and I came across this place totally by accident waiting for the ballet one night, and it's been a highlight of trips into the city ever since. We've brought his sister, who studied in Florence for a semester, and another friend who studied in Rome, and they both agreed it was like being back in Italy.

Yes, the reviews that said it's small and on the darker side are absolutely true. It's a little, family-owned place, and I'm sure the darker lighting is for ambiance (although I'll admit, it's a little overdone). Still, can't fault them for trying! And the food absolutely makes up for it.

Lasagnetta. That's all I have to say. You HAVE to get it, at least the first time you go. I've never had anything that's as amazing. Personally, I've never gotten anything else there, because after tasting it the first time it was the only thing I ever wanted to eat again for the rest of my life. My boyfriend has gotten about four or five of their other dishes, and each taste I've had has been delicious. But seriously, get the lasagnetta.

Yes, it is a bit pricey, but I mean, it's a restaurant in the middle of San Francisco. If you want cheap, go to the Tenderloin, or better yet, try Richmond. If you want good quality Italian food, be willing to pay a little more. I certainly wouldn't say that the prices are unfair at all, and while I was in San Francisco, I was a student.

Seriously, once you try their food, you'll know it's worth it.
author: Kaysee T.

description:
I have been here 11 times in the last two months. There are many reasons I continue to enjoy this place, but here are the ones that stick out most:

* AUTHENTIC FOOD: growing up with Italian food every night, i can say this food is authentic and addicting. They seem to have more of a northern Italian approach which isn't too rich in flavor. More olive oil vs butter, lighter sauces etc. but they also have some of the classic southern Italian dishes too.

* FAMILY BUSINESS (mom, dad and son) all seemingly straight from Italy
all of which are genuine as hell. speak Italian to you (they speak English too:) and with pleasure want to feed you and make you smile. i truly feel at home at Borgo.

* CLEAN; forget some of the angry reviews from the past, this place is CLEAN and food is FRESH every time i have been here in the last two months.

* AFFORDABLE. So difficult to find affordable Italian food in this city that tastes this great and more importantly consistent. I have ordered a few of the same things and always its perfectly the same great dish i had last time.

* CHARMING & COZY atmosphere. Wow, real candles everywhere!! melting over old vinegar and wine bottles. seriously detailed pho-painted artwork surround the entire interior making you feel like you are in fact in an outside patio on a warm evening in Italy! you won't want to leave.

* SERVICE. i am picky with service most of the time. i am not the easiest customer when eating out and i have no complaints thus far with il Borgo. after 11 times now of eating here, i can expect huge smiles when i walk in and a hug upon departure. ill be back again and again. 

If you haven't given it a shot, please do.
author: ELiOT S.

description:
Adorable.  Delicious.  GREAT ambience (didn't seem old and outdated to me - I thought it was cute).  Great beer.  Good prices.  We visited with folks that are good friends with the owners, so that helped alot, hehe.   

The food was really good!   Definitely worth a try.  :)
author: Stacey M.

description:
A girlfriend and I came to eat here prior to the Passenger concert at Slim's. As both of us are commuters, Hayes Valley was an easy spot to meet in that wasn't too far away from our destination. I'd heard good things about Il Borgo from another girlfriend, so we decided to give it a shot. 

Il Borgo is a hole-in-the-wall family place that could probably use a little TLC. It doesn't feel dirty- just out dated. 

Our server (the only one in the joint) was incredibly hospitable, until it came to paying.  We decided to cut the check right down the middle, and neither of us had cash. She was outwardly upset and mentioned it wasn't worth the taxes she would pay. We both apologized, and we're taken a back that she was so upset with us. We certainly weren't looking to screw her over! (We both left generous tips to make up for her anger...)

I ordered the Penne Alla Aribiatta and added pancetta. The pasta was cooked to perfection (chewy, firm, deliciousness) and the sauce was just the right amount of spicy. Could have bypassed the pancetta though- it was pure fat, little yum.

Il Borgo is not a place I'd rave about to others, but if you're looking for a decent, reasonably priced meal, its a-okay. Just don't split the check!
author: Annalise F.

description:
The food is really good, but the waitress is terrible and is the reason I have not returned. In general, the main waitress is sassy and has an attitude, making it less than pleasant during the course of the meal. I'm not sure why this restaurant hasn't heeded the feedback, as clearly I'm not alone. In my experience:

-She assumed my dad was my husband, and made an awkward comment about a romantic dinner during the check. When I corrected her she just said "oh you never know these days."
-I asked her what pasta she recommended between two, and she shrugged and just said they were different and laughed in a "i don't know what to tell you" manner.
-I asked if the tiramisu had a strong alcohol taste and she the same laugh and responded with "tiramisu is tiramisu."


I write this review because I hope Il Borgo will look into this. It's very unfortunate because the food here was awesome,  but I walk a few extra blocks to other Italian restaurants in Hayes Valley simply because I can't stand the waitress.
author: Ari R.

description:
I came here for a friend's birthday dinner. The service was okay. The woman was very nice and answered all of our questions. The decor on the inside and outside we're okay, seemed a bit outdated though. When we had dinner there, they only accepted cash, luckily we were prepared for that. I ordered the salmon dish. The salmon was very moist. The broccoli I got was cooked well, although I think it could have been taken out earlier.

The food was pretty good, but it's not a place I would go back to unless I was invited to go.
author: Breniel L.

description:
This is the first time I have ever experienced racism in San Francisco. 

1) My friends asked for a different table because the one they were directed at was wet. The waitress began getting sarcastic with them. She began wiping the table and saying "Is it more wet now"?

2) When my friend ordered wine and asked about her opinion she said " full" in a strong Italian accent. When my friend said excuse me she says "You don't know about wine?". 

3) When she began pouring the wine I joked " You should serve the lady first" she began saying she can't reach the lady's glass and I should pass the glass over. The girl in our group was sitting across from me so I don't see how she could not reach. Then the Italian immigrant waitress says "In america you shouldn't have to ask me this". At this point I decided to get up and leave. 

I asked her to cancel the food and charge us for the wine. She began swearing at me in Italian saying "Indian" several times as she cussed us out in Italian. 

Don't come here. Check out the other reviews.
author: Daneel O.

description:
Good to the last bite. I've ignored this spot for a while since 1) I'm not crazy about Italian 2) I'm not crazy about Italian in SF, and 3) the reviews aren't great.

It's pretty dingy on the outside. The inside reminds me of little Venice in Vegas, with the large murals and decor. There are the checker tablecloths, and the hostess even speaks with an Italian accent littered with ciaos and gracis.

I don't know what service is like since I got takeout.

Lobster ravioli for 16 dollars, which isn't cheap. A plain waxed box and a large cut of twisted baguette. The bread, cold from my walk and undisguised by heat, was fantastic. The ravioli was perfect -- not too salty, al dente, sturdy, savory. It was a medium portion, but paired with the bread, the only thing that was missing was a glass of red wine.

Oh and the hostess preferred cash -- pretty lucky I had a few bills on me.
author: Christophe C.

description:
I wish I could give a more multifaceted review; 5 stars for the lasagnetta and 1 star for the service.

The fabulous: the prosciutto lasagnetta, the friendly clientele, and the neighborhood joint faux Italian atmosphere. 

The not so fabulous: I came by on a Saturday night at 6:15 wearing my writing at home work clothing of clean overalls, a longsleeved teeshirt, a hoodie, and boots. The joint was full except for one long empty table. I asked for a table for one and was told there was nothing available for that night. I walked one block home and called the restaurant. I was told I could come in right away, that there was a table available. I made a reservation. FYI: I'm transgender and look male but sound female on the phone, so doubt if they knew it was me calling! I showed up, identify myself, they've made the long empty table into four two person tables, and sat down to eat. They forgot my bread, but brought it out after the lasagnetta arrived and when I reminded them. They also neglected to refill my water glass. They were excessively prompt in bringing out my bill despite the fact that there were empty tables. Their obvious discomfort with having me there was pretty funny. And the other tables got bread and refills promptly. There were two waiters working a small room, so this was not excusable.

I don't know if this was transphobia or classism, but clearly they were not interested in having me as a customer in their restaurant. I've eaten here before when I was less artistically dressed and before I transitioned, and did not have any problems. I plan on returning because I really do like their lasagnetta and it is one of the few affordable restaurants left in Hayes Valley. Lets hope they respond well to gentle education.
author: Avery C.

description:
Kitschy décor, fine.  Italian standards that are just ho hum, fine. These things can be looked over buuuutttt what can't be looked over is the server/?owner getting completely upset that we wanted to pay our bill with a credit card.  Other people who have reviewed here seem to have had similar experiences. She stopped smiling at us, yelled at us that we were making things difficult for her and told us she would not run our card because they were suddenly out of receipt paper.  So we sat there awkwardly, and double checked on the window pane to confirm that the establishment does in fact take credit card and decided to call her bluff.  She conveniently ignored us this whole time.  
    Here's the best part, suddenly a large party/family walks in and needs to be seated and we're seated at a table large enough for them (everyone else in the restaurant isn't ready to go yet).  IMMEDIATELY the receipt paper is fixed and she finally runs the card and hands us the paper to sign.  My friend and I were watching her the whole time and she did not replace the receipt paper. 
    So....shady and militant service/ownership basically sums it up for meh food.  Probably the only way this place is staying afloat is forcing people to pay in cash and if you're familiar with the restaurant business you know why it's better to be paid in cash.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Atmosphere cozy on a cold fall evening. Food was even good, especially the homemade pasta. Linguine bologna (without meat) was a bit overpriced at $12.50, not including even the tiniest salad or cup of soup. Service could have made up for this scant serving, but the only waitress/owner? was cool and indifferent, a real spoiler. We were in the city for medical procedures and needed a smile. We got friendly service and plentiful, delicious food the next day at Via Veneto.
author: Susan T.

description: I can't believe there are any positive reviews, especially people saying its just like a restaurant in Italy. Everything tastes like it's from a can, I ordered a pasta with meat sauce and got Taco Bell piled on top of chef boyardee. The waitress seemed generally displeased with us the entire time, and super mad when we wanted to pay with credit cards. Would not recommend.
author: Robbie C.

description: The most pretentious and obnoxious service ever.  The lady thought she was the best server ever, acting very condescending and bitchy. From the moment we got seated and pointed out that the table was not clean, to the "don't you know full bodied wine" comment when we asked her about the wine. The final straw was her extremely rude comment to the lady. When we had enough, and chose to cancel the order and leave, she had the audacity to curse in Italian at us. Definitely stay away.
author: Avi S.

description:
We came here after being put on one too many 45-minute wait lists for the other restuarants in the area. The decor dangerously borders charming and cheesy, but seeing that we were starving and it was getting close to 9:30, I'd say charming. We were surprised by the pizza quality. Gorgonzola was perfect. French-style bread instead of Italian, but really good nonetheless- and did I mention it was endless..? We also got the bruschetta which was kind of a rip-off seeing it was three tiny slices of bread with some diced tomatoes on top. Skip that next time and opt for the free shit.
Would have been a pristine five stars had the service not been so terrible. Our server was a young girl with dark hair who could very visually give zero fucks about being there. When we came in she literally grunted and led us to a table where she managed to muster the care to ask what we wanted to eat. Our server then switched to an older man who would mermur indistinct words to us when refilling our drinks and bread. Strange...
author: Liz R.

description:
Why 5 stars? Was going to put 4 but then... giant Mickey. You'll know what I mean.

On a more serious note: I feel consistently underwhelmed by Italian food in SF, but but this place was delectable. The Lasagnetta was incredible - great dish and fantastic tasting pasta. Quima Vignabaldo is prefect with the pasta dishes. 

Wonderful hospitality. Whole experience reminded me of the North End in Boston. So happy to have stumbled across this great little place, definitely a good spot to catch some noms.
author: Amanda J.

description:
I'm so lucky to have this in my neighborhood. When I moved here I was glad to have a nice little Italian restaurant on the corner but when I went there I was surprised at just how great it really is. 

You walk in and the first thing you notice is the decor. Between the wooden tables, the candlelight, and the little details on the shelves around the restaurant, it sets you at ease and makes you feel like you're in a little villa in Italy and not on Fell St. The hostess there is delightful. She greets you right away with a big smile and makes you feel at home.

You can't go wrong no matter what you order.  Everything on the menu is home-made, even the bread. I've had almost everything on the menu now and from the appetizers to the pasta to the chicken to the variety of artisan pizzas I can tell you that it's all good. If you still have room for dessert after this the tiramisu is out of this world. Even the house chianti is better than at most other restaurants.

 This place has ruined us for all other Italian restaurants, and very happily so. Every now and then my girlfriend and I will go to another Italian restaurant when we're in another part of the city and every time we always end up saying "nope, not as good as il Borgo".  We're not alone in this, either. We have numerous family and friends that say they "MUST visit il Borgo" when visiting. 

It's just a start-to-finish great dining experience that makes it the go-to place for all special occasions for us and we will keep going back for many years to come.
author: Dave E.

description: I normally don't write a review but, I felt this restaurant deserves only two stars. The pasta here is good but, the bread was stale. When my boyfriend and I asked for the bill and we asked to pay with a credit card the waitress gave us attitude for not paying in cash. It is ridiculous to force a customer to pay in cash. There are no signs outside that says cash only. When we told her we had no cash she started speaking in Italian to herself (probably complaining) that we didn't have cash and that we were using a credit card! I definitely will not come back again! The service is terrible!
author: Helen C.

description:
I wish I had read the reviews before I experienced the rude service tonight...on my birthday!  The pretty lady that was supposed to be our waitress had such a bad attitude toward me; even my 12 year old son felt sorry for her because she was baseline miserable.  At first I thought I had somehow offended her because she  seemed nice to other customers. 

I went there because I read a review about the amazing lasagna on the War Memorial Opera House website.  Therefore, I ordered lobster lasagna, but was served pasta primavera by a nice man that smiled (which I agreed to accept because my son was already served his correct meal and we did not have time to wait for another slow service meal process).  Overall, food was good, but the service was terrible...too many not so nice details that I don't care to relive (but I see other Yelpers had the same experience).  

Best advice:  Eat elsewhere; the poor Yelp reviews are very accurate.
author: Susan H.

description: Just OK.  Waitress was nice until she said that she didn't accept cash "when shes busy."  Overall, bread was amazing.  Pretty authentic Italian pizza (:
author: Alyssaaa S.

description:
Great food! Its small, quaint, subtle, and I think deliberately so. Suppenkuche next door is a tiny bit larget but they pull off the "scene" better. If that is what you are looking for then the intimate setting of Il Borgo may not be for you.

However, great service, wine, bruschetta (which is bad almost everywhere) is amazing, carpaccio, veal piccata, pasta. Its wonderful.
author: Z P.

description: I like this place.  Good pasta, pizza pretty good also.  Very homey.
author: Michael E.

description: Food is okay.  Would pay with cash if possible.  Staff becomes incredibly rude when they find out you want to pay with a credit card.  Would not recommend. Never coming back.
author: Andy N.

description: The lasagnetta (#6) is a life-changer. I will describe it as thin strips of lasagna noodles layered with prosciutto and cheese and rolled into spirals of heaven, covered in delicious tomato sauce. Pair this with some Chianti and a salad, and you have a perfect night.
author: Candida B.

description: Salad was kinda brown (like it was chopped a while ago) and it was basically just romaine, but cost 6 dollars. Lasagna thing was amazing. Wine was pretty good too for only 30 bucks! Lady who owns the place is super cute and smiley.
author: Joyce Man H.

description:
Il Borgo is a lovely family-owned business with delicious food, a romantic but relaxed atmosphere, and friendly service. It's one of the only casual Italian restaurants in the city that I would ever recommend! 

This restaurant is perfect for a low key night out with friends or a spontaneous mid-week date night. 

The vegetarian lasagnetta is my go-to - it just melts in your mouth and is covered in a savory creamy tomato sauce. The gnocchi is also really great, and we love the bruschetta despite its tendency to give you garlic breath! The portions are large, you won't be going home hungry.
author: Christine B.

description:
Love the food and hospitality here!

My boyfriend lives about half a block away from Il Borgo, so obviously this is our go-to Italian place in SF.

Dim lights, cozy atmosphere and delicious Italian food. I highly recommend the lasagnetta.  But everything else we've had here is delicious too, from the Chicken Marsala to the Lobster Ravioli.  Absolutely delish.

If you're in the area & looking for great Italian food, definitely give Il Borgo a try!  It's also very affordable.
author: Grace C.

description:
This place is not super fancy by any means, but it's an extremely comfortable, homey place that serves solid Italian comfort food. The inside is small and cozy, making it feel like you just stepped into one of those little pasta restaurants in an alleyway in Italy.

The woman who works there (one of the owners, I think?) was very sweet and extremely nice to us. We ordered a salad, lasagnetta, and carbonara. Large portions, and the meal came with some hearty Italian bread to start.

The lasagnetta was really good, I've never really had anything like it before. The carbonara was okay, but nothing special--a little too much cream vs cheese for me, but that's just my taste. I'll probably try something else next time I go back. However, both pastas were fresh and springy, really hit the spot.

We ended with some delicious tiramisu. Tiramisu is my favorite dessert, and I have to say that Il Borgo's is some of the best I've had in a while.

Overall, I really like this place. It's cozy, comforting, and doesn't break the bank. On top of that, the service is excellent.
author: Rhea K.

description:
Family-owned business that has definitely seen its better years. Decor is little old and dated, nevertheless, still charming.

Ordered the bruschetta, lobster ravioli, lagsanetta and a bottle of white.

Bread - Served warmed and looked home made. 

Bruschetta - Huge chunks of tomato, drizzled with balsamic vinegarette on top of nicely toasted bread. 

Lobster ravioli - A little disappointing. The ravioli was alright. It would have been better if the sauce does not look exactly the same as the lagsanetta he got.

Lagsanetta - Interesting presentation, but the color and texture of the sauce kinda ruined it.

All in all, the price is not exorbitant, but the food is just A-OK. Hence, 3 stars.
author: Wendy P.

description:
Amazing food  even better service
A true hole in the wall
One word to describe il borgo: authentic
author: Nader S.

description: Owner wouldn't let me use the restroom even though I was going to pay for a full entree. Fucking ridiculous, especially since we were the only people there. Also I've eaten here before and the food was mediocre. If this is the kind of person you like giving your money to, then you should consider eating here.
author: Josh J.

description: Worst experience. We don't recommend. The food was bad and the staff rude. It was the worst experience in a year
author: Marius S.

description:
This is an indoor restaurant. It had ants running all over the walls at our table and the tables on either side of us. Ants. Enough said. 

The staff was rude, and we spent over an hour trying to get someone's attention so that we could pay, after they didn't take our orders for half an hour. We spent over two hours there total. 

The food was acceptable, but certainly not worth the rude staff and ANTS.
author: Torsten L.

description: Avoid it - if you are looking for italian food there are way better alternatives in Hayes Valley! The staff was rude - simply laughing in my face when I was complaining about the food and not even trying to apologize.
author: Andrei S.

description: Fabulous handmade pasta, great homemade gelato and tiramisu, terrific service all in an unpretentious homey environment. Authentic Italian cooking -- just became one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Lisa M.

description: AMAZING lobster ravioli. I ordered an Americano there and it was the best Americano I've had in a while. I would definitely come back.
author: Summer L.

description: I love this restaurant. The no-frills atmosphere is pleasant and unassuming. Combining that with reasonable prices and generous portions causes me to feel more relaxed than I do at almost any other restaurant. I suppose the wine helps too. I recommend the lasagnetta if you're off your diet and love cheese or my personal favorite, the arrabiata, if you like spicy.
author: Will D.

description: We chose the restaurant because it was convenient to Davies Hall.  The atmosphere is simple and unpretentious. I had a nice conversation with the chef, but the highlight was the delicious Lasagne and my husbands lovely lamb chops nicely rare and tender.  This is not fine dining but a well priced restaurant, with food prepared by the owner with pride.  I look forward to going back to have the gnocchi that he prepares.  Clearly a neighborhood establishment.
author: Judith L.

description:
OH MY GOD. You have to get the lasagna with pancetta and vodka sauce! Just tried it, and was instantly in love. It has lasagna (ricotta, mozzarella, pancetta) rolled and then cut to make flat spirals, drenched in vodka sauce.  I'm going to try to replicate at home, and will definitely come back again for it. Best Italian dish ever.

Ambiance is awesome. What you'd imagine a hole in the wall restaurant looks like in Italy. It was raining, I was there with my boyfriend, place is candle-lit, Italian music; it honestly felt like a movie. 

The bread they serve with the meal is great, Caprese Salad is great. This place has good food and is super romantic. Go here on a date!
author: Ruby L.

description: I've dined here many times because first and foremost, the food is fresh is delicious! Also the inside is very cozy and is decorated to look like a quaint Italian square. Prices are reasonable especially for Hayes Valley.
author: Mark I.

description:
Me: whaddya think?
Her: I like it
Me: not 5 stars though
Her: right, but not 3 stars either
Me: 4 stars it is
Her: yep, it's in the neighborhood.  I feel comfortable there. That's important
Me:  yep. The pasta is good, and the service nice. 
Her: the pizza isn't as nice as that place in north beach
Me: yeah, true, but the pasta was tasty.  And tasted home made.  
Her: The tiramisu...
Me: um, hello?  You ok?
Her:  I was dreaming of that tiramisu.
author: Travis B.

description: I've been passing this place for months-- every time I'm stopped at Fell and Laguna, in fact. By power of suggestion, it became more and more enticing until finally last night, in a light drizzle, it seemed there was no place more perfect to eat in the city. And there wasn't. We ordered well: the Mista was perhaps a tiny bit overdressed but fresh and a very nice accompaniment to the Margherita pizza, its crust thin and buttery, the basil added last, as it's meant to be; then we finished with the lasagneta with prosciutto-- the dish everyone else is raving about on here. Guys! It was kinda outta this world. And then the decor did not disappoint, either. My girlfriend felt like she was back in Italy; I kept thinking we'd flown to New York. Either way: we were transported.
author: Margaret G.

description: Italian restaurant with excellent food but not so friendly service. Not normally very busy but parking may be tricky in this area. The bruschetta was yummy but the vegetable lasagna was even better!
author: Amanda C.

description:
*friendly homey feel, with some okay italian food*
fettucine del borgo | chianti | bread

This is your definition of a neighborhood spot. Surrounded by so many new, popular, and fancy places, this place is a comforting gem. The handmade noodles were delicious. Although I can't say I was blown away by the food, it was some great home-style cooking, affordable food in a neighborhood that has changed the most since I've lived here. 

A great place to go when you don't feel like breaking the bank and making dinner just seems too difficult. The ambiance and decor super seceded it's food but this place was just added to my repetoire of dinner spots.
author: Kevin T.

description: I kept giving this restaurant a benefit of the doubt. I'm done. All their pasta are very quite salty. I asked not to put too much salt and they still did.
author: Joseph M.

description: Elementary School cafeteria food at not elementary school prices. The only nice thing I can say about this place is our server was pretty friendly and they had cool candles on the table.
author: Michelle O.

description: Fantastic food! Try the salmon with the wonderfully fresh veggies. The pasta arrabiata is also perfectly spicy. Service was great even if you don't speak Italian.
author: MC D.

description: This restaurant was a fun hole in the wall type of place.  It is very small and only has one waitress/hostess and one busboy.  Because of this the waitress is pretty no nonsense.  She is an Italian woman that goes around the restaurant asking everyone what they want and she is blunt and brisk.  I found her very entertaining, but I could see how some patrons would be unhappy with this.  The food was good but not great.  It is very close to the ballet so I would recommend it for people looking for a nearby restaurant.  Also, I had heard in other reviews that they only took cash, but they have updated their system and had no problem taking a card.
author: Alexandra B.

description:
I shared a lasagna with a friend because we had eaten not too long before visiting here.  We read on the yelp reviews that the pizza was no good, so we ordered the lasagna.  Considering that I was full, the lasagna wasn't too bad.  It came out in 3 pieces of rolls instead of the typical layered lasagna.  It tasted mediocre, nothing too special about it.  

Maybe it's because the water in San Francisco is not good in general, but my glass just tasted horrible.  Plus, there was a glass that was brought out with some remnant of some sort stuck to it.  Gross! 

I don't plan on visiting this place again next time I'm in SF.
author: Teresa N.

description: Best pasta in Hayes district. Very nice and well served in a pretty and italian atmosphere.
author: Joege M.

description:
Liked Il Borgo so much we returned in a few weeks.
Service, food, everything was great -- if a wee bit inconsistent from one night to the next.  In a City loaded with great [Italian] restaurants, Il Borgo stands out as simple, fresh, clean, and fun.  Small, authentic eatery.  Molte grazie. . . .
author: Russell R.

description:
Great attentive service the minute you walk in! However thats where the raving ends for Il Borgo. Their food was just so-so for me and I so wanted to enjoy a good plate of pasta for dinner that night!

I ordered the fettuccine primavera and the hubs had the fettuccine in bolognese sauce. The sauce was lacking in flavor and I found myself wanting to douse the dish in salt, which I might add that i refrained from doing. The complimentary bread was cold and meh. A little warming up would have gone a long way.

Cash only but there is an ATM inside.
author: Esther A.

description: Horrible service. The waitress was very rude. The food was not great. I could have made better pasta myself. I went with family for a special evening and we were all very disappointed.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Fellow Yelpers...Pleeez are you kidding me??? First off the smell of the place, kinda like when you're walking down 16th & Mission and especially since there is no circulation/ventilation. Service was slow since there was only one person which was probably the owner. One of our friends had ordered a salad as her entree. It came first and about 30 min later our entrees came. Needless to say we felt bad that she had finished her salad and pass some food onto her plate.

We ordered the Saltimbocca which was extremely salty & greasy. It came with potatoes that were hard had been sitting for hours in grease. The Bruchetta was also too salty. Finally, what kind of restaurant does not accept credit cards especially when the bill is over a $100!! The meal was not of value.

Better off eating authentic Italian food in the North Beach
author: marcus c.

description:
Love stories, romantic talks, and rekindling of past significant others all fit perfectly in this lovely, quaint and adorable restaurant. If you think chivalry and romance has slowly died away, bringing your date here you will get you heated again. This I guarantee! The candlelight, the custom wooden furniture, and fabulous hostess Mitra will make you feel as if you walked right into Milan, Italy (origins of the restaurant owners). If you aren't with a partner (I highly recommend you bring someone), you can surely enjoy the same pristine service by your lonesome. 

Does this make you want to visit yet? If not, the food definitely will. With recipes past down from generations and hand-made created pastas prepared same day, your taste-buds will awaken like night and day from the imitators. Go try for yourself! Need suggestions? Lasagnetta for the hungry, and the Margherita for something lite.

Now grab your cute neighbor, friend, or ex, pour the vino and have some mature conversation....
author: riz l.

description: Great ambiance. Very authentic and makes me feel like I'm back in Rome. The food is just as good. You can order anything and love it.
author: Jenny D.

description: Truly I hidden gem for authentic Northern Italy dishes. Good pasta, tasty pizzas, and an eclectic but homey interior makes this place a local favorite. Italiano parlato! Buen apetito.
author: Victor O.

description:
This place is a little hit and miss.  Had the best italian food of my life here three times, and some crappy spaghetti once.
I've been to Italy, and this place is better.
Try the pizza or the artichoke raviolis.
And don't forget to bring cash, no cards.
author: Mira F.

description: I came here with 3 friends ordered a bottle of wine, different pasta dishes and it was awesome. Great food, great atmosphere and great prices. I had the lasagnetta and it was delicious. Plenty of cheese, sauce and full of flavor. The bread and butter was on point as well.
author: Kiril S.

description:
We were walking around Hayes Valley at 9pm on a Saturday in search of dinner.  Suppenkuche and Domo both had very long waits so we popped into Il Borgo.  Plenty of seats available on Saturday ... usually a warning sign but we were hungry and had plans later on.

Our group of three ordered a pasta and two pizzas.  All were mediocre at best and awful at worst.  Pizzas were very soggy and the toppings of bad quality.  The carbonara was very average, with pancetta that was more like pure fat rather than any actual meat (it was translucent).  Wine was cheap and forgettable, as was the desert.

Two stars for relatively friendly service and easy seating on a Saturday, but otherwise forgettable.  Would only recommend if you find yourself in the area without reservations and are desperate.
author: Ryan S.

description: Sometimes you're going to want a lot of dense, cheap Italian food. That's ok - we all do. This is the best place in the city for that.
author: Chris A.

description: The lasagnetta is my favorite. Pasta is fresh, and bread is delish! I've been here several times, with everything from a small to large group, and service has been great.
author: Michele T.

description: Stopped in on a Sunday night after craving pasta all day.  The decor is very dated and a little on the cheesyball side. The staff was pleasant but the food was very sub par. Might have been an off night as it was very slow but we won't be back.
author: Ryan S.

description:
I'm in love with this place. 
The food is very good.
Service is top notch the lady who was serving us such a sweetheart.... very nice, fun, and very attentive.
author: Aphrodite L.

description: I really love this place.  Signorina is awesome, and the food is a tasty value.  Not Michelin rated, but we love it as a neighborhood haunt.
author: Robert D.

description:
This place is above average Italian food in an environment that actually feels Italian - you can even practice your Italian with the staff if you're feeling up to it.

The homemade raviolis were all delicious along with the salmon. The carpaccio and caprese salad were decent. Reasonably priced wine list. Cash only (ATM in restaurant)

Good date spot or family dinner out. Service was almost overly attentive but convenient.
author: Rachel G.

description: Authentic Italian food. Very friendly staff and the food is consistently good. Great place to get Italian food if you are not into big food chain, e.g. Olive Garden. Keep in mind that parking around here could be challenging, and cash only but they have an ATM inside.
author: Ian W.

description: Stood in the entry way amid empty, uncleared tables for over 15 minutes and was acknowledged twice. The second time with some undeserved attitude (really. We were just standing there. Waiting. Because of our reservation). Eventually left because it certainly did not appear that we were going to be seated and served in time to make the symphony show.
author: Patrick M.

description:
I came here wanting pizza but managed to save myself in time when I saw on Yelp that the pizza wasn't that great.  I ended up ordering the lasagna (which was different - it's like three spiral rolls of pasta with pancetta rolled in it topped with a well done tomato sauce) and enjoyed it.

The atmosphere was okay, the service was slow, and the place wasn't so clean.  I don't think I'd come back even though I did enjoy what I ate.
author: Anna V.

description: We came for dinner on December 28, when we discovered the wait for Suppenküche was 90 minutes.  There were only a few tables with patrons, but it felt cozy and we liked the old school ambiance.  Although I speak very little Italian, when I greeted the waitress in Italian she happily replied in Italian back to me, and then never spoke a word of English to us the entire evening.  It was actually quite fun and surprisingly, I was able to keep up.  Our food was good, and the bill was shockingly low.  We had a leisurely dinner and they were very patient with us taking so long and being the last ones there.  Would definitely go back.
author: Linda H.

description: Yummi!  Cash only but they have an ATM.  The service ROCKED!  I food was a little light on the quantity side, but just get a starter and it's PERFECT.
author: SF Goofball G.

description: Love the food here, especially the nochie, and the Spumoni ice cream , both made in house. Great Italian food, reasonably priced.
author: Sacha I.

description:
I am torn on this place, but thought it was an interesting enough experience to write my first Yelp review in years. My boyfriend and I came here while starving since we live in the neighborhood and have walked by many times. It looks very cozy with nice lighting, ideal for a cute, neighborhood date. When we came in, there were 2-3 four tops open as well as another table for two by the window, but the waitress gestured for us to take a table for two right by the bathroom, where one chair was crowded right up against the chair of the table next to it. My boyfriend and I asked to have the other table for two instead, which was fine with the waitress. No big deal. 

The problems started when I got some kind of a pasta that was not what I ordered. We let the one waitress know and she just said "Okay, give me the mistake." No apologies. My artichoke ravioli came a little while later. The waitress said, "Careful, it's very hot." When I hesitated for a few seconds because I thought she was going to set it down on my table for me, she just handed it to me and said, "Why don't you use your head? If it's so hot, how can I be handling it?" I just couldn't believe she spoke to a customer this way. I'm not sure why she didn't just walk two more steps to the side of the table to put it on the table, rather than handing me a dish over my boyfriend's shoulder. I was pretty mad, but I rationalized that it's just because she's a kind of fiery Italian lady and doesn't mean anything by it. I can see, though, how other reviewers have perceived her as being rude. 

The problem though is that the ravioli was, as other reviewers have said, exquisite. The wrapper was clearly home made and the filling had a light, fresh artichoke flavor that was not overshadowed by the light tomato sauce. I would love to eat  it again anytime. The portions were just right. I think I would wrestle with myself when coming back however - the ravioli is amazing (five stars) but the bruschetta, salad, and pizza wre just okay (3.5 stars) and I feel like the service can be unpredictable (2 stars) - from warm and friendly to attitude. Maybe I can find a compromise in getting take out so I can avoid the service while still getting great ravioli a few blocks away from home.
author: Lijia X.

description: Family type restaurant. I went in with a good small group of friends and we ordered a bunch of things on the menu and some good wine to pair. I would definitely go back. It wasn't super expensive, for Italian, and the gnocchi was definitely something to have again :-)
author: Jennifer S. C.

description:
Not impressed. They don't take cards and I think I was served hamburger helper and my girlfriend was served Costco ravioli with Newman vodka sauce. 

I have had good Italian but this is not on that list. I don't understand all the 5 star reviews? This is what I would consider a poor Yelp experience. 

Great that they are family owned and good pricing but I think the quality wasn't there for my experience.
author: Don O.

description: SF GEM! I've drove past this joint for years and finally tried it about 2 months ago.  I've been back several times since and will continue to come back for the authentic Italian cuisine.  Try the Lobster Ravioli and Veal.  The Tiramisu is a must.  Enjoy :)
author: Grace O.

description:
I thought it was near impossible to screw up Italian food. Apparently, I was wrong. And it wasn't just our food that was screwed up--our checks were too. Big time (read: scam).

-- Food: I got the Fettuccine Il Borgo, which was supposed to be fettuccine, sun dried tomatoes, chicken, and capers. The tomato sauce tasted stale and was severely lacking in flavor--I had to douse my food in red pepper flakes to taste ANYTHING. My fettuccine was oddly dense and definitely did not taste fresh at all. The WORST part: the chicken. Not only was it completely tasteless, the texture was so off-putting--soft and jelly-like, almost like tofu. One of my friends who also ordered this dish agreed wholeheartedly. The last time I checked, chicken is supposed to be...I don't know, fibrous? At least chewable. I don't think I've ever had chicken so strange and inedible in my life.

-- Service (TERRIBLE, TERRIBLE, TERRIBLE): As a party of seven, we asked the server (ostensibly the owner) to split our checks. Of course, we understood that it would be an inconvenience, but we were prepared to tip generously in return. When we received our checks, they were not separate. Instead, six out of seven of us received the same check. 

In other words, even though my dish was listed as $13.00 on the menu, my friend's dish was $12.75 (penne with mushrooms and sausage), my other friend's dish (artichoke ravioli) was $13.75, etc...we somehow all owed $14.95, according to the server and check that somehow encompassed six of our differently-priced dishes.
 
"Everyone came out to $15.00," the server and/or owner said. 

Seriously? What kind of outright scam is this? I'm pretty sure a five-year-old could figure out that with tax and whatever other charges they decided to tack on (as another diner recently noted, there was NO breakdown on our bill...is that even legal?), WE WOULD NOT ALL BE PAYING $14.95. Even if there was a gratuity charge for parties larger than x number of people, it should have been clearly listed on the menu or the bill.

Regrettably, we didn't question the bill or the lack of breakdown of charges, but I literally have never been so confused after a meal, attempting to figure out how much I owed. I now realize that the server/owner/restaurant was essentially scamming us--essentially stealing our money.  

Contrary to what the website says, this is NOT "a small gem" with "some of the best Italian cuisine in the city."

Disgusting. Stay far, far away, unless you want awful food and appalling service.
author: Deborah S.

description:
We had a nice dinner yesterday with party of seven. All went well: nice atmosphere, pretty good food and excellent company and lots of holiday spirit!
Once we got the bill and we had questions about some of the charges ( the handwriting was illegible) the head waitress did not like it! In the bill there was a number 6 and a line, which seemed like writing, I asked what it was. She said it's four cokes. OK, um, there is number six and we only had 3 cokes? No, you ordered 4 cokes, she said. I said we have three kids and we ordered three cokes. She said something angrily and walked away. We had already paid, so she did not come back to our table anymore nor did she bring back the money owed.

I'd recommend you check your bill carefully before handing her your money.

Not so nice ending for otherwise nice outing.
author: Salla V.

description: After 6 years and many meals later, the review still stands. In addition, this is the only Italian restaurant in SF that reminds me of the trattoria in Florence, minus the variety of course. The tiramisu compares well to those in Italy though, which is not a small accomplishment.
author: Francis W.

description:
This place is a gem. Had lamb, chicken dish and  some Bruschetta . Everything was fantastic. So was the $36 bottle of cab. Service was personable, atmosphere was cozy. Not pretentious, small, inviting and great food.

And it's pretty cheap!
author: Jon C.

description: So good, like a real authentic italian restaurant.. I loved the food. it was grant
author: Tim N.

description: Prosciutto Lasagna is my favorite dish....so amazing and I like the rolled up pasta used.  All deserts are amazing as well.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Something very special about a family owned and run Italian restaurant. There is a funkiness to the decor, which delicately walks the line of hokey and authentic. You walk into a darkened dining room, with murals all on walls, lit by large candles, with music playing.

The food I truly excellent and comes in very large portions. I would recommend the lasagnetta (of course), and was pleasantly surprised by how good and big their pizzas are. They also have a great tiramisu. 

I dock them one star because they are cash only. I have gone at least a half dozen times with my parents and in laws and when you drink wine too, you will need a lot of cash. That said they do have an ATM and very reasonable prices, so you won't drain you checking account by going there.

This inconvenience though, is the only thing that keeps this from a 5 star place. That said, their prices are very low since it is cash only. I have only seen a few entrees over $20, none over $30. Great food, great ambiance, good for parties large and small, and excellent services.
author: Benjamin M.

description:
My friends took us there... and everything we had was amazing. I tried a bit of everyone's food at my table, and it was soooooo good..
My only complaint is that it was VERY noisy in the restaurant... But the food was soooo good I'm willing to overlook that :)
author: Jessica V.

description: I don't know why this is 3.5 stars, this is a great Italian restaurant that I've been going to for years! Consistently amazing fresh pasta, love the bolognese, pizza is thin and authentic! I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Ashley L.

description:
AMAZING.
So, ever since I spotted this cute little dark corner spot with the long stick candles lit on every table, I have wanted to go on a date there! It finally happened, and it was everything I hoped for. Our server was wonderful, she made us feel like we were eating at her home in Italy :) Get the Lasagnetta $12. It was soooo good,...we also got the carbonara $13, the caprese salad $7, and the romaine salad $5...all were great choices. Can't wait to go back!!!! :)
author: Nikki W.

description: I LOVE this place, it is straight up authentic Italian food. The owner is very nice, unassuming, but attentive enough, so your enjoying your conversation, without too much interruption. I have eaten here 5 times in two months, I love it. I am a connoisseur  of Tiramisu, seriously, I rarely find anything in the US remotely close to what I have eaten, numerous times in Italy. The flavors, textures,  moisture and consistency are in perfect harmony. I dream about it. I actually have had two pieces each time I have eaten there. :)
author: Rick P.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place, simply because every time I came into town to visit my old neighborhood, I would see it there on the corner after you take that big left on Fell Street at the end of the Octavia freeway exit.

It's a tiny place, where you wouldn't expect an Italian restaurant. Atmosphere is a bit dark. It's actually very pleasant. Ideal for an intimate dinner date.

But the food is just OK. I'm not a huge fan of Italian to begin with, so it's got to be really special to impress me. My thinking is... "How good could it be if I could do it better?". That's how I felt about their Spaghetti Carbonara. It's a unique dish where the sauce is essentially made with raw eggs and some type of bacon and grated cheese. Awesome if it's done right. Borgo's version is great, if you've never had it. I also sampled one of their veal scalopini entrees which was also just a little let's say under seasoned. On a good note, I didn't see dishes that were ordered by any patrons that were "smothered" in tomato sauce.

Service was friendly enough, fairly fast and attentive. However, they don't accept credit cards. I wasn't prepared to empty my wallet, but there is an ATM machine there. There's probably a $2-$3 service charge, hopefully one way... but certain gratuitous fees had to suffer for that, if you know what I mean.

Not a place I'd make a special trip for, unless you had to get rid of a guy named Solozzo.
author: Rick V.

description:
I ate here for the first time this summer, and since then, this has become my favorite Italian restaurant in SF... maybe my favorite restaurant, full stop.  It's a tiny place, and even with reservations, there can be a wait.  Service is very, very slow and rather inattentive -- however, there seems to be only 3 people working in the restaurant, so that is understandable and is not problematic as long as you plan for it. (ie, do not show up here hoping to rush through dinner).  The decor is cute, the lighting is slightly dim, and it seems like it would be a wonderful place for a date.

The food is excellent.  I am afraid I am rather addicted to the artichoke ravioli.  I have trouble ordering a different entree at this point.  That said, I always end up trying my friends' entrees as well, and almost everything has been good.   The notable exception are their bolognese sauced dishes, which look like wet dog food.  Actually a dog may not even wish to eat it.  Everything else is delicious, really, though!  My favorites are the artichoke ravioli, the lasagnetta (for which they are most well known), fusilli with eggplant, the pizzas, and the antipasto mixed tray. 

If I lived closer I would probably wind up here at least once a week...
author: Heidi M.

description:
We are local costumers of this restaurant for years,but we have been particularly upset today and we will never come back to this place. The waitress was serving us with her head set on her head, talking very loud in italian in her phone , she talked for half an hour, never stopped for service..., totally disrespectful of her  customers. restaurant was very dark, we had to ask for her to turn on the lights. She added 18% gratuity on the bill ( for a diner of four regular customers)without telling us. When we asked for explanations, she said she never seen us before (We go in this restaurant for years) and said she always add the gratuity for tourists.. She laugh in our faces, taking the other customers as witnesses...  A real shame for this local business. 
As local costumers, we will relate this incident to our friends and neiborgs who use to go to this place....
author: carole d.

description: Not my favorite, caprese salad tasted really weird, way too much oil. They didnt cut up the bread. Salmon was decent but pretty tough to mess up..
author: Tiff W.

description:
I live close by and decided I needed to try something new (actually I was watching a rerun of Iron Chef America "Batalli vs Constantino" and decided I wanted Italian...).

I called and the lady that answered had an italian accent and I gained a little confidence in the place.  I ordered the rigatoni alla mattriciana.

The food was hot and ready when I picked it up and the pasta came with a side of focaccia 

The was still piping hot when I got home and really fits the northern style of pasta dishes in Italy... which means that it's fairly al dente and a little salty.  That being said, all of the ingredients and the sauce tasted super fresh and it was better than some of the dishes that I had while traveling in northern Italy.

The bread... I thought it was some store made filler until I noticed the fresh sprigs of rosemary and the sea salt on top.  The portion was large and the bread tasted like it came out of the oven right before I got there.

Overall, this was a great pasta meal for $13.  Also, the portion is large enough to have a decent portion for leftovers tomorrow.

I'll probably take someone here sometime soon and spend more than $15 ;)
author: Joseph H.

description:
OK traditional Italian food.

Let down by a pretentious head waitress. 

No credit cards a turnoff - particularly as this is not displayed clearly on entry.
author: John S.

description:
Great pastas and the specials menu is full of intriguing dishes.  Also amazing service!

Two stars off since they are cash only.
author: Carl S.

description: I came here a couple years ago, and while my date enjoyed his meal, I've avoided the place since then because I really didn't enjoy the food or the upset stomach I had the rest of the night.  I wish I could say better things about this place, but my experience was enough to keep me away.
author: Andrea T.

description: Wouldn't have gone here if the wait at the Sushi place next door wasn't so long.  But I am sure glad i did.  Intimate setting although noisy.  Only 14-15 tables and the 1 server working them did a great job.   Nice rustic feel to the food.   To me the pizza was just so-so. But the pasta was cooked perfect and the sauces were flavorful.  I haven't been to too many Italian places in  the city but this one is the only place whose red sauce had a comparable flavor i have only found on the east coast.  I will go here again.  The prices are low for the quality of food.  Tiramisu was really good.  Fettuccine Bolognese had that slow cooked dark complex flavor.  Loved it!
author: Marc S.

description:
My parents and I found this little hole in the wall out of desperation thanks to Opentable because we needed a place to eat dinner that was walking distance to SF Opera. What great luck! The staff was attentive (despite there being only two servers and one bus boy), the atmosphere quaint, but most importantly, the food was fantastic! What makes it 5 stars for me is that our dinner cost us half of what many of the other area restaurants would have. 

Per the yelp reviews I got lasagneta. So deelish! My 14 year old daughter, who is not a big fan of tomato-based sauces, raved about it when she scarfed down the leftovers I brought home from my large portion. The broccoli I pilfered from my mom's veal plate was cooked perfectly with just the right amount of butter and salt. And unless you're gluten-free, you HAVE to try a piece of the hot bread they serve.  

We'll definitely be back for our next pre-opera dinner!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Very good, very authentic Italian food. Reminds me of when I was growing up and I pretended my grandmother was Italian and I pretended that she was cooking for me.

I want to deduct a star for the hipster infestation, but I guess it's not their fault.
author: Adam L.

description:
Il Borgo is a cozy unpretentious family restaurant that serves delicious food without a lot of frills.  We stay in the neighborhood a few times a year, and almost always fit in a meal at Il Borgo.  We've always been treated with kindness and good cheer, and have tried many things on the menu for many good meals.

Tonight we had Fusilli with eggplant and mozzarella, and Lasagnetta.  Both were very good --- excellent flavors and sensuous textures.  We were cheerfully provided with boxes to take home our left-overs plus a large slice of tiramisu which was supposed to be for later, but it's so good we've eaten more than half already.  "Just one more bite. Ooooh."  All that for $45 including a good tip; quite reasonable for SF.

We've had faster service sometimes in larger places that can support more servers (but usually with higher prices also).  If you're ready to take your time and savor your food, it's not going to be a long wait.

Comfort food.
author: Janet M.

description:
Oh Il Borgo, you still did not disappoint 3.5 years after my first experience.  We arrived around 630 on a Tues night before my dreaded overnight flight back to the east coast and were greeted by the gorgeous Italian owner/server who sat us in a booth near the back.  

I ordered the handmade fettuccine with bolognese sauce and my bf had penne with mushrooms and sausage.  Soooo yummy, yet he preferred mine and I preferred his.  I was expecting the bolognese sauce to be a bit more tomato-y, but it was on the creamier side.  Still very, very good though.  The handmade pasta was so delicate and perfect, I wanted to take it home in bulk for my future pasta dinners!

The waitress was so sweet, smiley and very attentive, always coming by to check on us and refill our water glasses.  I'll definitely be back next time I'm in SF and craving good, authentic Italian pasta.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Good service, and good food.  The Price is very good for Italian food.  I took my parents here when they were in town last and the server made them feel right at home.  This is a very special place great for a date or family event.  
Thank you
author: Eric B.

description:
Mugatu: SHUT UP! Enough already, Ballstein! Who cares about Derek Zoolander anyway? The man has only one look, for Christ's sake! Blue Steel? Ferrari? Le Tigra? They're the same face! Doesn't anybody notice this? I feel like I'm taking crazy pills!

After reading these AWESOME AMAZING reviews and experiencing Il Borgo for myself, I feel like *I'm* taking crazy pills.
