Things that ARE true: the atmosphere is f'ing adorable, (some) of the servers are kind, and the location is great. 

Things that are true and did not win me over: the cash only thing. I can see the appeal for any business to be cash only, but it seems pretty ridiculous for a place where the bill could easily be in the 100s. 

Coffee and donuts? Yes. 
Lasagnetta, pinto grigio and pancetta? No. 

The food? Good. Definitely not "OMG WOW AM I IN FIRENZE?" good. I sampled a variety of things and nothing made my mouth water the way Buca di Beppo does. 

(Kidding.)

If you're in the hood and mad craving on some noodles, stop by and judge for yourself. I don't think you'll be disappointed- I just don't think you'll be impressed. 

PS: Go to the bathroom and check out the lock on the door. After closing it and locking myself in, I was ready to save Princess Fiona from a castle tower and slay the dragon that was holding her hostage.
author: Jared S.

description:
We were here last night for a wine dinner and I felt like I was at my Grandmother's kitchen table in Italy! The atmosphere is so comfortable and charming and the food is family style all the way.  We shared massive dishes of pasta, chicken marsala, great wine from all over Italy (St. Michael-Eppan Pinot Grigio, Satrico, Cesari Valpolicella and Amorone to name a few), and topped off our experience with some of the most amazing Tiramisu I've ever had (and I even make my own at home!).

Service here is excellent and I would recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for an authentic meal!!
author: Lisa R.

description: I love this place! It's just that simple.  The owner, Mitra, is always so welcoming and friendly throughout your entire meal.  It's a quaint spot on the edge of Hayes Valley's bustling business core.  I highly recommend the Lasagnetta!  I was first introduced to il Borgo over 10 years ago and keep going back.  It's a great date spot when you want a quiet, intimate space to get to know one another.  Finish off your meal with some Tiramisu and a glass of port while you check your calendar for when you'll be back!
author: Dana E.

description:
It has taken me awhile to find the time to write this, but I am still incredibly stoked about my experience at Il Borgo.

The restaurant definitely has a "family style" vibe about it.

For my birthday I thought I was going to have maybe 8 or so people out for dinner.  8 turned into 30+.  The owner and staff was unbelievably accommodating.  They rearranged all of their furniture to fit us in, allowed us to bring in our own magnums of wine and champagne at a VERY reasonable corkage rate, and the food was amazing.  

They make everything from scratch and after you order it.  The quality of the food is some of the best I've had in this city.  They also have cute details like red and white checkered table cloths, those candles that drip down on empty wine jugs, and adorable murals inside.  

The staff was as nice as you could ask for and even took the time to check in on my birthday experience and comment on what a great vibe the group had.  I have a great group of friends, but they didn't all know each other.  Il Borgo provided a warm family style setting that encouraged them all to mingle.  

I think I'm going to have a lot of my "special occasions" there.  I'd recommend it to anyone.  Also, this would be a great first date spot for anyone who's looking.
author: Lyz L.

description: Went here before a show in the civic center area. There were ants ALL over the wall next to our table... in December. Made the whole place seem super unsanitary. The wait staff was also very slow and very rude. I wish I could leave 1 and a half stars instead because the pasta was decent. But the bugs and rude staff made it so disapointing.
author: Katie M.

description:
I don't think I have ever had a food experience where I was actually able to somewhat overlook crummy food due to such a lovely atmosphere and attentive service from such a nice person. The atmosphere is classically rustic. Very charming. Just what a neighborhood Italian American casual place should be. The woman who I presume to be the owner was so sweet. Very attentive and pleasently chatty. 

Now let's get to the food..The Pizza was great..Absolutely no complaints. The salad was edible, but overly dressed. The pasta was terrible. In particular, the red sauce. It was essentially just canned tomato sauce with zero herbs, or spice. The cream sauce with peas I had was pretty rough as well. Both pastas were undercooked.And I don't meal Al Dente..I mean undercooked...

Bottome line is I would absolutey go back to this charming neighborhood spot for good pizza, wonderful atmosphere and pleasant service...Oh, and the prices are VERY reasonable...Just don't get the pasta..
author: Tim E.

description:
If you're looking for comforting, fairly inexpensive, authentic italian food, go to Il Borgo. 

The woman (I think co-owner) who's been working there ever since I can remember is the loveliest, kindest, most precious server ever.... yes, you heard me. Sometimes I find myself craving Il Borgo just for our interaction. 

The food comes in serving sizes that really should not be consumed at one sitting.  You will definitely need a to-go box and if you did clean your plate, you've been cautioned that you may not be feeling too well later. 

It's true, they don't accept credit cards.  They probably should get a square reader but for whatever reason they choose to run a cash-only business.  They do however provide an ATM in the corner that charges the lowest fee I've ever seen (i think it might be $1, maybe 50 cents). If that's too much for you, should you really even BE eating out?

This isn't haute cuisine but it is comforting authentic warm-your-soul kind of food so if that's what you're looking for, you've come to the right place.
author: Jason R.

description: Had dinner here last Tuesday. Got my usual: chicken saltimbocca. Still one of the best things I've put in my mouth. So good. Dave & I took another friend, she also had the saltimbocca- she was thrilled with it. Dave had his bolognese- he loves it. Mitra gave her usual outstanding service. A glass of chianti before dinner and a shared gelato after- what could be better? Il Borgo has NEVER disappointed me.
author: Trisha F.

description:
The ambiance is homey, and the service is tremendous.  The owner(?) is a delightful woman, and is always very patient when we make our feeble attempts at communicating in Italian with her.

The pizza seems like it would be the main attraction.  The dough is crispy where it ought to be, and chewy where it ought to be.  Margherita.  MMM.

Lately I've been stuck on the sausage ravioli.  I'm guessing hand made.  Delicate pasta, and the sauce is right on.

It's on a block which hasn't got much else going on, but give it a try!
Oh, and bring cash!
author: Ken B.

description:
Il Borgo was the scene of a lovely date.  The inside is made to look like a small Italian village complete with clothesline full of clothes.  It is small and intimate.  The staff is very attentive to your needs. 

We ordered the Antipasto Misto which was piled high with meats and cheese.  We also enjoyed the Insalata de Borgo which has the perfect amount of blue cheese and radicchio.  The artichoke ravioli was delicious.  The chicken dish we ordered was a little salty.

I will definitely return to this quaint little place next time I am in Hayes Valley. Just remember it is cash only.
author: Megan P.

description:
Quiet and romantic atmosphere, and hospitable staff. 

get the caprese salad, the italian salad(2nd on menu), lasagna, and tiramasu. just trust me.
author: archiee n.

description:
A bad taste in my mouth! The reason(s): the food and the rude attitude!
We welcomed a new friend coming in San francisco by dining in Hayes Valley. We didn't look for something fancy, but still we expected an experience that will make us want to come back. The mistake was choosing Il Borgo. Never again!

We all ordered pastas, and the girls from our group ask for the Carbonara plates. So we had on our order two Carbonara pasta. It was the worst they ever tried. The both of them just looked bad: the so-called dressing was made from tiny bits of scrambled eggs (!) and the taste was so greasy.

We didn't want to make a fuss and waited for the lady that served our table to just come by. When she did and ask us by default how was it, we actually answered her it wasn't the best and that we couldn't eat this. She ask us if we want a box (??!) to take it home. We said no thank you, it doesn't taste good so we would like her to take our plates. She started to laugh and ignored us. From there it all went south. Starting with the comments from the open kitchen, the awful attitude, the loud laughing and disrespectful jokes they made in the back so that all the customers will share our uncomfortable situation.

It was clear for us that they will refuse to take the two Carbonara out of the check so we just asked for the check. They made us wait with the two Carbonara pastas on our table for more that 30 minutes and when she finally came she add by hand a 20% tip to our check, after all that rudeness. We were speechless. We asked her to bring us a new check without the "personal" note of 20% tip and you might guess what followed: a new round of loud, awful comments! We left after paying promising to never come back!
author: Alina S.

description: This restaurant appears to be family-owned, and has a very relaxed, romantic vibe. The staff are very friendly, and the pastas are amazing. I wouldn't write home about the salads or starters, but mains are consistently very good.
author: Samantha H.

description: AWFUL SERVICE.  Everyone working here failed over and over again to provide any even resembling customer service.  Overtime we needed anything, even water, we had to flag down our waiter.  Moreover, the staff was highly unprofessional when we even had the opportunity to interact with them.  There are many good places to spend your money in SF, this is not one of them.
author: Tom C.

description: We had tickets for the show at the SF Jazz Center.  We made a reservation for 5 when they open.  The restaurant was empty when we arrived, and we were warmly greeted and immediately seated.  Our waitress was "Mitra".  I probably spelled it wrong, but I asked her name because she was so kind and gave us excellent service.  The food was delicious and fresh.  We had the appetizer platter, received fresh warm bread, and we both had pasta.  We were able to have a relaxing meal, authentic and simple, and make it to our show on time.  This place is a small neighborhood restaurant, simple and good.  And the prices are very reasonable.  And we enjoyed the music..............
author: Katherine R.

description:
I can't BELIEVE how incredibly rude they were to us.

We sat down and ordered a bottle of wine. The server comes over very quickly with an already opened bottle (who knows how long it's been sitting there) and pours our glasses. We take a look at the bottle - it's not the one we ordered. 

We catch the server's eye and say that we don't think it's the right bottle. She says, 'it's the same, it's Cabernet! We don't have the bottle on the menu - the menu is 11 years old!'

We ask why she didn't tell us that the bottle we ordered wasn't available. She says she's busy, gets all defensive and says she's sorry, but what is she supposed to do about it? She basically yells this at us and we get up and leave.

Maybe the food is ok, I have no idea, but that waitress needs to go! Also, why don't you invest in some menus that have the items you have in stock??
author: Kate A.

description:
INSANELY DELICIOUS!
After a mini road trip, we decided to have a proper dinner at a random place.  We pulled over, found parking in the city, walked five blocks, pointed, and found ourselves here at Il Borgo.  I would rate the bread and the Prosciutto 3 stars, but everything else is 5 stars (meal, wine, dessert, service).  Literally, as I was shovelling the Chef's Special Lobster Ravioli with Aurora sauce on to my palette, I kept exclaiming "This is insane!"  If there is a place like this in SoCal, I would go every week.
THANK YOU IL BORGO for an unforgettable dinner.  Your fare and your service is impeccable!
author: Amber P.

description: fairly traditional Italian restaurant. We only had a couple of the pasta dishes and didn't try the wine or desserts. Overall, we weren't really impressed with either the food or the service. It was ok.
author: Laurent L.

description:
Next time you pour off 101 onto Octavia, slow down when you turn into Fell Street and stick to the right side so you can peek at Il Borgo (at Laguna).  For seven years, I've whisked past on Fell and wondered about Il Borgo.  I mentioned this to my boyfriend, and he called me on Friday to suggest that we do some investigating.

Ever miss a place so much that you forced yourself to bury your feelings because you knew you'd just be an ugly mess of smudgey eyeliner and boogers if you let it out?  No?  Not that you're aware of?  Me neither ... until I came to Il Borgo and felt myself thawing and was flooded with memories of incredible times with friends in New York, amazingly romantic restaurants hidden away in dark alleys and the most delicious food I've ever had.

We started with bread so crusty on the outside and fleshy and soft on the inside that we tore into the basket and devoured the entire loaf before our entrees made it to the table.  For a starter, we ordered the rustic bruschetta which was fabulously garlicky, piled with chunks of tomato and torn basil, and sprinkled with fragrant herbs.  

Both of us ordered fresh, perfectly cooked fettucini: he = primavera (peas, cream sauce & proscuitto), me = puttanesca (anchovy, tomato, olives, capers).  It was a serious  "Like Water For Chocolate" sort of meal ... someone's emotions were transferred into the food that we ate, so much so that I wanted simultaneously to weep and to burst with love all over the place.

Ready for an emotional breakthrough?  Trying to get in someone's pants?  Both are on the menu at Il Borgo.

P.S.  Don't mind the creepy teddy bear in the bathroom.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I love it here. I got engaged here.. Sergio and his staff are wonderful.

Their menu is incredible. Nothing on there will disappoint.
author: Lisa S.

description: Service is moderate, but food is excellent. Location is cute and intimate if not a bit kitschy. Nice quiet spot in Hayes Valley. Lamb was delicious.
author: April M.

description:
We went to Il Borgo for the first time last week.  What a fun little place.  The food and service was great and the atmosphere was that of a corner neighborhood restaurant.  We brought in our own wine and the corkage was reasonable at $10/bottle - that is a big plus!  Parking can be tough but that is everywhere in Hayes Valley - we found a good spot less than a block away.

Would definitely recommend this place - we will be going back.
author: Jerry B.

description:
Lackluster Italian without any kind of pleasant vibe. A tired Italian restaurant with tired kitschy decor, a tired staff and a tired menu. The lasagnette was good, as many people said, although a little over salted to my taste. The service was adequate. The salad was okay but not great. The bread was dry and tasteless, definitely a sad thing in an Italian restaurant.  The wine tasted distinctly watery, making  me suspect it was either low in quality, or slightly watered down. Once upon a time, I'm sure this was a charming place. Today, it massively needs a refresh in every way. zzz.

People, this is San Francisco, a foodist's paradise!  You can do waaaaay better!
author: John S.

description: A satisfactory, if unspectacular local Italian spot.. close to the 'house of soap' (which is a very good thing). I had the Ravioli, which was soulfully satisfactory and SP had a chicken with capers recipe - equally 'okay'. Unfortunately, the most memorable thing about this place was the grumpy, smelly waiter... but we'll likely be back to this affordable and cozy local restaurant.
author: Kristy M.

description: If I could only eat here every night! It's authentic Italian, and the food always tastes quite good. The atmosphere is calm and soothing. The service is always attentive.
author: Roberto A.

description:
The location is overwhelmingly convenient and the fare is nothing short of delicious.  Given the convenience (across the street from home base) I have given myself several opportunities to sample dishes.  Note I used the verb sample, as in to taste a dish that I myself did not order because I stick to (and demand you do the same!) the Lasagneta.  Only food item I've ever wanted to review w/an OMG.  It's fantastic- the vodka cream sauce and the prosciutto are terrific with the unconventional lasagna swirls.  

I have asked, and overheard other patrons ask, the owner/hostess/server Mitra for her recommendation and she never gives one; "everything is good." This may be true, but every time I hear somebody ask, I am tempted to whisper in their ear "... Lasagneta..." then creepily slink out of the restaurant.  Not sure how well that'd be received... but the order is never regretted.  

Its cash only so be advised**
author: c d.

description:
I've driven by this place a thousand times and finally decided to try it.,  So here's what I thought:

If your looking for a romantic spot, with a no frills, reasonably priced,  traditionally prepared Italian food then this is your place.   

*The ambiance romantic - 4 stars
*The food a little above average 3 to 3.5 stars (except the garlic bread it was below average...it wasn't even real garlic, they used garlic salt and Parmesan, yuck.)  My pesto gnocchi was creamy and good but very heavy, but it is italian i guess.  My bf got the lobster rav and he said it was OK but that the sauce wasn't anything special, just a basic tomato sauce that could have come out of a jar.

*The service average. It was a one man show here, our waiter who was probably the owner was waiting on everyone.  He didn't offer much in the way of conversation and he left our used plates at our table way too long.

Bottom line is  I would come back for the atmosphere and gnocchi if I was in the neighborhood.

Oh and keep in mind its a cash only establishment.
author: Molly M.

description:
Lasagnetta. 
They told me I had to get'cha.
So I took yelp's advice. 
And thought Il Borgo's ambiance was nice.
I might even come here twice!
Yes, you betcha ;]
author: Lucia C.

description:
Went here for anniversary dinner with the hubby a couple of weeks ago.  We stumbled across this spot a couple of years ago and keep coming back for the food, service, and ambiance.  Cozy, warm space with  a genuine "little village in Italy" feel to it.  The owners and servers are all wonderful, they make you feel welcome from the time you are seated until you leave.  

As for the food, top notch home made Italian fare.  I love to get the veal dishes and we've tried several of the pasta dishes, all of which are divine.  Great wine list and outstanding desserts and dessert wine.  Highly recommended.
author: vanessa b.

description:
Sitting on the corner Fell in Hayes Valley is a little Italian restuarant but they are way better than chef boy ah di. Now you are talking Italian food. Ordered the Gnocci dish with tomato and basil, perfect .  With a radiccio salad too boot with pine nut, olive oil and gorzogola cheese, I was all set. The tomatoes were not over bearing and the gnocci was to die for. This went  perfect with the glass of chianti.

Definetley come back.....
author: Jim D.

description:
A great, go-to place for Italian food in San Francisco. I'd been to Il Borgo once before, and both then, and now I was with a large group of 8 or more. In both cases they were able to accommodate us (we did make reservations.) I found the service to be adequate on both occasions. I had to turn around and wave over the attendant to have my bent fork replaced, and again to see the wine menu for a second bottle. In both instances, the waiter wasn't terribly busy, so he was able to see that I needed something and immediately assist. 
The food is absolutely top notch. The bread appetizer is nicely soft and fluffy on the inside with a crisp outer crust (though not impossible to pull apart) Last time I was there, I had some sort of pasta dish, which was good, but I remember being really impressed with the pizza my neighbor had. This time around, I ordered the Funghi E Salsice pizza, and it was delicious! The sausage pieces were large and had a notable licorice taste. The dough was thin, but still firm enough to support the pizza and crisp enough to make even the crust a treat when dipped in oil at the end of each slice. I also sampled my friends prosciutto lasagna. I expected the lasagna to be taken over by sharp tomato sauce flavor, since the it was drowned in the stuff, but somehow the sauce was well balanced and satisfying. What was most impressive, though, was the texture. The lasagna noodles were incredibly thin with lots of layers, avoiding the rubbery texture I usually associate with Lasagna.
I'm not really a coffee drinker, but if I were, I'd imagine the tiramisu would have been right on the money. It was so moist I could have mistaken it for rum cake, but also very coffee flavored. I only had a taste.
author: Nik K.

description: Me and my sister went in for dinner and had a great experience, the pizza was really really good and the food was fresh! The tiramisu with cappuccino was perfect.  The host was really friendly and gave us some Italian lessons lol,  small mom and pop place with a homy feel.  I would highly recommend it to everyone!
author: David K.

description: Based on Yelp Reviews and seeing the crowd queuing a few weeks back, we decided to try Il Borgo. We loved the sort of kitsch-ey Italian decor, and also the big Mickey Mouse who watches you in the bathroom. The waitress was attentive and steered us correctly on whether to share the salad or not.  I had read recommendations on yelp for the Lasagnetta, lasagna noodles rolled in spirals containing  prosciutto and mozzarella and topped with a yummy, slightly creamy red sauce. My friend had the Pollo Pizzaiola, breast of chicken with tomato, olives and caper sauce, and declared it very good. Hers came with Broccoli and  delicious roasted (or sauteed) potatoes. Pizzas and pasta at nearby tables  also looked delicious. The portions were huge, and we both left with doggie bags. Instead of three of the spiral lasagnetti, I would've like two and some broccoli.  The Chianti was serviceable, and the prices were very reasonable.  We will definitely go back.
author: Crystal C.

description: Very fresh, delicious, authentic home style Italian. The tiramisu is amazing!
author: M G.

description:
I love this place!  I have been coming here for years and honestly have never had better  Penne Al'Arrabiata ever before. The authenticity of the food is unmatched when it comes to the dish mentioned!!  

The decor is odd, but I think it makes for great conversation.  Their are clothes hanging from a clothes line and the walls have an Italian mural landscape and brick theme.  Their are only 3-4 people that work there and service is direct and friendly.  

The prices are excellent and the portions large.  The house glass of wine is filled to the brim and they serve every table fresh bread upon arrival.  I highly recommend this place and obviously would suggest the Al'Arrabiata.
author: Bonnie Marie J.

description:
Delicious little family Italian place in Hayes Valley! 

We went in last night during the rain storm for takeout. The staff was very friendly and welcoming. The atmosphere felt very authentic and warm. 

The woman who took our order was great, very friendly and VERY willing to discuss and alter the menu items! 

We ordered the Lasagnetta - OUT OF THE WORLD delicious. My boyfriend gets this AT LEAST once a week! Fantastic! 

I, on the other hand, made it a bit more difficult and asked for a dinner portion salad with chicken, which to my surprise was not a problem at all and the dressing was outstanding! 

All came with delicious homemade bread and was ready in no time! 

Would recommend for dinner and would be a great place for a first date! Just sayin!
author: Kelly B.

description:
Full of surprises around every corner, San Fran has once again delivered delectable Italian food outside the famed Italian district of North Beach. 

After passing Il Borgo for about 2yrs coming off the lovely 101 N. the fam and I decided to give it a go. A late night dinner in Hayes Valley led to multiple bread baskets, large plates of pasta, vino rosso, and loads of Italian charm. 

Starting with a crisp and crunchy salad always gets a meal off to a nice start. Il borgo's house salad is composed of fresh radicchio dressed with a light olive oil and lemon dressing. Perfect to share. 

As a little snack before the main dishes arrived we tried the bruschetta as we tend to at every Italian place we eat at. It was served on warm thick crostini slices with heaps of tomatoes covered in basil and olive oil. Moving onto the main dishes, it is apparent that pasta is the star of this restaurant. The homemade artichoke ravioli sauced in a wonderful house tomato sauce was a solid choice. The lasagnetta (rolled version of lasagna) was generous and delicious.  

The tiramsu is worth every bite if you can manage to eat a bit more!

Casual ambiance and delicious Italian fare.
author: Theresa T.

description:
The hostess was absolutely delightful, and began our wonderful evening at Il Borgo. She not only provided a beautiful ambiance, but was able to capture the essence of a family dining experience, which I believe every Italian establishment should have. They even had clothing strung up on a line above the kitchen to make it feel like home (not my home, but I'm sure that was what they were going for).

We walked in and were immediately transported to Italy. Pavarotti serenaded us with Nessun Dorma as we sipped our Nero D'avola (that's wine in case you were wondering). I digress.

Unfortunately, the food was average (eh' slightly above). I should have begun by saying that I really didn't  tag along to eat, I was more interested in the wine list (which was extremely limited). I am also not a huge fan of pasta. I recommend the Insalata del Borgo, and the Funghi e Salsice pizza. I was not as impressed with the Pasta Carbonara as the party I was with. I felt that their pancetta was beautifully sliced, but seemed to overpower the sauce. I would have used more garlic.

I would definitely return for wine and appetizers. The ambiance made it comfortable for us to converse, and the service was superb.
author: Alyvia M.

description:
Ok, so this place has it's list of positives and negatives...let's start with the good stuff:
- Veggie lasagna is damn good (if you like eggplant...which I normally don't, but the way they cook it is yummy)
- Prices are reasonable
- Never had to wait for a table
- Nice rustic Italian feel

Ok, now the not so nice stuff:
- Service is slow...not bad, just slow
- Cash only...meh
- Bread they give you is pretty bland - a little heat-up in the oven would do wonders
- When ordering a bottle of wine, they bring it to your table already open and pour huge glasses for the whole table
- Stay away from the bruchetta - garlic city!

Overall a decent place for dinner. It was my go-to when other restaurants in the area were showing a couple hour wait.
author: Kalie M.

description:
I had dinner here with a group of friends and I wasn't too impressed with the food after the meal. Presentation of the food wasn't super impressive and the taste wasn't all the way there. 

Food: 
1) Artichoke ravioli: These were homemade raviolis that looked like Chinese dumplings. The ravioli skin wasn't bad. I liked the texture, it was an appropriate thickness and overall, well made. But the filling was a little lacking of artichoke flavor. I couldn't really taste anything but just some mush in the middle. If you didn't tell me what the ravioli was filled with, I would have never in a million years been able to taste or use visual cues to identify that it was artichoke. 
2) Spaghetti: Made with a white wine sauce instead of tomato. The sauce was on the creamier side but it was well flavored. The dish wasn't presented in the most appetizing manner. It just looked like a large dish of spaghetti noodles cooked with nothing else. No variety and very bland looking. 
3) Bruschetta: Pretty good. Tomatoes were diced into larger pieces. They went liberal with the olive oil so it that was well pronounced in that taste of the dish. The bread was baked to perfection. Well made dish overall. 

**Notes: I just felt like the whole meal was too carb heavy. It was one big carb party. I really feel like the dishes could have used a larger variety of ingredients to prepare. Like adding in a dash of veggies here and there to add color and flavor to the dishes would have really helped. Or at least adding some meat to give a little more nutritional value. Just my two cents...

Service:
Pretty nice. No complaints. 

Ambiance: 
Heavy Italian themed decor! I loved it! Romantic dim lighting with candles at every table. Made you really feel like you were in Italy, dining in a cozy alley somewhere, experiencing the essence of the Italian culture. The bathroom had this heavy dungeon type lock on it. No one's breaking in that door for sure! 

Price: 
For the quality and portion of the food here, I don't think it was very appropriately priced. But if you just base the price off of Italian food in general, then it was average. 
*There is no sign but CASH ONLY!!! There is an ATM inside there but who wants to pay stupid ATM fees?!?!

Overall: 
Not too impressed with this place. The presentation and taste of the food was not that great but maybe I just didn't order the right thing? I don't think I'm coming back to give it another chance though :(
author: Amiee H.

description:
My family & I really enjoyed this place. Staying at the Hotel Kabuki in Japan Town, we were looking for something with good reviews within walking distance, and this fit the bill (it's .7 of a mile away). I called ahead to make a reservation; I'm not sure it was necessary, but it was pretty steadily busy until about 9:30. We crammed into a slightly uncomfortable booth, though there are no complaints from me, just one of my overtired kids who didn't like the hard bench. 

Food overall was great, and prices were right. Our bread came out a bit on the cold side but we were too hungry to care. As an opener we had bruschetta, which was done perfectly in my book - big chunks of tomato, olive oil, basil, and perfectly toasted bread. My pollo pizzaiola was right on as well - tender chicken breast with tomato, olives and caper sauce, with string beans and potatoes to accompany; I liked the sauce a lot but others in my party found it a bit heavy on the capers. Their loss. Margherita pizza (mozzarella, tomatoes, fresh basil) was just right as well, though my daughter prefers it heavier on the cheese. My wife was blown away by the gorgonzola pizza (tomatoes, mozzarella, gorgonzola cheese), and everyone else who tried it liked it. Our oldest was disappointed the fettuccine bolognese came out as a brown sauce when we were expecting red. We finished by sharing cheesecake and homemade tiramisu; delicious. Cappuccinos too. 

Service was a bit slow; the two people running the place (one of whom I took to be the owner) tried valiantly to keep up with tables and were courteous, but they really need someone else to ease the load. We waited quite a while after we'd eaten so we could order dessert. But it's not something that would keep us away.
author: David L.

description:
GET THE LASAGNETTA!
GET THE LASAGNETTA!
GET THE LASAGNETTA!

Ok, now that I made my point, we had four dishes for four people.  To start, we could have been given four pieces of simple bruschetta but we were awkwardly served 3 pieces.  The lasagnetta was probably the best spiral of saucy, cheese infested noodle I've ever thrown down the hatch.  If you are one for ambiance, notice that the bathroom lock is like a dungeon hatch.

From this beautiful family run restaurant, we also had two mushroom and sausage dishes (Funghi e Salsice) in the penne and pizza formats.   I must say, don't be afraid to order the pizza because it will blow away any simple pasta dish.  The rigatoni was alright but if you're ordering this before the lasagnetta then you're crazy.  Did I mention to get the lasagnetta?
author: Joey S.

description:
I stumbled upon Borgo in the midst of a, "Ahhhh I don't know what i want to eat, craze!"  I couldn't stomach sushi, just ate pizza, wasn't feeling burgers and there we were, on the crossroads of a no-man's land of food establishments.  I think my friend was getting nervous because when we looked up saw Italian he seemed relieved in his, yeah I can find something.  

We walked in and it had a very tuscan feel to the decor.  I couldn't believe I had never seen or heard of this place before.  The rustic decor was welcoming and the staff extremely friendly.  Oddly enough in the bathroom there is a large teddy bear sitting on a chair and a medieval style lock on the door.  I felt like I was bolting the gate from Romans potentially storming my castle.  

I ordered off the menu, which I tend to do in Italian restaurants.  The waiter said no problem!  Chicken Picatta, you got it.  My friend ordered the sausage mushroom pizza.  His pizza was huge and had plenty of toppings.  My chicken picatta was just right.  It came with potatoes, veggies and artichoke.   I've been searching for good classic chicken picatta in the city and I think I found it. The sauce was on the thicker side, the chicken was thin and cooked in flour before serving.  Delightful!

We couldn't stomach dessert but the waiter gave us a free small after dinner port!  It was a great ending to a very yummy dinner.  Home cooked Italian all the way!  

If you ware in Hayes Valley and don't feel like anything on the main strip come over to Il Borgo, it was worth it, not just the food but the whole package experience.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
We stumbled into Il Borgo last week after the restaurant we originally wanted to go to (which didn't take reservations BTW) had an hour wait.  My hubby and I and the in-laws were looking for an old school Italian place and were looking forward to having old school chicken parmigiana and noodles and sauce.

The place is small, but decorated like it's in old Italy. Even though they had a decent wine selection, the only wines you could order by the glass was the house wine. 

The starter salad was AWFUL!!! All of us had different salad, but they had the same salad dressing. The dressing was bitter to the point where you couldn't eat the salad. The waiter was like, "Can't you taste the garlic?" I'm thinking, "Um no. Um Hell no." Please take it back.

I was a little scared about our entrees after that. I ordered penne with mushroom and sausage, hubby ordered chicken parmigiana, mom-in-law ordered lasagna with Prosciutto, and Dad-in-law ordered spaghetti. All of the dishes were smothered in the same color sauce, a very light red sauce that reminded me of Trader Joe's Four Cheese pasta sauce. In fact, I think it was...

The entrees were good, but I could have done them at home and not paid $120 for all four of us to eat.
author: Erica S.

description:
Lasagnetta!  What a fabulous dish that you don't find at too many Italian joints.  I will now come here just for this dish.  The bolognese was good but the lasagnetta was the winning dish, with the saltiness of the prosciutto, gooey cheese, and perfect marinara sauce!  

if you order a soda you get a can.  The bread is ok, but you get olive oil and vinegar to dip in, which I prefer over butter.

I think the average price for a dish is $11-$14.  Overall a solid, quaint Italian place!
author: Lyndsey H.

description:
I have a feeling that five or ten years ago this was four or five star.  The food was good but nothing notable and worth it for the price.  However, with all the choices of restaurants in the area there was nothing that set this place apart.  I had the lasagna and my friend had the primavera and the portions were huge and a good value.

The server and service in general was very good.  The owner seemed like a nice guy but didn't seem to have his heart in it.  I have a feeling that if you live in the neighborhood you get personalized attention.

I'd venture back if there were too long a lines at some of the neighboring restaurants (not to name names).  Next time I do go the pizzas look like the item to order.
author: J. S.

description:
Swinging little gem,
Simple, traditional dishes,
Went twice in two weeks.
author: Brian J.

description: Not a good experience here. We were in the mood for some yummy Italian food and decided to walk down to this spot. We have been here before but not in many years and waited a revisit. Upon walking in we were seated immediately. After 15 minutes our water arrived and we requested some bread. I ordered the pasta primavera, my dining companion ordered the margherita pizza. Nothing super fancy but always good choices. Our food arrived and we could not be more excited since we were starving. I took my first bite of the pasta and it tasted very bland. I decided to try another bite and yep, bland as hell. The cream sauce was like milk, no flavor, nothing. I asked my husband to try incase I was being too picky. He, who literally will eat anything, agreed that it was the blandest dish he had ever tried. I flagged down the waitress and requested some parmesan. Luckily she brought over a small bowl and I dumped the entire portion in my pasta. It was edible then but I was super bummed. I shoveled the food down to ease my hunger. We looked at the receipt when it was all over and it was 5 dollars over what was to be expected. The bill was unreadable and scribbled so we had to ask her what it said. When we explained that the pizza was three dollars less on the menu she adjusted that price but would not budge on why my pasta was two dollars more than listed. Only saying "these are our prices, the menu is old" . She returned and we threw down our card. The waitress (the owner) requested cash instead of the card we gave her. My hubs explained that we had no cash and only had the card (we hardly ever have cash). She stood and looked at us for a minute as if we magically would pull out dollars our of air then stormed off. Then began our wait. I saw her run our card and tend to the other tables.....for 25 minutes. I could see our receipt just hanging off the machine. She finally gave it back to us and walked away. No thank you for dining with us or how was your dinner. We left vowing to never come back. I hate having to make that decision especially since we are HUGE supporters of our local businesses. Its such a shame. Hopefully they will improve on their standards and attitude.
author: Bri R.

description:
Ok, I have to update my review to 5 stars.  Since my first taste of Il Borgo, I have brought countless friends and relatives over to my favorite weekday Italian eatery, and have made genuine converts out of them. 

It is amazing how many people have walked/driven/biked past this past and wrote it off, thinking that for sure it was a dump/front for organized crime.  But once their mouths are full of warm proscuitto and tender ricotta lasagnetta, they can't help themselves. Il Borgo becomes a new favorite.

I heart reasonably priced Italian wines and the radicchio salad with pine nuts.  Absolutely awesome/delicious.
author: Lorin Y.

description:
Il Borgo... Il is right!  

My girlfriend and I went for a late dinner, shared the caprese salad and the lobster ravioli.

Caprese salad was horrible, I could have went to safeway, cut up tomatoes and mozzarella myself and it would've tasted better.  The cheese was sliced so thick, had no flavor, and the weirdest texture ever.  The tomatoes tasted unripe.

The lobster ravioli was nothing to rave about either, presentation dull, not anything special.  

It's a nice atmosphere, great staff, but the food just isn't that great.  I wish it had been better.
author: Alicia T.

description:
Worst service ever.
The waitress was plain rude. 

Two examples:
She brought a plate to our table and said we ordered it, and we had not. So she just put it in front of me and said you guys figure out who ordered it. We complained, so she took it away.
 I asked for a glass of water at the counter when we were paying. She made a fuss and asked me, "what did you do with your [previous] glass"?
author: babak h.

description:
Although parking is horrendous in this part of the city, I can still safely say that'll I'll return to Il Borgo without a moment's hesitation.  

Their table bread is rustic, wholesome goodness.  It wasn't served warm, but it was fresh and good with a flavorful olive oil already waiting on the table.

I can give 5 stars to the gorgonzola pizza, without reservation, and warn you ahead of time that if you order this as an appetizer (to share with one other person), you'll be too stuffed to enjoy your full dinner.

I have to drop back one star on the lobster ravioli.  The Aurora sauce (tomato-cream combo) didn't do a lot for me, and although the ravioli were cooked al dente, I could *swear* I've bought these particular ones at Costco before.  Could be wrong, but they looked and tasted familiar.

Note to folks who keep kosher, their food is laced with prosciutto, so be careful what you order -- that said everything I saw come out of the kitchen looked interesting and delicious. I also always find it amusing when the patrons don't hesitate to ask each other what they ordered or share tasting notes in a more convivial fellowship.

Final five star marks go to the lovely Italian hostess/waitress, and the warm, intimate decor.   

One last note (I should start labeling them p.s.s. or p.p.s.) - order the bottle.  The wine pours are not what I'd call overly generous for the price.

And the final, final, final note, I regret that I didn't have room for the desserts.  I pledge a swift return and full report!
author: Theresa B.

description:
I wanted to LOVE this place! I AM SOOOO incredibly sad and let down:( 
I walked by last night and said to my husband, "If Gordon Ramsey could see the filth from this window!" He said, in a British Accent "What the F*ck is wrong with you people?" The owner/lady/hostess, was so nice, it's ONE block from my apt, I LOVE LOVE Italian food (being Italian/Greek), and it's ideal when our family is visiting from NY and not wanting to go to N.Beach. The Lasagna, was mush, the wine was cheap (taste), bread was boring, pizza- :(, Raviolis, again mush, AL DENTE CHEF!!!!  Everyone at our table, walked in with the same attitude, so excited that we found a hot spot ONE block away! But all 6 people had a major let down. I am so sorry to even write a bad review, really, I hope the owner reads this, because there is hope!  You could have a line out the door (look at your neighbors-Suppenküche, HELLO). Take those curtains OFF YOUR DOOR, IT LOOKS CLOSED, and wash them! (actually, toss them out.  Sitting at the table facing Fell Street, look up at the wall, look at how dirty it is.  The floor, the windows, the curtains, COME ON!  PLEASE I BEG YOU to shut the door and revamp!!!  I promise I will write a great review and tell everyone about you!!!  

Copied from an interview done by a restaurant owner:

What's one restaurant pet peeve you have?

"Filthiness. Honestly I don't mind a rude wait staff if the food is good enough, but if it's dirty, I hate that and I'm not coming back. Also, when it's too loud or crowded. "  

Well, you DO have the crowded taken care of..... :((((
author: Kristie H.

description:
Feeling like you need a little love and comfort?  Hit up Il Borgo for some outstanding homemade pasta, from-scratch tiramisu, and service with a warm smile and plenty of "gratzi"'s from Mitra, your adopted Italian momma for the night.

Dishes are overflowing with fresh flavors and it's evident that very little, if anything, comes premade.  Simple, flavorful, home cooking in a warm, welcoming neighborhood spot.
author: Sean H.

description:
Yet another so-so, overpriced "Italian" restaurant (I would certainly ramp it up to a "$$$", despite the simple decor). The carpaccio was served straight out of the fridge, exceedingly cold and with mediocre grated cheese on top. My "uccelli scappati" were not even remotely reminiscent of what my mom used to make when I was a child (I grew up in Northern Italy). Tiramisu was just average. Only redeeming quality, the wine - we ordered a bottle of Valcalepio, which is from my region, not easily found elsewhere, and it wasn't outrageously priced. At least I got to chat a bit with the waiter, a kind man from my area (we even joked in our own dialect). 
All in all, il Borgo isn't that bad (there's worse in SF, when it comes to Italian restaurants), at least it's not pretentious.
author: Maurizio F.

description:
I crutched a couple of blocks up the street recently to have dinner at Il Borgo for date night. It's been around for a long time, before the neighborhood bloomed into its current state, it was the restaurant near the end of the freeway. And I guess it's still holding on to a bit of the past, in that it's Cash Only (-1 star). Oh well.

Then again, there is a reason why it has survived for so long, and that reason is the food. The food was delicious across the board. Wine seems to be only by the bottle, but they have reasonable prices for tasty wine (we had a bottle of Chianti). 

Service is a bit gruff, and a bit loose (another star gone), but if you're willing to put up with it, and the fact that they don't take plastic (but do have an ATM), it's worth a visit if you are in the area.

NB - if you are going on saturday night, call ahead and make a reservation!
author: neil c.

description:
I rarely go to Italian restaurants when I eat out because I feel like Italian food comes pretty standard.  Italian restaurants rarely wow me, and I make damn good pasta (if I do say so myself...and I do) that easily satisfies any pasta-cravings I may have.  

That said, Il Borgo blew me away.  I had dinner here a few nights ago with a family member who lives in the city.  We decided to have dinner in Hayes Valley because it is a middle point between our apartments and it is teeming with adorable places.  She found Il Borgo on Yelp, but we were open to strolling around and finding something else if we felt like it.

The delightful aromas of basil and garlic wafting out of Il Borgo sealed the deal, however.  We both started salivating before even entering this delightful little restaurant and decided that we HAD to try it.  I am so glad we did!  

We ordered the vegetable lasagnetta (with ricotta, veggies, and cheese), and the pizza margherita.  The lasagnetta came out first, and all I can say is wow.  It was amazing!  It had the perfect blend of garlic and cheese and it melted in your mouth, which is a VERY difficult thing for pasta to do!  The tomato-based sauce was savory and delicious, and I sopped up my bread in the sauce because I didn't want any of it to go to waste.  

By the time the pizza arrived, we were already full because we had stuffed ourselves on the VERY filling lasagnetta.  But it smelled so good, we couldn't resist (story of my life).  It, too, was delicious!  I am usually a parmesan cheese-fiend (who are we kidding - I am an all-kinds-of-cheese-fiend), but it was not even necessary.  The pizza could stand alone.  

In addition, the ambiance of the place is so adorable!  I was transported back to the rustic little cafes in the squares and alleys of Venice.  There are clothes lines traversing the walls and the golden faux-brick paint inside the Il Borgo gives it a warm, cozy atmosphere.  It would be a great place to share some wine and pasta - Lady and the Tramp-style - with a date.  

Finally, the owner of the restaurant is a delightful Italian women.  She was really nice and helpful and wanted to make sure that we had a great experience in her restaurant.  Italian-born owner?  It doesn't get more authentic than that, folks.

The only down side to this place is that it is cash-only, which I am not too happy about in this day and age when everyone accepts credit cards.  But as long as you know that going in, it's really not a big deal.  They also have an ATM inside or nearby, and I think that the quality of the food and ambiance makes that oh-so-steep $2 bank fee worth it;)

I really loved this place and would love to go back!
author: Julie S.

description: Good, solid, tasty food. Felt welcomed and well taken care of by the owner/staff.
author: Gary M.

description:
Had a horrible experience. Very rude service. We ordered a bottle of wine and when it was brought to the table it was already open. I looked at the label and saw that it was different from what we ordered. They yelled at us, "it's basically the same thing!" That seems like a total scam.

We were yelled at for complaining, and then literally just left without having anything.
author: Sachin A.

description:
Cute place, random uncomfortable benches to sit on. 

Ok, ok... Enough random talk- let's talk about the food! I had the gnocchi with the Gorgonzola and pesto sauce, mixed in broccoli, it was pretty good!  

Also tried the lasanetta.., ok here's the deal. I dint really like pig meat.. This had prosciutto in it..  At first I thought, heck no!!! Then I tried it.. Can you say yummy to my tummy!! I couldn't even taste it.  Melts in your mouth.

Mmmmm Mmmmm Mmmmm
author: Belina G.

description:
Pass. After seeing this place a million times we finally went and what a waste of $70.00. Carpaccio was good, caprese was a caprese, but the pasta bolagnese was super bland and did taste just like ground beef. My saltimbocca was ok, excellent side veggies. But the whole thing was just eh. Chianti was like drinking fire water.  One waitress, so we hardly could ever get water etc, and the WORST, it was CASH ONLY. ARE YOU KIDDING ME. That in itself was the kiss of death. 

Once was plenty for me, won't be back.
author: Nicole F.

description:
OMG the best Lasagne in the whole world! Never had a better one! It's so yummy and it's huge, It's not made with ground beef it's made mit prosciutto (italian ham) and loads of cheese:) And a subtle tomato sauce. I was there for the 4th time and I can't get enough! 
The restaurant is cute and cozy and has lots of italian flair!
author: Katja J.

description:
unbelievable pasta! It really has something special.

from-scratch tiramisu was also so good.
author: Woosung A.

description: My favorite spot in Hayes Valley! Very cozy and quirky atmosphere, hearty Italian dishes served by a super friendly staff. Prices are reasonable for the neighborhood, and every single thing I've ordered from here has been rustic perfection. Cash only, but there is an ATM right in the restaurant. A + +, would try again.
author: keara r.

description: Basically what you pay for - it's a mid priced local Italian place. Pretty easy just to walk-in for a casual meal. We had the chicken breast with endives and the carbonara. Wine selection is limited.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Dined here prior to seeing SF Ballet "Romeo & Juliet".  This is a cozy, casual restaurant which seems to fill up quickly on Friday night, so a reservation is probably recommended.  

Lasagnetta was excellent and I'd definitely recommend it  ($12.75, Rolled lasagna filled with prosciutto and mozzarella).  Another notable dish was Vitello Saltimbocca ($18.75, Veal scaloppini in Marsala wine, sage, topped withprosciutto and mozzarella).  Also I liked Mista ($6, Romaine lettuce, radicchio, arugula with Italian house dressing & fresh herbs), which I thought was really fresh and yummy.

Didn't get to the dessert section as we were quite full, but heard that Tiramisu is also home-made.  I'm definitely going to try it the next time.
author: Kioko O.

description:
Really? ****? If your looking for an American take on Italian, this might be a good fit. Large portions, extra cheesy, mild flavors. 

Service was fine, but a bit slow. When we sent back our radicchio salad (it was just radicchio and three little pieces of blue cheese) and explained that it wasn't what we expected, the server cackled and walked away. 

Clearly others find something valuable here, but I'd recommend pushing on to find better Italian. 

Food: *
Service: ***
Space/Atmosphere: ***
Value: **
author: Saul E.

description:
Waaaa!  They won't take my credit card!  Businesses are now responsible for the fact that you no longer use paper money?
This place is great.  Cozy atmosphere, hospitable host and great food.  This is my wife's favorite place, so I've eaten there a lot.  Pizzettas are great, as is the Lobster ravioli, artichoke ravioli, penne e fungi and I just tried a chicken special: breast rolled with mozzarella and ham in a mushroom sauce.  
Also best tiramisu I've ever had.
These types of places are going extinct, go there already.
author: Ian S.

description:
It's all about the Lasagnetta!! To be honest, I haven't had anything else here at all but the Lasagnetta is amazing. It's a strange take on lasagna and it's not as meaty as I normally like my food to be, but it's still delicious. 

I've never sat down in this restaurant to eat; I've always down takeout so I can't really comment on the ambiance. It's a fairly small place though. The real bummer though is that they only take cash. They have an ATM in the place in case you don't realize that but it's still a pain.
author: Lauren C.

description:
This is my favorite Italian restaurant in the city because it's a perfect walk from the lower Haight to the edge of Hayes Valley, and a perfect walk from there to Hotel Biron afterward!

I've only had one bad experience where instead of artichoke ravioli I got some pork-filled pasta.  Granted, that's a huge mess up, especially since I am vegetarian.   I think under normal circumstances I would probably never go back after that but I have a special place in my heart for Il Borgo.  It's so cute and romantic, with candles in chianti bottles and al fresco cafe style seating.   

They make the best Italian pizza in the city, hands down.  Cracker thin crust, fresh mozzarella, fresh basil ... its always perfect.  The pistachio gelatto is also to die for!  

I think my love for Il Borgo is more sentimental than anything else, but its definitely worth a shot.
author: Molly B.

description:
Wandered by here after striking out at Stelline and Cafe delle Stelle -- both booked because of the symphony that night (usually no trouble at all getting a table).  Cute, with laundry hanging and trompe d'oeil plaster walls.  Reasonably priced, fresh, and tasty. I had the penne with pancetta and white wine sauce, my friend had the chicken tortellini and another had the chicken in balsamic vinegar.   Not the hippest place but very homey. Had a $27 bottle of chianti with dinner.

Cash only.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
San Francisco classic, Italian without the trek to North Beach. Looking for super fancy reclaimed wood interiors? Don't go here. Want no-frills delicious Italian food and generous wine-by-the-glass pours? You'll love this spot. Family-friendly, casual, and consistent. 

Great place for a casual date or to bring out-of-town guests. Bring cash!
author: T. C.

description:
The pizza crust tasted like salty tap water, the pastas seemed like they were straight out of the jar, and the chianti reminded me of grape stems.

Oh, and the waitress's English was very poor, and so naturally she was unable to listen very well.  Not ragging on someone's language abilities, but in the context of waitering, it didn't help the experience.

Pretty sure the Yelp ratings here are yet another example of Yelp rating inflation, which is getting pretty annoying at this point.
author: Jee S.

description:
I went here with a girlfriend last night and I would definitely come back with a date. The prices were reasonable, about $11-$15 for pasta, and the whole place is decorated as a small Italian square. At one point the romantic mood candle at our table burned out and was so promptly replaced I didn't have time to notice. 

Obscure warning- the bathroom has a giant Teddy bear in it....

I ordered the pasta primavera- each bite was a little bite of butter heaven. The peas popped perfectly in each mouthful. Service was great, cash only though. A must go!
author: Briana G.

description:
Three years ago I had a very bad experience here, but since I just created a yelp account I need to share it with you. 
Food was OK, nothing spectacular here.. 
Service was horrible, our waiter was kind of an older man who looked like an owner or a manager. He wiped tables with his hands, kept us with no water or silverware for 15 minutes and was very rude. 
I also noticed him clearing a table then turning the cover over and setting it for new patrons!!! I've never been back, Ewe!
author: Carl T.

description:
I love Italian food.  I love Il Borgo.

Have had the lasagnetta and lobster ravioli on different occasions, and both were very good.  The Il Borgo salad is absolutely delicious, made of fresh radicchio, the perfect amount of italian dressing, and crumbles of blue cheese.  They also pour a generous glass of house chianti.

My dining partner had the chicken stuffed with prosciutto and cheese, with perfectly seasoned side potatoes in a savory reduction sauce and steamed broccoli.  She said it was a bit on the salty side... I tried some of it and thought it was delicious.

The interior decor of the dining area is very charming and romantic, being lit mainly by beeswax candles.  It's a bit dark and subdued, but very relaxing.  I believe the proprietor waited on us herself, and she was very gracious and inviting.  

One important thing to note is that they accept CASH ONLY..  There is an ATM located inside the restaurant at least.  The guy next to us was a bit outraged to find this out after he and his wife finished their meal, but don't let that minor inconvenience stop you from trying some great Italian food at fair prices.
author: Dave N.

description:
This place has the right mix of being a hole in the wall, authentic decor and GREAT food.  I had the Gnocchi and it was to die for.  The service was for the most part great (see below).  Not sure if it was customary, but they gave us complimentary muscat wine for desert.  

For the price of the food (medium), they should accept credit cards.  When we were complimenting the owner at the end of the meal, he did not accept our criticism about having a cash only restaurant.  They even have an ATM in the restaurant.  Pay the extra 10$ a month and get a credit card machine.

This may keep me from returning in the future.
author: J J.

description: Love this place it's right next to our also favorite restaurant Mazzat . My husband has a special pasta that he orders and the owner always accommodate him all the time. I tried their pizza for the first time last week and it's excellent. Real Italian highly  recommend this place.
author: Sue K.

description: Great little family restaurant close to Octavia and Hayes.  Quaint, thoughtful service along with enjoyable wine & food (reasonably priced to boot)... well worth a stop by.
author: Andy C.

description: Great margarita pizza for under ten dollars. Noticed they seem to have switched the brand of cheese they use (bland taste).  Wish they would go back to the previous.
author: John C.

description: This is a small and quaint Italian restaurant nuzzled in Hayes Valley (Cash Only!).  I felt like I was in that episode in Sex and The City when Carrie and Mr. Big for to an Italian Restaurant where he sings to Carrie and she chokes on red wine.  The waitress/hostess had a thick Italian accent and moved around like she was floating (maybe too much wine).  I ordered the carbonara pasta and it was AMAZING.  I loved loved it.  With the bread, I killed the plate.  It was so good, I had a dream about it and then tried to make it at home.  I definitely want to go back again.
author: Neville B.

description: Like others who have seen this place while at the light in their car on their way to someplace else in the CIty, I was happy to finally come to this restaurant one night before the symphony. But it's better to just see the outside and keep driving. It was pretty dark in there and not in a romantic kind of way. We ordered the lasagnetta and a chicken dish and topped it off with the tiramisu but it was all just ok. Nothing stellar.
author: Vivian L.

description:
No frills, nothing fancy, just really good Italian food the way Grandma made it back in the old country (of course I'm trying to picture myself being Italian with an Italian grandmother).

The beef carpaccio is a great place to start on the menu especially if we're having one of those rare warm nights out.  

The carbonara is probably one of the best I've had in the city.  You'd think it's an easy dish to make but trust me, doing it right is tough...I've tried and a lot of other Italian restaurants I've been to have failed.  This one finally restored my faith that finally...someone knows what they're doing.

A great little neighborhood joint for a good food but don't bother bringing your credit card as its cash only.  Lucky for you theres an ATM inside.

1 bottle of wine
1 appetizer
2 entrees
1 dessert
$75.00

Good food and good value for this city
author: Dan S.

description:
I've been here a few times and its been ok.  Recently though it really disappointed us. The girlfriend, a vegetarian, ordered the lasagnetta with vegetables (and I clearly heard her order the vegetarian version) - NOT the version with prosciutto.  A few bites after receiving it, she quickly realized it was stuffed with prosciutto.  By the time we realized there was meat in it, and flagged down the waitress, most of us had eaten all of our food.  Only full plate remaining was the gf's.

OK fine, the waitress f'ed up. But we made it clear that we had ordered the veggie version - and that we did not want to wait for a new dish to be made and brought out and so on, the item was still on our bill at the end of the night. Great.

So the waitress screws up and brings a strict vegetarian a meat dish. Then charges us for it when she realizes her mistake. They would not take it off the bill.

Avoid this place. Food isn't worth it. It's not vegetarian-friendly. It sucks. A million other places to try besides this.

Oh, and to top it off - cash only. Hah.  What is this, '73??
author: Will M.

description:
yummy food with a relaxed atmoshere...great homemade pasta dishes and yummy coffee/desserts!!
parking is tough on the street ....but is really easy if you park a fiat 500!!!!!!!
author: Chris F.

description: For the price, you can't beat the food and service here. My gorgonzola pizza was delicious. I would have preferred a more crispy crust, but for $10 who can complain?! The house red wine for $5 was actually pretty good too. It was our waitress's birthday, and she was friendly as could be. Charming little spot indeed.
author: Mark S.

description:
I got the asparagus ravoli (homemade) which was pretty good. 

 The interior is unique which reminded me of eating at an osteria in Italy. 

Service was quick (plop down the menu and we ordered). 

The chicken/ham dish with red wine sauce was something that could be replicated at home.

CASH ONLY.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Ok, so I finally decided I was giving Il Borgo the short end of the stick by not trying their "signature" menu items.

I ordered their margarita pizza and the home made tiramisu. The pizza was actually quite fine. And the tiramisu was damn good.

Overall, this is a solid place if you know what to order. Stay away from the pasta, but embrace the pizza, and definitely have dessert.
author: Rondeep C.

description: I'm amazed to read the range of reviews.  My friend and I had a wonderful experience.  True... it's not as trendy inside as other Hayes Valley restaurants but the service was prompt, warm and friendly.  The food was what I would make if I could make excellent Italian food.  Nothing trendy or fancy but solid and very tasty.   We visit Hayes Valley about once a month for the symphony or the opera and will most certainly be back.
author: Lisa S.

description:
I came in because of the average 4-stars, but I was disappointed.

Three of us had dinner here. I found all pasta dishes we ordered too salty to my take. They used large portion of cheese, tomato, and salt in the cooking. It's not bad and tastes home-made. But it's not the more delicate Italian I would like. I don't see how the dishes cannot be made at home with a healthier/delicate style.

The service is okay. They didn't bring the bread before the entree at all. The waitress lighted up all the candles on other tables (it's dinner) but not for us. The candle thing was no big deal. But that shows how she ignored our table.

I will skip this place the next time. It's not too bad, just meh....
author: Lo Y.

description:
A blonde, brunette, and a red head walk into a restaurant... and have a fantastic time! Living right around the corner, this is the second time I've been to this restaurant. It just keeps getting better! You must get the fettucine with peas, prosciutto in a creamy sauce. It's so delicious and comforting. 

This restaurant gets five stars because of it's great service, cozy environment, and comforting food. It feels like a family-run restaurant, the people are so friendly and sweet, each time I've been there I feel at home and have a great experience. There was a great balance of excellent service by the delightful lady and the gentlemen (who I think is the chef), and great food that leads to a wonderful time there with friends. This is totally my neighborhood spot! Thanks guys!
author: Kate W.

description:
Il Borgo you made me ill & pissed off-o. I took my friend here for a birthday dinner because I heard it was good (but reasonably-priced) Italian food. The atmosphere of the corner restaurant was charming and warm. The service (one woman) was okay. 

Bread was ok. Caesar salad was pretty good. BUT THEN, I ordered the Pasta Carbonara and all hell broke loose. I have had Lean Cuisines that taste better. I normally don't complain about a dish unless I deem it inedible. This was so sick I had to speak up. When I did, the woman asked if I have ever had the dish. I've been to Italy a couple times and I have had the dish multiple times. There was no excuse. It tasted like it had been sitting in the fridge for a week and they simply re-heated it. 
The woman admitted she HATES pasta carbonara but didn't want to say anything when I ordered it. WTF?

My roommate's pasta was pretty good though (fusilli). They did not comp my meal or give any sort of dessert. In fact, they gave us the wrong bill that was more expensive but caught themselves. The chef came out in search of some constructive criticism. It was awkward but I think I got my point across "sick, bland, just bad."
author: Jackie M.

description:
The bread was really good (you know, the "free" ones they give). My sister's friend said it was really yeast-y. But I couldn't tell, it was good.
The pizza is pretty good, too; thin crust.

I got the gnocchi.... GAME OVER. I got it with the meat sauce, I cannot pronounce that word for my life. And it was not good. I just can't find a place that makes good gnocchi.

My sisters enjoy this place a lot. Well, the rest of the party got some different raviolis and they were pretty good. Their pink sauce is definitely a good mix between the white and red sauces.
author: Sophia N.

description: Cute little hole in the wall Italian spot.  Started out with the radicchio salad.  We ordered the carbonara and lasagnetta (both were good but I liked the lasagnetta a little better).  The owner was super nice!  As we were getting up to leave she overheard it was my birthday.  She was so sweet and insisted I sit down for a treat - she brought out a slice of tiremisu and sang happy birthday to me :)
author: Carolyn P.

description:
Their food is great. It really, really is. They have the traditional "Italian" faves, but also a bunch of different Italian dishes that are truly tasty. Anyone who has tried the lasagnetta will know what I mean. It looks like a savory cinnamon roll, filled with proscuitto and mozz-YUM. I've also had their gnocchi which is delicious as well. I tried the fettucine alla borgo  last night, which was yummm-the homemade pasta was thick and delicious-you could really tell it was homemade.

We got to go last night, but I find the interior to be adorable and romantic,  and the service to be authentic. SO why 4 stars? ATM. I mean, really, what restaurant doesnt take card?? I went in last night to grab the food, and had to use the atm, which was broken. So I had to go across the street and use their atm-which was $1 more! I mean its not the dollar that bothers me, its the unneccesary inconvenience and the fact that I had to pay extra because of their policy. 

Still-go eat there, I promise you'll enjoy their food-a lot.
author: Afton T.

description: We got very basic dishes pasta and salad no real food complaints. However, fork filthy traded with another table and serious attitude and glare from waitress when she wanted me to pay by cash despite credit cards accepted. I did not have enough cash hence the attitude. Also a diner at another table had to return wine glass with crack in it. No need to go back.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Totally couldn't remember the name, but it was the first thing that came up for "Italian Restaurant" under "Hayes Valley." Score!

Anywho, the bf and I came for dinner on Friday; we didn't have it in mind, just kinda walked in. I loved the decor from the get-go; really old-world and adorable. I especially loved the hanging laundry in the corner. 

We were both starving and ate the basket of amazing bread way too fast...luckily the waiter was very nice to keep that coming. I ordered the mushroom and sausage pizza which was fantastic. He got some pasta with meat on it-- good but I stuck to the pizza. The food was also very decently priced, but the wine was the kicker. For whatever reason, we ordered a $25 bottle of chardonnay which I forced myself to help finish. Maybe that's because I stick to dessert wines and there were only 3 whites to choose from. 

So all in all, good place. I liked the food a lot and if we don't bother with wine next time, I think I'd go back.
author: Emilia S.

description: I can't believe this place is still open!  Used to go there over a decade ago.  Love it.  The lasagnetta is legendary.  Gotta get back in there ASAP!
author: JR S.

description:
Rustic italian food in a very likeable rustic old world setting. Had the Fettucine Del Borgo which came in a huge plate. I didn't really fancy the canned tomato flavor of the sauce but overall the dish tasted ok and the homemade pasta good with plenty of chicken and sundried tomato. The Penne E Funghi Salsiccie was excellent. 

Great value for the portion and waitress was kind and friendly.  Unpretentious.

Food: ***
Service: *****
Value: *****
Overall: ***.5
author: M Y.

description:
Super cute Italian joint, really great date spot.  It's pretty small inside, which adds to the charm of the restaurant.  

But goodness, it was so hot inside.  We started with a pizza that was divided into 3 toppings:  1/2 of the pizza had procuitto, 1/4 had artichoke, and 1/4 had mushrooms.  Very thin, hot, and a great way to start a meal if you're hungry.  

For my main course, I had the lobster ravioli.  Great choice- filling yet not too heavy.  The lobster was seasoned nicely inside the pasta.

One great thing about Il Borgo- no corkage fee!  So BYOB!
author: Sarah F.

description: This is hands down the best Italian restaurant in the neighborhood! The decor is cosy and the place has a very laid back feeling. Prices are fair plus you get a large basket of delicious bread at the beginning of your meal. The Lobster Ravioli is one of my favorite dishes! The Insalate del Borgo is also a great starter to share.
author: Julie T.

description:
That's a'more!  More of a 3.5 stars...

My friends and I came here 2 weeks ago after the the Niners crushed the Giants.  Go Niners!  Though I can't say the ambiance of the restaurant is to my liking I had a great time at this restaurant.  I'm not much of a fan for dim lighting, my eye sight is bad enough as it is, so the dim lit room was pretty annoying to me.  Other than that the mural on the walls and the table/chair designs gave a nice Italia feel to it.  I'd say its a pretty good date restaurant if you're looking for one.  The server was great.  She was friendly and talked up a storm with us without being too intrusive to the point where it was interrupting our meal.  I'm always a fan of talking to the workers, it just adds a lot to the overall dining experience...so it was definitely a plus in my book.  Word to the wise...this is not a big restaurant, so I would NOT recommend bringing in groups larger than 4 into this restaurant.  You'll be scrunched up and eating with your elbows tucked to your sides.

I ordered the lasagnetta and good lordy...this is one heavy ass meal.  Carbs, meat, sauce and tons of cheese...just the way I like it!  Every bite was just as good as the last one and I was dying for more.  As hungry as I was, I could not find the space in my stomach to finish the entire dish.  I was pretty sad that I couldn't bring the food home to go as I had a flight early the next morning, so doggy bag was not an option.  Sadness.  The only complaint that I could make about this dish was that it was really hot during my first bite but the server did say the dish was very hot, so I should've nibbled at it a bit first before just shoving a big spoonful in my mouth.

Though I did not get a chance to try some of their wine selection, I saw plenty of tables with an open bottle of wine.  I'll just assume that the wine is good here based on that...either that or San Francisco sure has a bunch of lush drinkers around which wouldn't be too surprising either.  Overall, this was a great experience and if I lived in the city, I can definitely see myself coming back here just to have a nice dinner with some friends to unwind from the work week...
author: Michael T.

description: Eh. Nothing special. Wouldn't come back. Food lacks flavor and portions are small. The bread was good, that's about it....
author: Sarah A.

description:
The first thing that struck me when I first went to this place is that there's a  charming pretend line of laundry strung from the ceiling at the back, reminding you that you're not just at an Italian restaurant, you're at home when you're at this Italian restaurant. Everything else about this experience concurs. 

Il Borgo is much better than what you can get in North Beach. A family from Northern Italy makes all of the pasta and sauces fresh daily. There are many choices. Gorgonzola, marinara, pesto, alfredo, and on. Their best is the Aurora sauce--tomato with a touch of cream. Favorites are the massive meaty (or meatless, if you like) cheesy lasagnetta, the lobster ravioli, the artichoke ravioli, any of their wood-fired pizzas, their homemade bread served with every meal, and the Il Borgo salad. Formaggio? Buon appetito! Prego! 

Oh, and the tiramisu! Ohhhhhhh.

Sergio and his son are the chefs, and Mitra, the mother, manages the house and serves meals on weeknights. They're oh so friendly and genuine. They haven't taken down our Christmas postcard for four years. 

Cash only--ATM at the back. Come hungry or ask for a to-go box. The portions are large, and like the good mother she is, Mitra won't let you leave anything on your plate.
author: Bridget J.

description:
We were promptly seated after having made a reservation in advance.  The restaurant is small, and has a nice quaint feel to it which is good for a romantic date. 

The waiter, an older gentleman who appeared to be Italian, had a very strong accent which made it difficult for us to understand what he was saying.  He also had poor listening skills, as he failed to understand that we were complaining that he had given us the wrong dishes, until the manager pointed out that the dishes were for the adjacent table.

Server issues aside, the food was solid.  The misto salad was simple yet good, with a good touch of shallots.  Lasagnetta was good (a bit too salty and rich for our taste), but I'm sure others will continue to rave over it.

Finally, don't forget to bring cash  - it's cash only!
author: K L.

description:
Just went back for the I-don't-know-how-manyth time and was reminded of what a great neigbhood spot this is.  Il Borgo means "neighborhood" and they do it right in this one.

In the ten years we've been going, our daughter has gone from infant in a car seat to happily chatting up Mitra, the woman who runs the dining room.  Mitra welcomes us warmly each and every visit.

The pastas are great, and if you have a special request, they're happy to accommodate.  And you gotta love the dripping candle wax table lighting.

A great meal,  great deal, a great spot.
author: David A.

description:
I had to give Il Borgo a 5 Star because the food was excellent!  My wife and I enjoyed perfectly cooked salmon (5) and chicken (5).  The potatoes were also cooked perfectly(5).   The vegetables were good (3.5) and the cheezecake was also very good  (4).
 The wine was good to very good (3.5-4).   The service was very good (5) and the atmosphere was romantic (4.5).
author: Douglas E.

description:
I loved the ambience of this restaurant on a rainy Friday evening: candle-lit, small, cozy, friendly.  The food however, left much to be desired.  I ordered the fettucini bolognese and although I was in the mood for comfort food, the first comparison to come to mind was hamburger helper.  My husband ordered the chicken saltimbocca and enjoyed his sides (zucchini and potatoes) better than the main dish.  

Not sure we will go again.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
So after the GPES, Goddamn Premature Ejaculation-Sushi at Domo, we came here.
We were very happy to find this place because we were so pissed off and still hungry after spending 70 bucks Sushi at Domo.

A Small Cozy Authentic Italian.

My son ordered one pasta dish, Pizza Napolitan and a raw thin sliced beef thing..... forgot the name.
We loved it.
Pasta dish was just right .
Pizza was thin, great sauce,
Nice people.
Clean small bathroom.
There was a big stuffed bear sitting on a chair right inside of the bathroom.
Freaked me out.
The bath room has a small door with a 12 inchs long, 3 quarter inch diameter, large L shape lock.
The bathroom door itself looked like an antique small door from Frankenstein's house or something like that.

Waitress, " Would you like something else?"
Me, " Yes, I'd like a cup of coffee please."
Waitress, " Cappuccino?"
Me, " No, coffee please?"
Waitress, " Espresso?"
Me, " No, No regular coffee?"
Waitress, " Oh, Americano?"
Me, " YES, Americano!!!! (OMFG!)"

The Americano was a HELLA GOOD Coffee.

Cash only but ATM is in the restaurant!
The machine only charges 1.50 is pretty good deal.
I'll come back.

Domo Ali-Gatto il Borgo.

And FXXX You to Domo.

I am still mad.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Cheese.
