I'm a fan. Especially when it enters the decor contingent. I guess that explains my love for theme restaurants and some corporate chains like Red Lobster (hello, Lobsterita!) and Hooters (does this even need a parenthesis?). 

And so, imagine my delight, surprise and smirky smile when I walked by this restaurant a few weeks ago on a Sunday stroll and caught a glimpse of dripped wax covered candles, faux aged looking walls and fake grapes hanging from the walls! Could it be? Might it be? A totally cheesy Italian joint within walking distance of my house?!?!

Hell yes it is and so the other night we decided to make it amore. Or a cheesay or, well, he had no say really, i picked the dinner spot and so we went. As soon as we walked in it was even better than I could have imagined on the outside! The cheese went all the way to 11!

As for the food and wine, well, I think this place is kinda like Disneyland, and minus the one cart in the park with the killer corndog, you aren't really paying for or expecting a 5-star Michellin or Yelp-rated meal, but are going more for the fun ambiance of the experience. That was definitely had thanks to some great company and fun conversation.

For nibblies, we ordered the lasagnetta roll thingamahoos and he ordered the lamb chops. I will say they lost a point or two for the butcher skills of the chops as he spent most of his meal picking bone fragments out of his bites. Sexy! My dish was good, and made for decent leftovers, but not sure they were anything I would rush back for. Might try the pizza though as the reviews sound promising and the pizza the couple next to us was eating looked tasty.
author: Stephy S.

description:
I hate italian food. I hate italian food because by the time I was ten, this italian american had eaten through enough tomato sauce, cream, pasta and prosciutto to fill most people's lifetimes (or probably, four car garages). Also, I can make it at home, so why would I go out to get sub par food?

Occasionally I do get nostalgic, hungry and lazy. Il Borgo is the only place I've found in San Francisco that is up to my standards.

The cooking at Il Borgo - from my particular heritage at least - is spot on. Mind you, grandma's italian dishes were also heavy on the cream and light on the vegetables. 

Also like grandma's the desserts are fantastic and the lady who brings you food, sort of has a well meaning expectant look like she just wants you to be happy but is worried you aren't really happy and are just saying you are happy so she won't be disappointed. 

The decor, fortunately or unfortunately, is also spot on, from the dusty wine bottle candles, to the mural mixed with faux sculptural brick. If this restaurant had a couch it would be that bright yellow flowered brocade one that had a custom sewn plastic cover over it and was at my Aunt Antoinetta's house for approximately 50 years. It would also have Aunt Netti sitting there in a flowered housedress sewing a very complicated doily in the exact shape of the toaster "To cover it! To keep the dusts out!"

And if that image scares you away from eating at Il Borgo, fine, that just means more for me.
author: Gabe S.

description: Family owned and spectacular!! The food was really fantastic and the owner was charming.
author: Ashley J.

description: I have been coming here for several years and have always had amazing food.  I lived in Italy for 7 years and the food is authentic and the owners are really friendly.  Great prices great choices and amazing food a must if you are in Hayes valley
author: julie c.

description: Without Fredericka it simply wasn't the same. We made a reservation and they clearly gave our table away to some walk-ins and made us wait. And, then we waited FOREVER once we ordered w/ no updates from the waiter. I found the pasta to be a bit soft. I still love the raddichio salad.
author: Andrew K.

description:
From the outside you would not be able to tell that this place is a gem of a restaurant hidden just past Alamo Square in San Francisco.  The dishes have always been pretty incredible, and the pasta is certainly home made.  For many, the down side is that it is "cash-only"...and when they bring you the bill, the total always seems a bit "shady"/made up...but always a fair price.  They are also closed on Sundays, unfortunately.  

Always worth the trip though.  Great place to take a date.
author: Christian H.
jack p.

description: It doesn't get any better than iL Borgo. iL Borgo has the taste and aroma to make your  Woman stay for seconds. The taste of everything they have will sooth your mind and bada bing bada boom, you are in love again. In love with being alive to eat iL Borgo. Your gonna love the way you eat, I guarantee it!
author: James V.

description: Food was okay ordered Carbonara. Nice decorating- authentic. Female owner was really rude. Seemed bipolar- would be really nice and then come back and roll her eyes when asked for water refills. Would not go back bc of bad service.
author: Lissette L.

description:
This is a perfectly good neighborhood italian restaurant to go get an affordable plate of pasta in large portions.  If it's in your neighborhood, go for it; but I'm not going to leave my neighborhood again to get there.  We have "italian" food here too.  Reading other reviews, I wonder if the food varies with the cook of the night, but our meal was satisfactory.  And CASH ONLY.

They have a couple different red sauces.  Both are delicious.  One with a strong flavor of ripe tomatoes, and another which is tangy.  But overall, the food is standard "italian" food that reminds me of the place dad would chose for dinner with the extended family--food with no possibility of offending anyone; taking no risks and hitting no home runs.  The bruschetta was very good.  The lasagnetta is a lasagna noodle spun in a circle instead of layered, with one or two cheeses and minor bits of that fancy ham with a slightly tangy red sauce.  I was bored; STANDARD LASAGNA FROM COFFEEHOUSES THAT SERVE LUNCH IS MORE INTERESTING.  The spaghetti carbonara was good; more cheesy than creamy with a great red sauce.  I also want to note that the pasta plates don't come with any sides, but it is a lot of food.

It would have been a very comfortable place to eat dinner except the waiter seemed to want the door cracked open instead of closed and the cold wind was blowing the door completely open.  Another patron got up and closed the door after a couple rounds of this.

The decor is is generally charming, although it ranges from super high quality faux finishes to gaudy, which has the overall effect of "trying too hard."  The waiter I would politely describe as "efficient", which is nearly a compliment.  But when there are only four patrons in the restaurant, "efficient' seems borderline rude...

There are too many restaurants in S.F. for me to eat here again, but if you are hungry and nearby and on a medium budget it is okay with me if you eat here.
author: Alan B.

description:
I love a good italian restaurant - sadly this is NOT it.  

We went here on a Thursday night - about 7pm and waited about 25 minutes for the gal to take our order, or even fill our water glasses despite being one of only two active table in the restaurant.

The bruschetta was a little burnt, the tomatoes, very far from ripe and the rest of the food was a fairly bland.  The fettucini waqs especially buttery and the marina too runny for my taste.   Medicore food at best.

What really got my goat about this place was the experience we had while paying our bill.  We did not realize that the place only took cash.  Another nuisance but one you can deal with as there is an ATM in the place.    My friend left his credit card in the bill when presented.  About 20 minutes passed, we finished our wine and he must have not realized that he never signed for the bill because we left the restaurant and he left his credit card in the bill jacket.   

The busboy (whom I believe is the son of the owner) comes rushing out and jumps in front of our car yelling about how we didnt pay.  My friend realizes he has left his card inside and goes back in to handle the situation.  At this point we have a bus boy standing in front of my car on Laguna with a lot of traffic behind us.   I tried to pull over to the side of the road to let traffc pass and the bus boy pulls a knife out and motions to slash my tires if I move further - As though we were going to drive off without my friend inside.  

Meanwhile - my budy has since retrieved his credit card and paid in cash.  I was just in shock and in awe that we would be treated like criminals for making an honest mistake.    I cannot believe that this little pipsqueak had the nerve to pull a knife on us.  I had half a mind to call the cops.

Food C - 
Service F 

The one thing I will say is that the inside is decoraed very tastefully but if you want good italian there are a myriad of better alternatives in SF
author: Rick R.

description:
I really loved my food. The pasta Primavera. Wow. So good. you just know it has to be loaded with fat fat fat, because you know when it tastes that good it ain't low cal.

I couldn't chow down there every night, but I can once a month. The lady who waited on us I believe is an owner and she was just a doll.

I'm looking forward to going back to indulge my delights.
author: Marz W.

description:
If I had not been invited to eat at this restaurant with some friends I would have never set foot in the place. The point is of course that the looks of this place are deceiving, and the food is of a much higher quality than the decor would have you believe. The look of this place looks like an italian restaurant in the 70's that went overboard on trying to look authentic, with fake windows, balconies, and god save us fake laundry hanging out to dry, and I'm not talking mural here, i'm talking real string with real clothes hanging off of it. 

Luckily the food is excellent, the home made tortellini were fresh, perfectly cooked, and not drowned in sauce. The house chianti leaved a little to be desired but for the price it was ok. 6 of us ate, shared some appetizers, had a couple of bottles of wine and all got out of there for about $30 per head, not bad at all.
author: Karl L.

description:
I don't think I'd like this place as much if it were in North Beach, but it's in Hayes Valley--a weird part of Hayes Valley--so it works.

The food is pretty good, and the service for the most part is also good.  I'm kind of boring when it comes to Italian food; I tend to gravitate towards the gnocchi, and it's always good here.

They get an extra star for their weird interior and burning candles over and over without cleaning the wax out of the candlesticks.  They lose that star because they don't take credit cards.
author: John S.

description: One of the best places for authentic Italian food in the SF Bay area I love the lagsanetta  they bake they're bread daily and make the noodles daily so everything has a great fresh taste for dessert I usually get the tiramisu made in house like everything else.
author: Josué P.

description:
Love this place!

It is the epitome of an authentic yet quaint neighborhood Italian place.

I've been here many times (I used to live a couple blocks away), and I always felt like I had stumbled upon something great coming inside.  From the hand made pasta, to the Italian waitress and cooks, I always want to come back.  

It's better than most places in North Beach, and without the annoying paizanos telling you how beautiful you are just to get you to eat at their restaurant...don't get me wrong, a little sweet haggling always does the ego good, but doesn't necessarily make the food taste better.

Minus one star because I thought once that I saw a cook smoking and cooking at the same time in the kitchen before they opened...I could have seen this wrong as I was walking and just glanced in...but I mean, oh well...que sera sera :-) Also, cash only, but they have an ATM machine on site...how convenient...
author: Kristin E.

description:
Popped into this resto last night for a second visit.  This place is great in that kitchy sort of Italian restaurant cliche way.  I think this place may be more Italianish than many of its counter parts in North Beach.  The waitress, perhaps Italian, perhaps not, spoke with an Italian accent and filtered our meal with plenty of Italian phrases, verbs and the like, including bonjourno, bon appetito, etc. it was great.  

The piped in music was moving along swimmingly with the Italian restaurant cliche, lulling me into visions of gondolas and the like while we scarfed down our yummy pizza and pasta. I will admit that the caprese salad, eh, the tomatoes were a little tough.  Also, my pizza, the Quattro, while extremely yummy, was also very oily and the crust was not too crisp.  We ate the whole thing, so no problem there, but just sayin...

This place is great for a casual dinner with friends or on a date, as I happened to find myself.  The atmosphere, though campy, is also certainly charming and I suspect I will be back in the near future.  Don't expect high brow food, but if you're hungry, this is a great option. 

PS - Cash Only. 

PSS - As we left the waitress came by to take our wine glasses and noted that mine had a drop left, she asked if I wanted to finish it and I said sure, she told me it was good luck.  I like that kind of genuineness.
author: Claire C.

description:
Il Bargo is a cute, totally decent  Italian restaurant  nestled on a corner in  Hayes Valley.  We  were looking for a casual dinner, so this worked out perfectly.  The interior gives a lot to look at, with a faux awning and window box, balcony and working street lamps.  There is even a little clothesline draped across one corner with some hipster garb.  I half expected Tony from "Lady and the Tramp" to whip out his accordion and burst into a hymn-lengthened version of "Bella Notte."

The food was....alright.  I really enjoy tasting other people's meals (because I am a greedy eater) but there was nothing too inventive about the pasta sauce.  Every dish had the same, ho-hum sauce with lack of flavor and freshness.  The artichoke ravioli was quite delicious, but the fusili appeared packaged and standard.  

The service was fabulous (they have a staff of some really nice folks) and ambiance was terrific.  Then we get the bill and hear the words of doom:  "CASH ONLY."
author: Kerry D.

description:
ITALIAN LIKE MOM USED TO MAKE. I THINK.

but i'm not italian, and that's the problem. my very limited scope of italian food leads me to believe that this place is incredibly authentic, but at that point the food wasn't served yet. things improved, thankfully.

it's another one of those neighborhood diamonds in the rough, you fight for parking next to the projects [sometimes literally, it's like there's a homeless guy on every block demanding tip for "giving" you a space he found] and walk into a building directly across from the old Fell street offramp.

you walk in and see that the decor is very olive-garden-ish. i'm quite sure that most reputable italian restaurants don't need to put fake frescoes of fields and harvests on the walls to assure you that, yes, you're eating at an italian restaurant and not at mcdonald's. but they do. which annoyed me. until the food came.

the food was served very simply, with no strange garnishes or overly decorated glassware. it felt like... north beach. without the assholes. or the high prices. or the acceptance of credit cards. i had to look out at the busy intersection outside to realize that i'm at Fell & Laguna, not Vallejo & Columbus. no Banana Republicans or stripey shirts and blazers and miniskirts here. 

you're in hayes valley, biotch.

but the food was incredibly good. and incredibly [well, kinda] cheap. the parmesan cheese is coarsely grated. the flavors are intense and the sauces are rich. the wine is... well... nonexistent for me because i'm not yet old and wise and cranky enough to note the traces of smoke and strawberries and crap that you get by sticking your nose into a bottle for a half hour. so don't test me. 

the clientele is the neighborhood, people who live in the better area behind civic center who just want something good to eat without getting fleeced at Paul K or Indigo or Sauce or Absinthe or Jardiniere. or suppenkuche [pronounced soup-en-KOO-ka, not soup'n'cootch, you ineloquent bastard]. 

[or patxi's, which is disgusting, but i'll get to that later]

if you're from san francisco you'll love this restaurant. if you're not, you'll like it as well, but probably won't have the cojones to look for street parking in the neighborhood.

good luck, but either way it'll take some effort.
author: Charles C.

description:
A few hard core Italians took me to this little joint. They have been going there for authentic homemade Italian fare for years.

We walk in and were welcomed with open arms. The people are warm, charming, and Italian is their first language. The setting is stereotype Italian ristorante in the US in the 80's kind of feel, with murals of Italian villas on the walls. My friend ordered in Italian for our party of 11 (good for groups, and while I'm at it, good for kids too). Their homemade pizzas and pasta were fantastic and super-comfy wumfy. But THE thing, I mean really the THING... oh my goodness - THE THING to call out is the plate of heaven called the LASAGNETTA. They're coils of homemade noodles cut cross-wise like little jelly roll cakes. The velvety sauce with the perfect pasta texture is sinfully addictive. We washed down all the carby goodness with the best tiramisu I've ever consumed, and I don't usually like tiramisu. The lady fingers were not oversoaked and it had a marscapone-espresso-cocoa balance.

With yummy pizzas, lasagnetta, gnocchi, and way too much tiramisu in our bellies, we left to the sounds of "Ciao Bella!" and "Buono Sera!"
author: Sharon C.

description: Delicious Italian food, for an amazing price. The decoration is just part of the experience. Definitely try the lasagnetta!
author: Adriani L.

description:
Outstanding, authentic Italian food at a reasonable expense! Went there with some friends after a hard day work. Ordered the Spaghetti Carbonata and it was excellent. We had the tiramisu for dessert and it took less that 5 minutes for us to gobble it down. 
I highly recommend Il Borgo if you're looking to re-live your last vacation to Italy!
author: Amy A.

description:
I wish I could say (for the sake of other readers) that I review objectively; that I enter every restaurant as a blank slate. However, the people I am with and the state I am in must have some effect on how I review. For clarification, by state I mean level of soberness. 

With that said, I loved IL Borgo.  Yes, I may have had two or three glasses of wine before entering this establishment.  Yes, I was with many great people and I don't see how I could not have enjoyed this place.  But yes, I did love their artichoke ravioli.  Great bread and wine selection too!

I agree with Catrinel that the ma and pa way of running things is a huge part of the appeal.  If I were like my parents and went to the same restaurant every Friday night, I could see IL Borgo as being that every Friday night type of place.  The type of place where you walk in, the servers know you by name, your favorite glass of wine is brought to you immediately, and the owner comes out and chats with you.  

The only downside is the cash only part.  But in light of all the pros of this place, this is only a minuscule con.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
If you don't know how to get what you want out of a meal at this place, then you don't know how to talk to people who make/bring out your food.  No one that works in this place has any problem conversing with you about food and helping you pick the right thing from the menu.

An effortlessly class act even when it's rammed in there with a line out on the street.

They don't take plastic, but they have an ATM machine and I'm sorry but I don't know what the fee on it is.
author: Max I.

description: Il borgo overcooks pasta and relies too much on garlic for flavor.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Everyone seems to think that North Beach is the logical choice for good Italian food and it seems like a good idea, until you actually try to find it.  I lived there (Grant/Green) and tried all kinds of places and couldn't find anything much better than Olive Garden.  It's awful, and I'll take any suggestions for something that isn't tourist-fare.

I somehow ended up at Il Borgo, which is kind of a strange place right on Fell and Laguna, yet it is wonderful.  The Pesto Gnocci is the best I've had in SF.  

Some previous reviewers mentioned that the service was bad, maybe I've been lucky but the service has always been pretty good on my visits - the men a little more gruff than the woman, but never to the point where I remembered anything bad about it.  

There are no reservations taken, so you have to kind of wait around in the middle of the (tiny) restaurant, which is kind of a drag, and the wait can be a while due to the small number of tables and most people take a good amount of time to eat and socialize.  Best to go during the week and you can probably sit right down.

Besides everything on the menu I've tried being simple and good, the wine list is mostly affordable ( under $30) bottles of wine, which is nice.

As others mentioned, it is cash only, which I always forget when I walk in there but the prices are reasonable and I always seem to squeak by with whatever I have in my pocket.  $75 for three people with a bottle of wine is a pretty good deal in this city.
author: Doug M.

description:
At first I was skeptical of our old man waiter.  I'll tell you why.  At first it seemed as if he didn't want us there BUT after we ordered a bottle of wine he came up to the table and sang us the opening verse of "THRILLER", you know, that Michael Jackson song.  I WAS SOLD!

The Prosciutto Lasagnetta is probably one of my favorite dishes in the city!  It's unbelievable.  That's probably not saying much because I'll eat anything but honestly give it a shot.
author: Justin C.

description: I was excited to try this place as a local friend took me there and said it was one of her favorites. However, at one point I almost choked on a wadded up string?! which was in my spaghetti. Yes. I showed it to the owner (?) and she just took it out of my hand without saying anything- no apology, nothing. Overall my dish was pretty mediocre, aside from the string...
author: Emylou C.

description:
La Ultima !

Basically, the best, most authentic Italian restaurant in the city.  Puts to shame most of the N. Beach eateries....so if you can give up the N. Beach n'hood charm for something a little more mellow, just go here.

Family run...mom, dad, and son work the kitchen and tables most nights...occasionally, crazy uncle gets pressed into action as well (you'll KNOW him when you see him, trust me...)

Great for a romantic dinner for two as well as larger groups at the bench/booth tables.

this corner has come up since the offramp was (thankfully, finally) demolished...although, I gotta say, as I started coming here the first week it opened....there WAS something kinda thrilling about sitting at the window while 101 N traffic, headlights and all,  came hurtling directly at your table at 50 mph...ah, the good ol' days.

Great menu, awesome homemade pastas and pizzas...wonderful fish, too.  Kitchen is also very good at doing special orders/requests.   Often a complimentary grappa afterwards....nice.

Only downside/criticism:  menu has not changed in years and years...amici, you could add in some new specials every now and then, si ?

Go, indulge, be gluttonous...stumble home......
author: El K.

description:
One word: Homemadepasta! Went there the other night. The service was perfect, its a cute little place and the food was amazing. Their pasta was really the best I have had ever. Cash only tho.

Just go
author: Michael S.

description:
I've gone here twice and coincidentally with a group of four each time.  This place is quaintly nestled in the heart of Hayes Valley and its romantic setting is great for a first date.  The decor is cozy and has a rustic feel to it.  The walls are painted with murals reminiscent of Italia.  The hostess/waitress was very sweet and greeted us with Italian phrases.  The place seemed as if it was operated by the whole family.  Although, I don't know for sure... it seemed that way.  

The second time around I ordered the Fettuccine Del Borgo which consisted of homemade pasta with prosciutto, peas and capers.  I asked our waitress if it was possible to add mushrooms to the dish.  Her reply: "We can add anything for you here".  Now, that's what I'm talkin' about!  Accommodation!!!  The dish was great; a creamy sauce with flat thick sliced fettuccine.  However... the dish contained too many peas.  It seemed as if they put a whole can of peas in the dish.  The pea to fettuccine ratio was pretty high.  Despite the delta... I'd go there again.  

Moderately priced, great customer service, warm/romantic atmosphere and yummy food!
author: Melissa M.

description:
I made reservations for my husband and I for dinner on Friday night at 6:30 just an hour or so before the time. We walked in and we ere seated right away in a cozy little table for 2. We had waters within minutes, bread shortly after, and ordered our food in a timely manner. 

I ordered the lobster ravioli and my husband got the lasagnetta. Both were fantastic. My husband said the lasagnetta was the best lasagna he had ever had and would go back everyday if it was up to him. It appeared to be lasagna rolled up and then sliced with lots of cheeses inside and out. We had two cappuccinos for dessert. They had homemade tarimessou that looked amazing but I passed because I was so full. I had a glass of house Chianti too.  

$50 bucks for the whole meal and ate in under an hour!
author: Caroline F.

description: Best Tiramisu in San Francisco. Riiiich pasta! Quiet, cheerful, friendly. xo
author: Dom B.

description: Had dinner there last night.  I had the spaghetti pomodoro and my wife had the ravioli stuffed with artichokes.  We almost walked by this place.  I'm sure glad we stopped here.  The food and the service were superb!  I'm already looking forward to our next visit!
author: Ron L.

description:
Il Borgo holds a special place in my heart.  I fell in love with it, I want to say in late 2001 / early 2002, and the rest is history.  My favorites are the Lasagnetta, Pasta Primavera, and their Tiramisu.  Love.  While sometimes the service can be spotty, I never seem to mind that much.  I think perhaps it's because I know it will be an awesome meal.

So yeah, go, enjoy a fantastic meal that wont break the bank, don't mind the service, and whatever you do, do NOT leave without an order of tiramisu!
author: Kelly K.

description: Needed to find an Italian restaurant in the area so checked my handy Yelp application on the Ipod and found Il Borgo. Reasonable pricing. Delicious food. Cozy atmoshere and charming service. Definitely try the Vegetarian Lasagna.
author: Heather L.

description:
I like this place, I really do.  The "ma & pa" way of running it is what keeps me coming back.  I've had several nice dining experiences with friends where we all walked away full and happy.  

My roommate LOVES the lasagnetta and having tried it myself I can totally see why!

I like to order the 4 seasons pizza as I sometimes need to fulfill my need for a wood burning oven pizza.  The layout of this 4 ingredient pizza (artichokes, olives, prosciutto and mushrooms) is quite interesting.  The toppings are not scattered evenly across the surface of the pizza but rather are divided in 4 parts meaning 2 slices are just mushroom, 2 with olives etc etc...  At first I was confused by this and thought what if I kindly ask for my toppings to be evenly put on the pizza...I've opted out and figure I won't mess with the chef.

Please note that Il Borgo is cash only, but there is an ATM inside of it if you do forget the green stuff.
author: Catrinel A.

description: Came back here with some friends and had the same great experience!  They even gave us some complimentary grappa!  =)
author: Hui C.

description:
The most un-assuming (bordering on camoflauged) italian cafe which I walked by for almost an entire year before finally venturing a try on a monday night when everything else seemed to be closed. 

My expectations were low . . . 
but wow, did they ever get exceeded.

The food is outstanding and nothing on the menu is over $20. 

This place appears to be the real deal . . . it is family run (I'm pretty sure they are all from southern italy) and they make their own pasta.

The veal saltimbocca will melt your soul.

Once upon a time you never had to worry about getting a table which is still the case on week-nights but friday or saturday nights are now pretty brutal.

This is a great place to bring a date (on a weeknight).
author: Carlos C.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMMMM. Oh my god, I love this place. It's quaint, cute, kitschy, and the food is out of this world. You walk in and if you're lucky, you get a table. I've tried a few times to go there and decided not to wait cause all the tables were full. No reservations allowed. That makes me like a place even more. 

So last night Paul and I go there and have dinner, we walk in and the charming italian waitress tells us to sit anywhere and then brings over this delicious homemade bread. We order a salad, the dressing is so garlicky it's like heaven on a plate.

Paul ordered some pasta dish and I ordered some chicken dish, and they were both so sublimely good, I can't even remember what they were, but we both finished them.

And for a place with no reservations, they don't rush you out. Enjoy the food, enjoy the ambiance and feel like maybe you've stepped into a little piece of italy, cause this is not one of those modern, slick, stylized italian restaurants that ends with INA like in the mission. This is some damn good, home made italian food.

Thank you Il Borgo, thank you!
author: jason m.

description:
The lady that works here is a b*tch.

My dad and I were looking for a place to eat and decided to give this place a try.  Right off the bat, the cash only part was annoying and them conveniently having an ATM inside just seemed like a cheap way to swindle you out of a few extra bucks.  It is SF and most places are cash only, so that's fine.  We sat down and looked at the menu.  After about two minutes of sitting in a nearly empty restaurant, the lady starts rushing us to order our food. She then laughs at my dad because he didn't pronounce the name of his dish perfectly.  Then she laughed at us because we weren't able to hear her from across this counter that she insisted on standing behind while taking our order and asking us questions.  When we asked her what was so funny she complained that she had to ask us everything 3 times before we understood here.  I responded that maybe she should walk over to our table so that we could hear her.  We then decided to leave and I will never ever go back and support this cheeseball looking Italian restaurant.
author: Aaron L.

description:
I never think about coming to this place even though I drive by it everyday.  For some reason, it gives off that cheesy 'little Italy' restaurant vibe - you know the type of restaurant in NYC or SF that cater to tourists who want the Italian experience.  The walls are painted to resemble a rustic village of sorts...Yes, there is actually 'faux' laundry hanging on a string in the dining room.  

But don't let that fool you, because the food is so very delicious.  I went there with some friends after hitting some bars in Hayes.  First of all, the bread was heaven - I don't know if they bake it there or what.  The fettuccine bolognese  - some of the best I've had.  Pasta was perfectly adente.   And the portions are huge and you can't beat the prices.  I probably had more processed carbs that night than I have in a week, but it was well worth it.  

The service was ok.  The host was somewhat indifferent.
author: Eric C.

description:
I've seen this place for years while heading up Fell and I was surprised to see the high marks on Yelp. Could I really have missed this great of a place after all these years?

The restaurant is located on the outskirts of the nicer part of Hayes Valley and parking is typical for the 'hood. The interior is decorated in a standard cheesy italian grotto scheme which instantly made my scepticism alarm go off. Our party of 6 sat right in the middle of restaurant (as it should be for any birthday) and then off we went with ordering. Menu? Standard italian (american) dishes. 

Ordered? Margherita pizza appetizer. Lobster Ravioli. Spaghetti Bolognese. Penne E Funghi Salsiccie (mushroom and sausage). Grilled chicken entree. Forgot the rest. Overall, the food was decent and the penne dish was very good. Was not a fan of the overly fishy lobster ravioli (mush?) or the bolognese - think noodles and meat lacking any hint of a flavored tomato sauce. 

While food was sufficiently satisfying (portions and flavors) I was left disappointed overall because of the terrible service. Yes, every table was full. Yes, she was working alone. Not my problem... especially if I catch you swigging a glass of wine behind the counter doodling on paper.  It took her over 30 min. to just take our order (thank God we were all just chatting it up) and even longer to make refills, take additional orders or even get us a starter basket of bread. She also had the audacity to moderately complain about all are ordering asking us to consolidate our needs because she was the only one working. WTF!?! Oh, and its cash only and she does all the checks by hand. 

The place has decent food but put it this way, after walking out of the restaurant and strolling down the block, I saw two other places I would have rather visited. At least it's something to check off the list.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Good simple neighborhood Italian. Cozy, tasty, well priced. Good for a simple date on a cold evening. Would recommend to others and will go back again.
author: White K.

description:
Consistently tasty and authentic.
Who knew Hayes Valley could do Italian?

My recommendations:
Raddicchio salad (a la Borgo)
Saltimbocca
author: Chris M.

description: This place is a cheap-o Italian place, which I like.  It's not bad for cheap-o Italian, but unfortunately there are better, similar places nearby that I'd rather eat at if I had to pick a place around Hayes Valley.
author: Erika C.

description:
I used to live in the hood and this was one of my favorites.  For the mix of price, authenticity, and maximum deliciousness it get 5 stars.  

It's really a home-y place with no scene... Just normal people.  No frills, friendly owners, it can be quirky but that's the charm.

My favorites are the sausage mushroom pizza, carbonara, and artichoke ravioli (home made)
author: suckafree c.

description:
What a neighborhood gem - and an easy walk (in daylight) to Davies Symphony Hall.   Lovely caprese, lobster ravioli and spaghetti carbonara.  Easy in and out in less than an hour.
We'll return.
author: Nancy L.

description:
I really love the fettuccine primavera here. The noodles were the really wide, chewy kind and the sauce was perfect. I know I should try something else, but I just can't bring myself to do it. My boyfriend really likes the arrabiata sauce though. 

As for the atmosphere, what can I say? Very Lady and the Tramp sharing one noodle kind of thing. Nook-y, lit predominately with those candles stuck on top of a wine bottle. 

I also like the proprietor. My friends and I came in one night 15 minutes before closing and he didn't give us any shit about staying so long, although the poor man did seem relieved to see us go. A good moderately priced date place. If you go once before and make a little effort to talk to the owner, when you bring your date, you can excuse the not-outrageously-expensiveness of the place by saying you discovered this "little hidden gem" years ago and just love it.
author: Grace C.

description:
After a few years of driving by and mostly not noticing this place, I read the reviews and decided to take my husband here for dinner tonight.  After a too-long nap and getting ready session, we checked nextbus.org per a talk thread a few days ago, and realized we had only two minutes before the next 21 Hayes passed us by.   I grabbed my keys and unplugged my various hair straightening devices, and off we went.  It took us a good minute and a half to get out and a block over to the bus stop, and the bus was rolling down the street right on time.  This nextbus thing is priceless!  So, we got to Il Borgo and were sat right away, although they put us at a two-top right in the middle of the small room.  I don't like that; I feel put on display when I'm not on the perimeter, and there was a table for two available, though maybe it was reserved...don't know.  

Our waiter was a middle-aged Italian guy, he seemed pretty authentically Italian.  He brought a loaf of nice soft crusty bread, but it was cold and it would have been nice it they'd given us the illusion that it was just baked by serving it warm.  It was still yummy though.  There was nothing to spread onto our bread or dip it into, although after looking around at other tables, I saw that we just seemed to be missing our olive oil and balsamic vinegar, and their accompanying dipping dish.  I stealthily stole these accoutrements from the empty table next to us and  we devoured the entire loaf over the course of our meal.  

I had the artichoke ravioli which was really amazing, and my Irish husband had the Spaghetti Carbonara, which he said tasted just like his Mom used to make.  Incidentally, I tried to make the same dish for him a few years ago, spaghetti, cream, and bacon, and he did not like it.  At all.  So, we were pretty impressed.  They didn't offer a list of by-the-glass wine, which was unfortunate.  We both got glasses without knowing how much they were and would have been better off getting a bottle to split pricewise.  

Our waiter took a bit too long to bring our check, and I paid in cash and he brought weird change, so that I had to either leave a tip that was either a buck too small or a couple of bucks too much.  I went for too much, because although he was slow, he was a sweetheart and I think we'll be going back to this place.  Hopefully next time he'll seat us on the perimeter of this great little space.
author: kelly m.

description: Excellent Italian food... all homemade. I highly recommend this place. The artichoke ravioli in marinara was exquisite.
author: Alex G.

description: Very nice homey Italian restaurant. Highly recommend the Lasagna and Alfredo. It's a nice little date spot. Although, if planning on coming by car, be warned that there is limited street parking in the area and it make take a little while.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Is Il Borgo a world-class, five-star jaw dropper? No, but this little Italian joint is well worth the trip for several reasons.

1) The price is just right for a very tasty selection
2) Service is on point.
3) Cheap corkage fees
4) Nice, quaint, quiet ambience

So the service was a tiny bit behind, but managed well. The owner was very involved and so was the service. To the point that when our water was left empty for a short time, a complimentary glass of wine was poured without question...to five of us.

The antipasto was good, the Chicken Saltimbocca (though I am not a big chicken person) was actually quite impressive in and had very good flavor throughout every bite. The veggies served with the entreés were fairly vanilla, but were fresh and well prepared. Another dish I had a few bites from were my buddy's lamb chops. Wow, were they great! The tiramisu was very soft, fluffy and just right after dinner.
author: Michael M.

description:
Best Italian food in Hayes Valley! Very reasonable prices!!

I've been here on multiple occasions and always leave full, satisfied and with extras for take-home. Wait staff is not always polite, but the food is fantastic with a home-style flavor. That means that everything is really tasty, heavy and the pastas are fresh, but it can't be very good for you. 

If you have the space in your stomach, give it a shot!
author: Nick V.

description:
The food is tasty. The staff is friendly. It is not pretentious in the slightest.  As everyone says, the lasagnetta was amazing. 
They gave us free champagne at the end of dinner. Who could ask for more?
I hate tira misu. . but i love theirs!
author: Ryen A.

description:
It may be the awesome yet affordable wine list, the cozy ambiance, the kick- ass home made pasta, or very possibly the complimentary champagne and tiramisu the owner often bestows upon us, but this is one of my favorite places to eat in the city.  I can't seem to get away from their Fettuccine del Borgo, although I have tasted dinner companion's lasagnetta, gnocchi pesto, and lobster ravioli and all were very good. The salads are a bit boring (just lettuce and dressing) but not a bad start to the meal if that's what you're going for.  (I prefer the antipasto. . although I'm pretty sure I could live off of prosciutto and olives for quite some time.) The tiramisu is HANDS DOWN the best I've ever had.  Creamy, melt in your mouth, and (usually) free! What more could a girl ask for? 

Yes, it's cash only and that sucks. SUCKS! But they do have an ATM inside just in case you forget. Make a reservation, swing by Wamu, and gorge yourself on some of the best Italian food in the city.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Let's start with the plus and minuses... 

Plus: 
-Cozy, intimate setting (this is a charming place, feels like one of those tiny and super cute Italian restaurants on a side street in Italy)
-Charming hostess (she looks like the owner) who speaks to me in Italian, though I don't speak the language, very charming though 
-Cheap and wonderful wine. A bottle of chianti goes for only $25! 
-Lobster ravioli was tasty and not overwhelming. 

Minuses:
-Bad spaghetti carbonara (seriously, I know this is a difficult dish to perfect, but still, I've had  a lot better)
-Carpaccio is only so-so, a disappointment, since I was expecting better.
-Cash only. Man, this is such a bummer-I want to earn my frequent flyer miles with my credit card!
author: Selena L.

description:
Il Borgo is a tiny, adorable, delicious Italian restaurant. All of their pasta is homemade and completely amazing. They are owned by a husband and wife (if I'm not mistaken-he cooks and she waits tables) so sometimes service is slow-ish, but I usually chalk that up to the fact that Americans have a tendency to eat really quickly and they aren't used to that. 
But anyway, back to the pasta.
They definitely excel in pasta-making. They have this linguine with prosciutto, peas, and cream sauce that literally makes me moan with pleasure while I eat it.
In fact, I plan on going and eating some more pleasure pasta tonight.
Mmmmmmmm.
author: Steffany F.

description: I made a reservation for dinner on their website and received a confirmation. When I realized that I needed to change the time I called them and they accepted the change. When my party and I arrived they had no record of the reservation. They put us at a cramped table and were quite curt towards us. Then they rushed us through dinner. The food was ok though the vegetables were overcooked and the presentation was lacking. I will not be returning.
author: Sherry G.

description:
I met a beautiful blonde while dining here the other night.

It's name was Birra Menabrea, a delicious Italian Blonde (bionda) beer.  It's a great beer I've never tasted before let alone seen available anywhere else.  I like how it is also the ONLY beer served at this restaurant.  I realize this belies my dogma that promotes beer variety, but I'll let that slide based on the quality and originality of the offering.

The staff here can be a little gruff.  Upon entering, a guy who I believe was the owner, just sort of stared at us.  I offered "two, please" and he promptly seated us.  He seemed a little sarcastic at times in his responses, but I took it more as humor than contempt.  Additionally one of the other waiters wasn't very good at English which made requesting dessert a little awkward.

Despite this, the food was rather good.  This place is a neighborhood Italian joint and rightfuly so, just about everything is homemade.  The sausage and mushroom penne was delicious.  My notoriously picky sister thought the lobster raviloli was top notch, as well.  The food arrived within about 10 - 12 minutes of us ordering it, although I think we got lucky since we got here closer to 9pm.  We took a homemade tiramisu to go and massacred it, an excellent blend of coffee and cream flavor.

I was pretty uncertain about this joint as I had heard mixed reviews.  While I don't find the food to be the best, it's great being only 2 blocks away and a place at which I will likely entertain more guests.
Now if only Fell St. wasn't so steep...
author: Steven R.

description:
I am not a huge fan of this place, even though i'd like to be as it's right around the corner from my flat.  

First let me say that the Lasagnetta is amazing.  Hands down my favourite Italian dish that i've had anywhere.  

But the service is the reason i'm only giving 3 stars.  the service is so spotty depending on the mood of the lady ( I don't know her name but she's probably in a bad mood because her husband, the other owner, is such a womanizer).  She treated me and my friends like we were putting her out just by being there.  And no they weren't that busy.  

The decor is cheeky cute with faux painted italian scenes complete with a clothesline and wall sconces.  If you go there with hot girls and the men are working they'll invite you down to the basement for some free grappa and dancing.  
The last time I was there left a bad taste in my mouth - I don't think i'll be visiting them again any time soon.
author: ashton c.

description:
My old roommate Chris M. took me here one evening for dinner and recommended the Raddicchio salad and the Saltimbocca. Both were very enjoyable.

I just noticed his prior review and I quote:

"My recommendations:
Raddicchio salad (a la Borgo)
Saltimbocca"

Not feeling very adventurous Chris?
author: Joe D.

description: We ate some great Italian food here.  The Carbonara pasta was delicious.  There was a car accident nearby that the owner was very concerned with while we were eating.  We were the only people in the restaurant and the room was filled with police lights.  Our waitress poured us extra wine as she was afraid she was making us nervous.  A great San Francisco dining experience.
author: Guy D.

description: I ordered the Penne alla Puttanesca, which comes with Tomatoes, anchovies, olives, capers.  We paired that with a Barbera.  Both were very good.  The pasta was somewhat salty, which is what I was going for.  The wine went well with the pasta.  The prices were reasonable (around $24 each - the pasta was roughly $12 and the wine was $23), the atmosphere was quaint.  We will definitely be coming back.
author: Anne Marie F.

description:
Very  yummy Italian that's not she-she, is low key and is a great overall value. The first time my girlfriend and I ate there I had the lobster ravioli that was simply  delish. 

I enjoyed another meal there again last night  and started off with the the inslata mista followed by the uccelli scappati (chicken). The salad dressing was great, very flavorful with lots of yummy raw garlic and the greens were fresh, a solid overall combination. The chicken was good but I found it to be a bit too salty, my gf found it to be a bit salty for her taste as well. 

I would have rated the restaurant five stars but the overly salty chicken took it down a notch. The service is stellar, not too overbearing but very attentive and fun to talk with. I'll definitely be back.

BTW my gf is an Italofile, lived in Italy and knows her Italian food! She likes Il Borgo as much as me.
author: Sam T.

description:
Il borgo..more like il crappo... what a RIP OFF! I would like this place to be gone and replaced by a used car dealership.  Summary:  The food is plain and really heavy on the carbs, the service is annoying... It is a sit down dinner restaurant that DOESN'T TAKE CARD!!!!    They have an atm that charges a fee in the restaurant.  This is a petty trick you encounter in pizza parlors, not something  for atmospheric urban dinner restaurants. 

The food is really awful.  We ordered the eggplant fussili, and got a ridiculous amount of pasta that totally ruined the continuity of the sauce...making what would have been a plain dish HUGE and BAD.  Our second dish was the lobster ravioli which came out moderately cold and just as bad....absolutely plain.  What they lack in quality, they try to make up for in volume....20 big bright orange plain pasta cubes isn't better than 6 good hot ravioli.  The bread was the best part of the meal, and I give it a 5 out of 10.  A glass of average pinot rings in at almost $7(the price isnt even listed on the menu) 

The place seems inexpensive, but our ticket for 2 came in at $40 after tip and tax...I could have gotten a MUCH better meal for that price, and had dessert, too.  Also, the waiter really pissed me off.

Bottom line--don't go here, the atmosphere belies the food, which SUCKS.  I feel really ripped off and somewhat deceived right now, and I might just cry.  8-(
author: Frank S.

description:
Decorated in goofy Italian kitsch with street scenes painted on the walls and stuff (you know, the classic "you're indoors, but it looks like you're outdoors" theme).  Chianti bottles sporting years dripped candlewax adorn the tables.

And the food.. so so so good.  I *heart* the freshly made pastas.  I mean, I know fresh pasta tastes better than that dried stuff, but at Il Borgo you really are given good evidence of that fact.  The carbonara is awesome, and the lasagna is also one of my favorites..

Ok.. updated since I've been back a few more times.. Il Borgo continues to delight.. sooo tasty!!
author: Dennis Y.

description:
Great place to go pre-theater for Golden Gate & Orpheum - close driving distance, reasonably priced, very good food, cozy atmosphere and good for kids!

Pizza was delicious and the ravioli, salmon pasta, and lasangetta was good and huge portions.

One of the best places for tiramisu!

Very attentive staff at half full...surprisingly enough.
author: Wanda L.

description:
Very very tasty Northern Italian cuisine and I would strongly suggest the Lasagnetta as your main dish along with the caprese as an app.  

The decor is also very nice and cozy.  It's first come first serve on snatching up a table and it obviously tends to get busy on the weekends but well worth the wait.
author: David C.

description: I love to share the antipasto plate and the fettuccine bolognese with a nice glass of chianti.
author: Leigh D.

description:
I gave Il Borgo a pass a few months ago. No more.

The owner (?) is senile.  To make a very long story short, he promised me a table, and then gave it to someone else.  

2 groups of people saw this and commented to me that the guy is a complete loser.  No doubt.
author: Tim G.

description:
One of the highlights of my week was dinner at Il Borgo tonight.

The waitress couldn't have been kinder or had better timing.

The interior is charming and very cozy for this frosty weather.

I had Lobster ravioli. They were delicious and perfectly al dente ("to the bite," as Giada would say!)  The bread and olive oil / balsamic was also lovely.  The house Chianti made me perfectly buzzy and fuzzy wuzzy too. Warm, full of food, and fuzzy wuzzy, I went off to sing in my chorus.  I'll try to stop by again when I have time before rehearsal.

I will say it wasn't a cheap place, so be careful. They also only take cash.  But that did not stop the place from being fully crowded (but still cozy and peaceful) by the time I was finished dining!

Thank you for making my week, Il Borgo!  BACI !!!
author: Aaron W.

description:
Although I have only been here once, I plan to return again and again.  It is a place I went to a couple of weeks ago and I can't stop thinking about the saltimbocca (sp?) super good, with steamed broccoli and accurately salted rosemary potatoes.  
My friend had a wonderful house made pasta with a cream sauce and English peas, yum-o! ;0) 
It is a place you can take your parents and it will remind them of the old neighborhood Italian restaurants THEY used to take you too,  except this one is waaaaaay better.  I waited far too long to try this place as I've lived around the corner for 6 years!
*P.S. Each table comes complete with the dripping Chianti candles. Nice...
author: Suzanne L.

description:
I knew I was in for a yummy meal even before I stepped inside Il Borgo. 

While awaiting my friend's arrival, I sat myself on the stoop leading to Il Borgo's kitchen and was instantly intoxicated by the sweet smell of Italian dishes sneaking out from the iron-gated window above. 

You see, I grew up with my Italian grandmother who spent *all day* making sauce from scratch, into which she'd put her handmade meatballs, pork loin and sausages to saute for hours. So, when it comes to Italian restaurants I am frequently disappointed.

But Il Borgo did not disappoint. Everything--from the warmth of our server (an attentive, efficient and kind Italian woman who genuinely referred to me and my friend as "signorinas" throughout the meal), to the hearty red wine, to the perfectly cooked salmon and potatoes with rosemary (and my friend's luscious lasagna with prosciutto)--was supremely satisfying.

And one more thing: it's so nice to find a restaurant in San Francisco where I don't have to yell over loud, lyric-less beats or the conversations of other tables. What's up, SF acoustics?
author: franny p.

description:
I've had the pleasure of two dinners at Il Borgo in the past 4 months or so.  This little unpretentious restaurant is in my neighborhood, but both times I've gone was with friends from other parts of the city who suggested we go there.  

Let me just say thanks to those friends.  Will you have the most avant garde meal at Il Borgo?  No.  Will you have a relaxed, enjoyable meal with good food and an amusingly surly waitstaff?  Yes, most definitely. 

The first time I went with my friends, our waiter kept bringing us alcohol to try.  I suspect he was flirting with my female companions, but he had us try grappa and some of the house port wine.  Then, at the end of our meal, he brought us tiramisu on the house.  Of course, we more than made up for it with the tip, but it was such a surprise from this semi-gruff man who we were convinced hated us.  Not so.  

He just wasn't putting on airs.  And that's Il Borgo for you.  No pretention.  Just a good saltimbocca and a delicious antipasti dish.

The next time you're craving some classic Italian fare and can't stand the trek to North Beach, head over to Hayes Valley and step into Il Borgo.
author: Todd X.

description:
This is pretty much the place I picture in that Billy Joel tune....oh, man, the wax laden wine bottles, tiny cramped tables (unless you snag one of the boothes), the elder statesman and his (?) wife runnign the place on alternate nights....you rush in from the cold and it's warm and so so inviting.  I missed having a neighborhood Italian place for so long (Incanto is great but too "upscale" to fit the bill here).

I've stuck to the excellent pastas (artichoke ravioli, gnocchi) and pizza (quatro stagioni (sp)) but recently ventured into the non carb world (very unlike me) and got the grilled salmon.

"Medium rare please" I kinda admonished, I admit.  I expected well overdone and over oiled salmon and thought "why'd i do this?" till it arrived at the table - beautifully cooked, it almost looked like a piece of seared sashimi.  YUM.  Not over sauced.  And served up with 4 spears of tasty rosemary crusted potato (I wish they were even crispier) and some decadent but not overly so buttery broccoli w/a light dusting of a crisp cheese.  Much more restraint t han I ever would imagine.  

So happy to branch out.  Oh yeah, the pizza is still solid  - not life giving, just good.

Lastly, the carpaccio is EXCELLENT.  Very tender well seasoned meat made even better by the accoutrements of capers, lemon, shaved parm and s&p.  

A meal here will set you back about $30 per person.  I agree w/the reviewer who said "BYOB".  Corkage is about $10 or $15.  2 red/2 whites by the glass, both forgettable, one beer and a limited and unexciting wine by the bottle list.
author: Laurie A.

description:
Amazing Italian food at reasonable prices.  A huge fresco, and the crowds aren't bad.  

I don't know who the host was - he wasn't the owner - but anyone who stands by my table telling me and my dining companion racist jokes is a winner in my book.

I drove by this place coming off the old Fell Street ramp all the time and I drive past it now, and all these years I'd wondered about it.  Well, I wonder no more, and I implore the rest of you to keep this place a highly visible secret.
author: Frankie D.

description: My favorite Italian place in the city!!  Some of the best food I have ever had.  And if your charming to the lady working there, she might take a shot of grappa with you, on the house!
author: Jason D.

description:
I finally found it!!!!!!!
I've been hoping to find an italian restaurant that makes me feel at home. Here it is. Random corner in the Hayes Valley, a place that I've known to be there for a while but never set my foot in there. But I'm SO GLAD that I went and I will be going back very often.

The decor was very cute, casual, but nice enough that we all thought would be a great 1st date spot. Just like the location, things here are just random, the random street lamp standing there right in front of you once you step in, random but artsy candles with melted wax, GORGEOUS italian lady (waitress? wife of the owner?). 

Food. Yes. Yes. 
Hands down Best dish: Fettucine del Borgo, with sundried tomatoes, capers, and tomate sauce. Very simple, but sooooo delicious, with generous portion. The homemade Fettucine is just perfect in texture, not too soggy, not too tough, just the right right amount of chewiness that you just can't stop eating it. Sundried tomato adds the proper greasiness but finely balanced out by the sourness of capers. Such a great dish for only $13.

Highly recommended by people: Lobster Ravioli.
The sauce is so good, especially with the bread. Our plate was so clean that it looked like someone licked it clean. The ravioli are great, but the whole dish is a little too straight forward (nothing else besides ravioli and sauce). But it's what you get and what you expect in home cooking. So I still think it's great.

Bruschetta was fresh, with very crunchy toasted bread. But I could make better Bruschestta.

Last but not least, the Tiramisu'. If you don't the Tiramisu' here after your meal, you are missing out, your experience would not be complete. The Tiramisu' is SOOOOO GOOOOOOOD!!!!! It is indeed the only one I've tried in US that I've felt: wow!! it's better than the ones I made!! Get it, period.

To the lady who works there: I wish I could be as gorgeous as you are at your age.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I went here for my birthday dinner -- super intimate, great food, and warm staff. I felt like I was in an authentic Italian kitchen the entire time.

Everyone loved their order! Great portions, highly recommend the Chicken Marsala.

Only con to this place is that it's cash only -- but there is an ATM in the restaurant.
author: Torie F.

description:
Every neighborhood needs a good small Italian restaurant. This is mine. The prices are very reasonable. You can do a good dinner for two and a bottle of wine for around $50-60. It's a small restaurant, perhaps 15 tables. If you ask the wait staff about a dish they are probably the ones who prepped it earlier that day. The inside is made up to look like a Italian villa, complete with a clothesline and an awning (indoors). It is a romantic place, complete with checkered tablecloths and those candles made from wine bottles with the wax drippings coating the bottle. Think Lady & The Tramp without the dogs. 

The only downside is that it can get quite hot in there. The gear from the kitchen can make it rather warm.  Probably not the best place to go on a hot summer night.

Highly recommended for the overall combo of value, food, and atmosphere.  Definitely not high brow. Think more cutesy.
author: A A.

description:
Stumbled upon this place and so glad we did.  The waitress was beyond sweet and so genuine.  Service was FANTASTIC.

I ordered gnocchi and my friend ate fusilli with mozzarella and eggplant.  Both dishes were delicious, tasting very authentic.  Wine was also tasty.

Very reasonable prices.  Will DEFINITELY go back!
author: Margaret H.

description:
Exactly what a local family-style Italian restaurant should be...

Il Borgo is friendly, affordable, tasty, and most importantly... Cozy. Oh so cozy. I keep hearing and reading mixed reviews of this place, but it is what it is.

I believe the attractive middle aged Italian woman runs and/or owns the place. Just ask her what to eat, order a bottle of the house wine, and have a relaxing meal.
author: Trey F.

description: Cute environment! The lassagnetta was absolutely delicious!! Try the lobster ravioli too! :)
author: Leyna T.

description: Just simply a lovely italian restaurant that reminds me of the real trattoria that you would find in Italy...nothing's complicated but straight to the point. Food is family style with fresh home made pasta...and I love these home made pastas! The decor is deliciously typical of traditional italian places with murals that transport you to Italy and make you forget for a couple of hours that you are in busy San Francisco...but better than everything else: the whole family who owns the place is Italian. The lady who owns the place is just super nice and speaks with a lovely italian accent and the younger guy even rides Ducati...could not beat that as far as italian goes... Just simply love it and will be back!
author: Alexandra G.

description:
Took my mom and my sister there for dinner -- we each got a pasta dish and shared.

Mom got gnocci with gorganzola cream sauce.  The gnocci was great -- fluffy and delish.  I thought the gorganzola sauce was a little overpowering .  I love blue cheese, but this was a little too much.  Of course, we devoured it, anyway. 

I got penne with sausage tomato sauce, which was hearty and delicious.  The penne was al dente and the sausage savory.  

The real star was the lasagnetti (or something -- d'oh, I might be misnaming this thing) that my sister got.  It was homemade lasagna noodles, cooked and rolled together with cheese and sliced, so she got a plate full of delicious spirals of pasta and chese -- presented kind of like a bunch of cinammon buns.

The sauce was a decadent tomato cream sauce.  

My sister gloated and we shamelessly stole bites from her.

The wine list is short, but we had a lovely chianti and a lovely time.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
I see this quaint, little Italian joint every time I'm dead-tired in a cab on the way back home from the airport. And every time i say to myself 'that place looks cozy, i should go there.' And then I forget about it because I don't usually find myself near Fell @ Laguna. But location might be the only strike against Il Borgo.

J and I stumbled in one night when the wait at Suppenkuche was too much to bear. And we were glad we did.

The cozy, open room with rustic, yet tacky Italian decor was warm and inviting. Being two bottles deep when we got there only made it warmer.

I have to say the food rivaled that of North Beach, save a few of my fave places (more specifically, L'Osteria del Forno and Sodini's). I had the Rigatoni alla Matricianna- pancetta, white onion, tomato and white wine; J had the Fettucine Del Borgo- homemade pasta with sundried tomatoes, chicken and capers. Pretty standard Italian fare. Which, in this case, isn't a bad thing.
author: Billy L.

description: Check your total. She already adds gratuity. She hand writes tickets so you can't read it. The total doesn't add up. She applied a 5% tip before I even paid even though there were only 2 of us.  Nearly the worst carbonara I've ever had. Pizza was virtually flavorless. For an Italian restaurant the last place to save money is on Italian herbs. Had I not known I was supposedly eating Italian, I would have never known. Lesson to myself... If the restaurant is empty there is probably a good reason.
author: Adam H.

description:
tried the lobster ravioli - delicious! 
the pasta is all made daily  :)
and i have to say the tiramisu (my favorite dessert) FABULOUS!
author: Miharu Y.

description: Cozy atmosphere and well worth the 30 minutes or so for a table.  Food was delicious - simple, but very authentic.  Our waitress (who was everyone's waitress) was fun, spoke Italian (and French) with us, and provided excellent service.  I'd go back in a second, and highly recommend it if you are looking for something more quaint vs. trendy.
author: Josh G.

description: I love this place, the food tastes really good. Its all homemade pasta. I always get the pasta & chicken with cream sauce. My husband get the gnocchi gorgonzola, its outstanding. I come here most of the time especially on my birthday and other occasions. Perfect  place to celebrate with my husband and son, and the service very attentive, I highly recommend this place.
author: Maria I.

description: Magical! Enter through the plain front door from the middle of Hayes Valley, and suddenly, you're surrounded by Italian murals, dim lights, drippy candles, and warm tables for two or four. The service all times I've been there is friendly and attentive; the pasta is homemade and delicious! Gentle pieces of pasta drenched in homemade sauce.  Mmm! Prices are moderate, but be prepared: it's cash only! Be sure to try their Lasagnetta and their Tiramisu. Both are outstanding. You can't go wrong at this divine, romantic spot!
author: Heather S.

description:
Quick review, but not as funny:
"When the gnocci hit my mouth, it felt like I was chewing three hour old bubble gum.  Yeah.  No kidding.  I even used the description that the texture was like toothpaste."

Funny review, but not as quick.:
I always give a place a second chance.   But with my brooding and teeming secret glee I will regale you with my first review of something that is .. well.. just simply... umm.. terrible.  I mean... ugh.

A Thursday night on Laguna and Fell; as a restaurant you might conceive it to be a potentially busy night.  Busy enough... so that one might find a modicum of a challenge in getting any service *at all*  They staffed two... that is DEUX, DOS, etc ... twice as many as one, half as many as there should of been.... people.  

There was a sweet, but mindlessly distant owner-type... fancying cocktails on a beach somewhere in the backwaters of her mind... as she couldn't force herself to pay attention to the fact that the poor dishwasher preparing every single meal for every single table was panicking and, in a word, melting down like a trainwreck.

Oh.. I mixed my metaphors, but you should have seen what this cat did to the food.  It was like... fusion.  Like really fusion.. Not the good kind.

She recommended the bolognese... and it tasted like... you know air that is sort of musty and smoggy... if that air had substantive taste, mass, and surface area... it would have tasted like that.

But the gnocci???  I am not sre if he A) took them a previous meal three days ago or B) cooked them in a high powered dishwasher.

When the gnocci hit my mouth, it felt like I was chewing three hour old bubble gum.  Yeah.  No shit.  I even used the description that the texture was like toothpaste.

I like to think that I am an unpretensious foodie... and I feel the need to 'splain something.  I have *never* sent a dish back.  I cannot remember *ever* not eating a dish, even when it was completely wrong.  I am easy going, and I am friendly, and I have worked fine dining and low dining enough to know that it isn't always one person's fault.... you have to spit in my food in front of me to get me to tip less than 20%.

The service took... FOREVER.  Like... 45 minutes to get bread and water on the table.  The place was quaint, but I am only saying that because this place has an absence of service, skill, and flavour enough to go around.

I mean... don't waste your time.  I am putting the description of the gnocci at the top as well... so when you get hear you realize that by reading that at the beginning, you are actually in the future, or something like a Tarantino film coming back around... and if the restaurant review doesn't work for you, well.. at least it was fun.

And I saw Thievery Corporation that night.  That was a fine ole time, methinks.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Family style Italian dining is my favorite type of meal.  I am moving from SF, and we chose to have one of my last dinners here, with the whole crew.. all 15 of us last Saturday.  This joint is intimate, but the staff graciously accommodated us.  

The menu was full of wine selections and one beer.  As a non-wine consumer, I was disappointed with the lack of selection for anything besides one flavor of beer, but I can't complain because I did honestly enjoy it.  The food choices were all authentic and delicious.  Everyone enjoyed their pasta, pizza, and meat dishes.  

We enjoyed ourselves for a few hours and left with smiles.  It could have been all the wonderful energy from my sf family of friends, but I also enjoyed my dinner.
author: Michelle N.

description: I love the ambiance to this quaint restaurant. I've been back 3 times since and everytime the food is consistently great. The bruschetta is yummy. The lasagnetta is melt in your mouth delicious, and I've also tried their ravioli, everything is spot on. Great place to go on a cold evening.
author: stephanie w.

description: This is great neighborhoodie joint with tons of personality. The service and food are both true Italian style. Delicious! It's your local no frills Itatian eatery - enjoy!
author: Lisa R.

description:
I want this to be my home away from home. It's cozy, it's warm and they make yummy, saucy food. 

For years, when I would come visit friends in the City, I would leave the land of cows, bicycles and cheap beer (a.k.a., Davis) and end up entering San Francisco from the Fell Street off-ramp. I saw Il Borgo and wasn't sure what to make of it. It looks a little run down outside and didn't appear to be near anything except for a freeway off-ramp. And now, almost ten years later, I finally wander in.

Thanks to Yelp, I tried the Lasagnetta and loved it. Hand-made, flat pasta pinwheeled with prosciutto and mozzarella then smothered in a tangy tomato-based sauce. Scrumptious. 

Il Borgo is a place where you feel comfortable lingering after your meal enjoying espresso with good friends (and a cappuccino is $2 - hard to find in any restaurant). It seems like the type of place to film a montage of people enjoying life, friends and food. 

Damn, I'm sappy today. But I'm right. Il Borgo gets five stars for just being great at what is.
author: Erin M.

description:
We came here one night before a concert, first mistake. The staff was minimal and although there weren't very many people when we first arrived, the service lacked urgency. Now, I know it's our fault to attempt a leisurely dinner if you're on a time crunch, but we did and unfortunately it adds to my mediocre review.

I got the feeling that the woman serving us was probably an owner which gave Il Borgo a nice comfortable family and homey feeling. So, 4*'s for service, though again, they seemed short handed for the night.

I can't remember much about the food as this was a few months ago but I do remember my friend absolutely repulsed by his gnocci. 

All in all, again, I don't necessarily blame the restaurant entirely for my bad opinion of the place and the truth is, I might give it another shot sometime. However, with so many fab options here in the city, I don't see any reason to.
author: alexa c.

description:
I'll be back.  I enjoyed the food, it's not high-end Italian, it's more comfort food place that's fast and reasonably priced.  The service is a bit goofy, and the waiter tries very hard to be funny.

We started with the caprese.  I wouldn't recommend it.  Kind of bland and the tomatoes were the kind that had no taste.  It would be more forgivable if it were winter, but it's June, so i expect reasonable tomatoes.  

We had three dishes: pizza w/ sausage and mushrooms, lasagnetta, and fettuccine bolognese.  The pizza was thin crust with a lot of toppings.  Large enough to feed 1.5 people.  The fettuccine bolognese was good, but I really like the taste of the lasagnetta.  I'm definitely coming back to have more of the lasagnetta.
author: Joann C.

description: I came here with my fraternity brothers for dinner, the service was impeccable, the lobster ravioli was divine, the atmosphere is perfect to chat it up with the bros or a date.
author: Calvin T.

description:
This place is so cute that you really want the food to be better. We live right up the street so it's nice to have a pretty decent italian restaurant within a two block radius but our meals haven't always been consistent.
It's cash only which can be a pain but they pour pretty generous glasses of wine and there is hardly ever a wait.
The first time we ate there, the signora was pretty rude to us but she's gotten better since then.
I've taken my future mother-in-law here and she loves it and I love it too, the atmosphere is definitely 5 stars, the food, maybe 3.5?
author: Emily L.

description:
I'll usually be reviewing restaurants for the kitchen but once in a while it'll be for the diner.  Here's one.
If this place was more pretentious, I wouldn't give it four stars.  Fortunately its campy, kind of cheesy "Italian" decor and nobody is putting on airs. If you're like me you'll want to root for this place.  Definitely not a "cool" place, kind of a dive.  Overall it doesn't have the best food but it has a few dishes that are always consistently good if not great. 

The Il Borgo salad or whatever its called.  This is the reason I come here. Radicchio, Gorgonzola Salad- anchovy garlic balsamic dressing, pinenuts- absolutely delicious and simple ingredients.  

Lasagnetta is really good comfort food.  try it, you will like it.  

If you get these two dishes and nothing else, you will be very happy.  I can't vouch for anything else. I've tried a number of other pastas and pizza and they're generally very american italian i.e. blunt and a bit heavy handed.  I won't go into that; just get the salad and the lasagnetta w/ prosciutto, some wine and be happy.

decent wine by the glass, always enjoyed it, never gotten old wine.
author: Sarah A.

description:
came here last week...or a couple of weeks ago with some good friends. we had no place in mind when it came to where to go to dinner that night until we came across il borgo...and it was a pleasant surprise!! the lasagnita was what i had and it was delish!! both the pasta dishes my friends got were equally good but i think my dish was the major winner!! 

the funny thing is that i've driven by this place countless times as i am getting off the freeway. never crossed my mind to go check it out. but i'm glad we did and i would totally come back and get the lasagnita again...apologies if i spelled that wrong :)
author: caroline g.

description:
I really like the ambiance of this place.

Like little Italy.  I like the hanging laundry, and awnings, and street lights on the inside.  I feel this adds a nice touch to the place.  Rather than just a boring old restaurant like many others.

The food is scrumptious.  There were six of us that went the other day, and half the group ordered the lasagna, which is something they say is one of their signature dishes.

I had a bit of it and I agree - however, I ordered the lobster ravioli and it melted in my mouth.  Delicioso!!!  Molto Bene!

We will go back!
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Heck yes, Il Borgo. Heck yes. You were kind of rude, but in an endearing way. Very European. You warmed up as the courses moved on, and as we ordered more. 

Lasangetta was divine. We shared; it was plenty with a salad and their delicious crunchy crusty bread. Pistaccio gelato was the best we've ever had, and in the end, we loved our waiter, and the teddy bear in the bathroom was still unexpected, though I had been warned by fellow yelpers. There are plenty of other dishes I am looking forward to trying in the future. Lots of neighborhoodies and familiar faces. Definitely a nice non-pretentious off the track, but not out of the way comfortable Italian restaurant.

A good selection of vegetarian dishes, the artichoke ravioli was excellent and well received by P's dad.

Cash only- but they have an ATM inside. No worries!
author: Nadine S.

description:
Dear Nonna, 

Grazie for those 5 hour lunches and dinners you have provided me for years. Grazie for filling up my stomach during those long summers in Italy. Grazie for making me want to come home to eat some real italian food. 

However, I have found someone else that can do the same for me. I have finally found an authentic italian place in SF. While sipping a bottle of spumante, and rediscovering the pleasure of deliciously fresh carpaccio with a hint of parmegiano reggiano, exquisite tomato cream lasagnetta, but most of all a perfectly cooked and tasteful pizza, I was thinking of you. I prefer not to think, of the quantity of nights and money I have spent looking for those pizza's that makes you want to eat a second one immediately. Did I mention that they use a wood fire oven and that they make their own soft bread ? Sorry Nonna but you can't beat that. While the cost of my airline ticket will come close to $1.2K, this dinner came to $71 without tip (cash only accepted). 

As to service, we had the pleasure of having Mitra make this dinner even more formidable. She made sure that everything was up to par with the quality of the food. For that I am thankful. 

Nonna, I am sorry, but I will just have to come home to see you and not your food anymore. 

PS: No Nonna, I am not an employee, or owner of this place. But I will definitely become a local patron.
author: Nicholas C.

description: Rolled in with 7 people at about 7pm on a Saturday night with no reservations.  Got seated in about 15 minutes and for the next few hours it felt like we were family (Cliche but true). My family is from France and Il Borgo reminds me a bit of places i used to go when i was in Bordeaux. The wait staff is adorable and was cracking jokes and hooking us up with desert wine. The food is authentic and the atmosphere is really nice. Any one aspect of Il Borgo only really deserves four stars but the fact that the food, service, and ambiance all come together so well earns it that fifth star.
author: Nick d.

description:
We go to Il Borgo at least once a month. We think this place does gnocchi better than most places and certainly is THE best for the price.
