The Penne Arrabiata is fabulous if you like simple and spicy.  The chicken entrees are just OK. I'd stick with pasta basics instead. The Insalata del Borgo is a highlight: A wonderful radicchio salad with gorgonzola and pine nuts. My mother loves their homemade bread. 

At Il Borgo I always feel as if I'm eating in a family Italian restaurant in Italy. It's a Euro-sized small place with warm decor. The owners are from Milan. The male owner always seems overworked but hanging in there. The female waitress/owner (?) is never there on weekends anymore when we are. We miss her. My sweetie loves that she speaks Italian to him. 

There is a gray-haired waiter who once gave my group complimentary shots of Grappa, "the national drink of Italy" he said. I'm sure it was meant as a nice gesture but none of us drink hard alcohol and some didn't drink alcohol at all, so we had a hard time with this stuff especially since the rest of us had to polish it off. We always laugh about that experience.

However one time that same talkative waiter said some rather inappropriate things to my sweetie and I, and we felt a little uneasy for the rest of the dinner and for the next few times we were there. He must be a cousin or something that the owners feel they must keep on the payrol. Well, that's the story we made up about it.  We liked it better when the woman worked on Saturday nights. 

If you're bringing American out-of-towners who think that Italian food means spaghetti with meatballs, they'll be disappointed because this is a meatball-free joint. And they might have to go through the 'ol routine of  "could I have some butter for my bread" (yes they'll bring it out for you). 

On our first visit years ago we were given a complimentary cannoli for dessert. It is the only restaurant-cannoli I've ever liked. 

Beware -- cash only!
author: Paris E.

description:
Been going to this intimate and warm Italian neighborhood joint for the past year. I like to wander through neighborhoods and discover gems. I rarely remember names of places. So I always knew this place as the Italian restaurant that takes cash but has an indoor ATM, on the corner of Fell and that other street that Suppen Kuche is on. 

This is where Yelp comes in and helps me search for an "Italian restaurant" near "Hayes Valley, San Francisco, CA" on the semi-decent search. Il Borgo pops up first. Of course Arlequin wine merchant pops up second, followed by Zoya, and then Blue Bottle Coffee Co., which are not even remotely Italian. * Clueless * Shrug. I like how Stelline isn't amongst the top 3, which serves pasta, but it is not Italian IMHO.

Il Borgo serves true Italian restaurant fare. Each ingredient and handmade pasta is crafted with love. The special lobster ravioli has me swooning for more. And the handmade gnocchi pillows are a savory melt in the mouth. Nothing fancy schmancy but just great Italian meals, even if I have to comfortably eat alone in peace and quiet without any tourists (woohoo!). Everytime I go, there is this tall Italian waitress who is so sweet. She ensures that I am comfortable and my water cup is filled with no ice. 

Everytime I go, I find my eyes fixated on the classic 1800s indoor lamp post by the door. Then I glance over to the clothing line, that is suppose to help with the decor and ambiance, but it has turned into a lost and found for scarves. Cute.
author: Cathy H.

description:
3.5 stars - Il Borgo is a solid, not great, but good italian restaurant with simple comfy fare. Portions are NOT huge. They're decent, probably a heathy size but we're pigs and we like to eat:

-Bruschetta - 4 pieces of chunky fresh tomatoe on fresh white bread. good, but it's bruschetta. can't really ruin it.
-Lobster Ravioli - served in a creamy pink sauce, I couldn't actually taste the lobster.
-Veal Saltimbocca -  cut of veal hammered thin, with proscuitto on top. served with veggies. the color of the veal wasn't appetizing, slightly grey beige but it tasted all right. a favorite at the table.
-Penne Puttanesca - tangy flavors from the olives and capers. i thought this was more memorable.
-Gnocchi in gorganzola sauce - very light, not heavy like most dead weight potato pastas. another crowd favorite.
-Fettuccine w/ sundried tomatoes and chicken - this was my favorite. al dente fettuccine, w/ tang from the sundried tomatoes and a bit of meatiness from the chicken.

Can't forget dessert:
***Tiramisu - the best! not overly sweet, light, fresh, and you get a big hunk of it
-Vanilla gelato - 3 boules of this yummy vanilla beany italian delight
-Spumoni - tri-colored and flavors (chocolate, cherry, and pistachio). i don't usually like this italian neapolitan but this wasn't artifical tasting at all)
-Cheesecake w/ strawberries - a light cheesecake.

We also had a simple bottle of Pinot Nero (aka pinot noir) which was very easy on the palate.

Pluses: attentive service, no wait, quaint decor, unassuming, relaxing, quick to serve food too
Why it falls 1/2 star short of 4: smallish portions, somewhat uninventive dishes, cash only (pp tab w/ tip = $32)

Would I go back? Sure, for basic Italian food in an unpretentious setting.
author: Cindy W.

description: this place is a hidden gem. It doesn't look like much from the outside, but the staff treats you like family and the food is great. it's really a great place, and I'd definitely recommend it for a low key date night
author: Lauren B.

description:
I ate here about three months ago and just realized I forgot to review it.  I walk by this restaurant all the time.  I always thought it looked very cozy and family run.

It was pretty good food, but I don't know how often I'll go back for one reason only:  WAAAAAAY too much garlic in everything.

I love, love, love garlic, but this was out of control.  I'd recommend asking for your dish easy on the garlic if you go here.
author: Angie C.

description: Not sure why past yelpers have written that is smelled bad or the service was bad bc this place was charming, smelled pleasant and our every want or need was fulfilled.  Very quaint and romantic.  I recommend the homemade pasta!
author: Melissa B.

description:
I adore Il Borgo!  The pizza crust is a perfect, wafer thin crust.  I also recommend the lasagnetta, as it is amazing.

The owners are very friendly and make your dining a true experience.  The decor transports you to Italy with the detailed hand-painted murals.  

Il Borgo is the ideal place for a quiet, romantic dinner with someone special.
author: Jessica H.

description: I joined yelp today, just so I can write this review! This was by far the worst meal I have ever had in San Francisco, and probably in the top 5 of top worst meals ever. Let's start with the decor, we thought we were at the Italian section of epcot center, with the faux outside/inside decor, it was totally tacky, and I am all for campy kitsch, but it wasn't clever enough to be so. Ok, now the most important part, the food, the caprese was ice cold with dry oregeno flakes all over it, no taste and then shocks of spices. And sadly the pasta was inedible, I ordered the fettucine bolognese, and it was like american chop seuy back in grade school, just missing a good doughy hamburger bun. So overall, not good, don't go unless you want a bad meal in a disney land setting.
author: Brando W.

description:
DAMN I WANT THIS TO BE 3.5 !!

I can't believe we have not been here...it's local, casual, not expensive, and they take reservations.

The scene:  locals eating moms italian, if your mom could actually cook italian really well.  some romantic couples.  Tacky decorating that looks just like a movie set.

The food:  VERY yummy.  Bruschetta loved on my tongue with olive oil and garlic.  Raddichio salad was very interesting and delicious.  Veal was good.  This is easy, nice italian...don't expect haute cuisine.

Minus .5 stars for leaving the server all alone and for her calling me "senior" all night.

Minus 1 star for being so warm in the restaurant we could have had shorts and a t-shirt on.

Warning: Wine list does totally bite it....bring your own.  I forgot to ask what the corkage fee was, so someone let me know !
author: David S.

description:
I went here with my fabulous sugar daddy of a roommate on Friday night and when we were seated, I felt like I should have been eating spaghetti and meatballs off of a plate a la Lady and the Tramp and serenaded by a man with an accordian.

Cheesy ambience aside, the food was decent, and for Hayes Valley, the prices were pretty reasonable. My stuffed chicken breast with porcini mushroom sauce was a really great combination, however the breast was a tad dry, and the whole plate was a tad on the tepid side. 

Tepid would also be an appropriate word to describe the service. We stood by the entrance of the restaurant for a good 30 minutes for a seat and were not once greeted by any of the staff, however, once seated, our waiter was quite friendly and attentive. 

All in all a pretty decent establishment and I undoubtedly will find myself back there again to try the pasta.
author: Clarissa S.

description: I very much enjoy this local, cash-only, Italian eatery. The food is consistently quite good and I've introduced many people to it. I regularly enjoy the caprese salad and gnocchi in gorgonzola sauce. I've had a few different selections from the wine list that were ok, none really were memorable.  Lately we bring our own wine and pay the corkage fee.  That's ok though because the gnocchi is so fresh, like little pillows. I want some now...
author: P W.

description: Not bad. Not great. The consensus is Meh.  We were hungry. They had food. We ate it.  They were a bit grumpy and short and couldnt explain the menu very well.
author: Bryan M.

description:
On a whim, went into Il Borgo on Saturday evening.  From the minute I walked in, I felt I was transported to Italy itself!  Complete with a clothes line strung across the restaurant with clothes hanging on it.  The murals were Italian streets making you feel as though you're sitting at an outdoor cafe in Italy.  

Our server was an older Italian gentleman who I believe owned the restaurant before he retired to working only 10 hours a week as a waiter.  Very nice and welcoming.  The service was fast and not overbearing, wine always refilled, and the timing of the food & apps was spot on.

Began with an Italian red, pino nero - deliciously light and from what our waiter told us, relatively rare in SF.  Not terribly expensive either.  Around $30 - brilliant compliment to the food.

Had the bruscetta - very fresh tomatoes, but it lacked cheese.  Not a big deal to me, but a slight disappointment to my dining companion.  Although, without the cheese it seemed far more like authentic Italian than the high fat Americanized version.  

For entrees:  I ordered chicken breast stuffed with cheese & prosciutto with a dark rosemary gravy, veggies, and potatoes, my companion had lasagnetta, which was a rolled lasagna in a light and creamy red sauce.  Just delicious!  

The prices are completely reasonable, averaging $12 - 18 a plate.  Probably my new favorite Italian restaurant in my hood.  Parking can be a bit of a problem, but definitely worth the effort.
author: Alison L.

description: Lovely lady named Mitra. She is a true Italian woman! haha Love their pizzas (soft and not salty) and breads (fresh baked, always soft, outter part is chewy not hard!) and penne arrabiata is famous.
author: Nina N.

description:
My dear friend Jose suggested this tiny Hayes Valley diamond in the rough after pre Christmas shopping at Costco, and nothing could have been more welcome.  Like a period set from a movie lot, Il Borgo is almost too genuine to believe, but on entering the warm dining room from the street corner, warmth, sincere hospitality and scents of garlic and a working grill tug and draw you into this time warp with maternal arms.  It's small, rustic, dated and charming.  We were greeted by a sweet Italian lady who brought pints of water and menus, then a big basket of generously sliced sweet French bread to dip in virgin olive oil and a good Balsamic vinegar.  

The menu is short, sweet and feels like the real thing.  Pasta and pizza, antipasti, zuppa, entree and a simple, authentic Italian wine list conjure up village bistro's in rural Italy that are frequented and supported by the local villagers and this seems just like that.  The three of us went our own way with the menu, grilled Salmon, house made fettuccine with a tomato putanesca sauce and I opted for pillow like Gnocchi in the lightest, sweetest Gorgonzola sauce I've ever tasted.  This restaurant doesn't blink and eye at making almost anything you might ask for if the chef has the ingredients so feel free to discuss and even ask for what your heart desires, you'll likely get it.  The Salmon was generous and gorgeous on the large oval platter accompanied by a selection of sauteed vegetables my friend wanted cooked to order.  Jose's Fettuccine was al dente and so perfect I wanted to frame and freeze it to eat whenever I crave the best pasta ever.  My Gnocchi was so light and flavorful with the perfect sauce, light and cheesy, cooked so righteously I wanted to cry.  

The portions here are humongous so its impossible to leave hungry, but many folks do leave with a doggie bag for the next day, and return a week later for their two meal for the price of one fix.  I didn't see old fashion garlic bread on the menu and asked our charming waitress and what came out was delicious, among the best garlic breads I've had.  We were each stuffed when we left and I vow to return here many times in the future, I love Il Borgo and hope you do too.
author: Stu S.

description:
Ok - just order the Lasagnetta. Lasagnetta 12.75
Rolled lasagna filled with prosciutto and mozzarellaI. I think their cheaper bottle of Chianti pairs perfectly with the Lasagnetta. 



All the pasta is hand made. I also sometimes give up my comfort meal and get the lobster or artichoke ravioli. My hubby likes the Chicken Parmesan but they only have it on certain days. You have to ask for it - it is never on the menu. 

Sometimes the service is a little slow but they usually reward you with tiramisu (sp?).

I suggest going during the week. I often order take out - they are fast and give you a huge piece of bread for the road. 

PS - If eating in, I suggest public trans or walking. Parking is pretty hard. During the week you can usually find a spot on the east /south side of Fell.
author: Katy D.

description:
Charming place. The BF and I decided to stray from our usual saturday night comfort food stops, and I had long wondered about the charming-looking Il Borgo on the corner. We called ahead, were told there were tables available, and whisked there in a cab. 
The carpaccio was succulent, the salad was crisp and fresh, the bread texture-perfect. That was just the appetizer. I had the lasagnetta, which was incredible -- the prosciutto was so flavorful... BF had the lobster ravioli -- also really quite tasty, with a tangy and bright seafood taste... 
Add in some candlelight, some red wine, and sparkling conversation, you've got the makings of a perfect date night.
Definitely coming back for more of the same.
author: Fred L.

description:
This place feels like a small restaurant off an alley way in Rome.

The lighting is dim, you may end up sharing a table next to a stranger, and the waitress rarely speaks English!

I LOVE IT!
I'm not sure if she owns it or just runs it- the the Hostess / Server / everything else... is a delight!  Their bread is usually served fresh, and is JUST like bland Italian bread, you use to wipe the oil off the plates with.  YUMMY!
The pastas- all I need to say is: FETTUCCINE PRIMIVERA!
This is home made and to die for!!!
Their Tiramasu is delish too!
Oh- and don't forget the Grapa!  Stronger than ever- and if you're lucky and work the friendship right- she may give you a glass on the house!  That's if your lucky :)

I try to go at least once a month- if not every two months... When I lived in Hayes Valley, we'd go every two weeks!

It's due another visit!
author: Leslie D.

description:
Excellent neighborhood joint for Italian food. I would not drive out of my way to go to this place, but I would definitely walk over.
My wife and I always enjoy good meal, but the cash only option most likely keeps potential customers away.
author: Steve B.

description:
I have to agree with Omid T: Italian cuisine isn't too tricky to pull off.

I tend to not enjoy eating out for Italian, since a lot of times, I feel like I could just as easily make the majority of what is on the menu at home. 

+1 Star for the cool music and neat settting. I read in someone's review that the music was overkill in one sense or another (I think they may have used the word "kitcshy" and "Sinatra" in the same sentence to describe it). During my visit, there was some weird electronica/experimental/acid-jazzy thing going on that seemed a little out of place, but was a welcome relief from the Olive Garden Rat Pack soundtrack that tends to overpower the ambiance in most Italian restaurants.

+1 Star for the generous glass of chianti that I thoroughly enjoyed.

+1 Star for the chicken saltimbocca that was so delicious. 

+1 Star for being the best part of my day.

-1 Star for the service that seemed a little short and annoyed everytime he pulled up to fill water glasses. It was actually a little awkward: the guys who was waiting on us didn't say much. He'd just walk up to the table and stand there and stare. Maybe he just assumed that we knew the procedure at a restaurant, so he didn't need to waste his breath talking. But every now and then he'd bring his water pitcher with him, so I guess he was cool.
author: Meghan L.

description: This place is unbelievable.  The owner is from tuscany, and her food is AUTHENTIC.  lasagnetta is my all time fave.  anyway.  you cannot go wrong with this place.  It's a true Italian trattoria  The bread is always fresh and warm.  the ambiance is romantic... and heck, the place looks like a little italian piazza.  doesn't get any better than that.  and for those of you looking to practice your italian, the proprietor and some waitstaff eagerly fulfill your italian conversation needs.  I love this place and will be back the next time I'm back in my old home, SF.
author: paul l.

description:
The italian boyfriend and I frequent this place pretty regularly, and are starting to feel quite at home with the Milanese owner (yes, the hot waitress many yelpers have spoken of).  We have tried almost everything on the menu, and have never had a bad meal...

It's straightforward, ma and pa style italian dishes- the veal and lamb chops are awesome,  and the homeade pasta is amazing!  Try the homeade (large portioned) tiramisu, it's to die for.

There is an atm there, so no need to bring cash with you, as other yelpers have stated.  

The weekends show a larger crowd, but you can still come without a reservation.  The gentlemen of the restaurant give the lady Friday nights off of waitressing, and are a little more reserved and a little more italian, but are pleasant nonetheless.
author: megan k.

description: Relaxed, cute, with Italian rustic theme.  All the pasta was delicious.
author: Gabriela M.

description:
Most importantly: the food here is good! 4 stars, Yay! I'm a fan.

Next, this restaurant is small which means whether you have a reservation or not, they only have so many tables and seats, so you may end up waiting.  The staff is very friendly, but again there are only so many of them, that it can be a little slow (we went on a Saturday at 7:30pm, so it may have been their busiest few hours of the week. Another day/time might be a little less crazy). You can see into the oven/kitchen from the dining area, which I thought was cool. Also important: cash only.

Details: they bring you a little loaf of bread, with some oil and vinegar, yum. You don't have a plate so the crumbs go all over - I don't know if they just forgot to bring us the plates or if that's normal. Then between the 4 of us we got 2 orders of the lasagnetta (very cheesie, large portion, not much meat), 1 of the vegetable lasagnetta, and one of the artichoke raviolis (mine). I was impressed with the artichoke raviolis: thought the serving size was perfect, the sauce was very fresh and light, and that the raviolis were very tasty.  All of the meails were delicious. Oh and the glass of wine we got was a very generous pour :)

I thought the ambiance was great, and that coming in a group of 4 was the perfect size.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
Came here w/the gf as we were exploring the neighborhood. The decor is great -- welcoming and intimate, and the service was fine. The food, however, was really just average. Gf ordered the lasagnetta, which was way too cheesy and the pasta lacked texture. I got the bolognese, which also wasn't much to talk about -- it was salty and unseasoned at the same time, if that makes any sense. The homemade pasta was good though.

Cash only.
author: Henry T.

description:
Screw the food..for now. The decor did it all for me. From rustic wooden tables, checkered italian-eatery style table cloths, a creative clothesline in a corner, painted walls to italian charm, this damn little hole is such an old-world turn on! The melting candle on each table was a delight and a point of disagreement between my dinner partner and I. 

The wine-by-glass selection is very limited - there are only two you can do. Do the Merlot. I am not a chianti fan in any case and this Merlot was actually quite balanced. One look at the menu and the bruscetta and artichoke ravioli (chef's special) were both no brainers. BTW, I learned bruschetta is pronounced 'brus-ketta'. Damn...and you think you know these things! I think I learned a lot more italian than I could have on one of those CDs. The owner (assumed) insisted on speaking only italian with us (which is a little disconcerting when there is a communication gap and informative, when you dont know a shread of the language)

So this is where the fun tapers. Ordinary bread-n-tomatoes, a slightly sticky ravioli, uninteresting tomato sauce and insipid conversation dulled things a bit.

I think I'd go back. This time..with better food for ear and different item off the menu?

Oh.. and don't forget cash. This place does not take credit cards, but they have a *conveniently* placed atm in one corner!
author: Ranj V.

description:
We've been to this place three times and think the food is good deal. Its well prepared and not too pretentious. 

This last time, when we've brought our own wine in, I have gotten a little bit of a hassle for asking for the bigger glasses for our wine, which was far better than anything on this place's wine list. What do you expect dude? I was then lectured about how they reserve these glasses for people "paying for the wine" 

Either you let someone bring in wine or you don't. Don't treat me like a cheapskate just because your wine list sucks..

The waiter warmed up when we all ordered enough food to make up for the wine sale. ....Jeesshzzz - lose one star for being a clueless ass about glasses...Guess I will bring in my own glasses then!

The lamb chops are cooked to perfection - the salads are delicious and the pastas are made with a great touch.

I love the food - sorta charmed by the old school waiters/owners who are grumpy Italian guys, but they are also warm and friendly once you share the wine with em...
author: larry n.

description:
This place is pretty decent.  Not too impressed with the wine selection, but I did enjoy my dish (very al dente, but a flavorful sauce).

I started with the radicchio salad with Gorgonzola.  It had a very light vinaigrette which pulled the edge off the radicchio.   And if you're in the mood for Gorgonzola - get this.

We hit it on a Tuesday night - not a lot of people in there.  Be comfortable using just a little Italian (Prego and Grazi) and I think it will make your visit pretty smooth with the server.

NO CREDIT CARDS - they have an ATM in the back.
author: RiCH K.

description:
Good, honest food at a reasonable price. The atmosphere is warm and cozy - A good casual date place.  

We had the Insalata del Borgo, the gnocchi with bolognese sauce, the tortellini, and the tiramisu.

The Insalata del Borgo was simple but delicious. It had a  light, and slightly garlicky vinaigrette. The gorgonzola and pine nuts paired really well with the bitter radicchio. 

The gnocchi was great comfort food. A nice steaming plate of fluffy little pillows, surrounded by a tasty meat sauce. What more can I say? It really hit the spot.

The tortellini filled with sausage was straightforward and light. The tomato sauce was simple and fresh.  The tortellinis were tender, and perfectly stuffed.  

The tiramisu was light, creamy, and not overly sweet. The flavors of the coffee and cocoa were nicely balanced. We licked the plate.

This is a great neighborhood restaurant that has love in the food.  Don't forget to bring CASH.
author: Miyas J.

description: Went here for a nice meal with a friend. I loved the atmosphere (drip candles and light music) it was very comfortable and the waitress/owner was very sweet and welcoming. Very authentic and the fettuccine was fresh. We also ordered the salmon which was cooked perfectly and paired well with the fettuccine dish. Owner even gave us some complimentary tiramisu and dessert wine. I would go back again! ;)
author: Lauren B.

description: I ordered the gnocchi. Gross. The $3 frozen gnocchi I buy from Trader Joes is leaps and bounds better than theirs. Sauce was lacking flavor and the pasta was over-cooked. My dining-mate was not impressed either - his fish wasn't fresh at all. The service was pretty bad too - no one ever asked how the food was or why we didn't finish the wine (the server's recommendation did not agree with us). Not going back, even though it's right next to my apartment.
author: Kori M.

description: Italian at its best!  Felt like Italy!  Excellent food, atmosphere, and staff attention - and we were there on a Saturday night.  My first dinner here and I will certainly be back!
author: Sarah V.

description: Excellent food.  Been there twice and had the Fettucine Del Borgo both times - oh so good!  The ambiance is excellent, warm and cozy.  On weekend nights it can get crowded; reservations might help.
author: Lee K.

description:
i had passed this place a few weeks ago and was intrigued by the atmosphere.  i was walking around hayes valley recently with my boyfriend and we decided to stop in.  this is a great traditional, non-shishi italian restaurant with great decor and atmosphere.  the bread was good, and the salad i had was very very basic, but i really loved the dressing which was unique but tasty.  i had penne all'arrabbiatta, which is what i usually have in italian restaurants, and theirs was solidly good.  it had the perfect amount of spiciness, which often seems difficult to find with arrabbiatta sauce.  my only complaint would be the lack of wines to choose from by the glass.  i wanted red and all they had was chianti and merlot, neither of which are my favorites.

there are drippy candles on every table, and the decor is quaint and lovely-designed to look like an outdoor italian village (i think.)  the waitress was very attentive and nice as well.  i really enjoyed myself here.  they take cash only, but conveniently have an ATM inside too!  i will definitely be coming back here to try some more of their dishes!
author: Kate W.

description:
My girlfriend and I had dinner there last night based on a friend's recommendation. About 2 seconds after sitting down, an older waiter made some weird comments to my girlfriend and pretty much made us uncomfortable for the rest of the meal. It was as if he did not want us there. I was really pissed off.

Food came quick and was alright, but we're never going there again.
author: Sean K.

description:
I took my ex here once and she really liked it.  She was living at my place and we had been living entirely off of food from the Lower Haight and it's various restaurants.  

While I see no harm in that, we both wanted Italian food and didn't want to drive (drunk) or take a cab (kind of broke) and so it was that we discovered Il Borgo.  

The food is home-style Italian.  My Nana's  is much better but she lives back east so this will have to do.  The lobster ravioli is delicious and there's no shortage of garlic in any of their dishes as I believe was pointed out by someone already.  To me, this is a positive thing.

That and cheese.  They will give you a lot.  Whenever I go back, I will take it from them gladly.

Oh, I don't pretend to be a wine aficionado (or tard, whatever) but I am something of a wino.  Suffice it to say, the lady and I enjoyed two bottles of cheap red from across the street, one at the table and one on the way up Fell to Filmore.  

Nothing's so impressive as a drunk woman gracefully climbing the streets of San Francisco in crazy high heels without spilling a drop.

One star deducted for the pricing, which though mostly reasonable, does seem sort of arbitrary.  The outside is beyond quaint, for those who might be put off by that sort of thing, but it's a nice effect when you walk in.  

Good for a date or the beginning to a night out with your boo.  

Not cheap.
author: Hebrew K.

description: We love this place and except for one Dutch guy, every person we ever took there raves about it and wants to go back. The hostess is fabulous and makes you feel at home. Try a tiramisu for dessert with espresso. There is an ATM inside, so don't worry that they only take cash. Absolutely a great date spot. Can't understand what kind of person doesn't like this place.
author: karl g.

description:
Service is amazing when Mitra is there. If you go Sunday thru Thursday, she will greet you with the best service and smile. Her husband seats and serves Friday and Saturday, and he isn't the greatest. 

The lasagna is to die for. I think everyone should give it another chance. it is one of the hidden gems in SF. I have been going for three years now. 

Also, no corking fee!
author: Karen B.

description:
If you want to know how it feels to be served in an Italian home with authentic Italian cooking, go here. The restaurant is very homey and the waitress is very courteous. The only thing that separates you from the kitchen is the waitress counter, everything from the pots hanging from the ceiling to the stone walls and stone oven makes the restaurant feel homey. The walls are painted to look like the streets in Italy, dinner is candle lit, since it was winter when I went-there were scarves hanging from a clothesline that ran across one corner of the room, the metal chairs have red comfy pillows, and the whole room smells like fantastic food. Now to the food, the food is delicious. I had artichoke ravioli, didn't realize how hungry I was until I took the first bite. Next was dessert, and I had Chocolate, Strawberry and Vanilla gelato and Tiramisu. Gelato was what you would expect, delicious but the Tiramisu was the best, it was spongy and light and melted in my mouth. If anything I would go back to try another ravioli and top it off with Tiramisu.

This restaurant is cash only, with an ATM located inside, in case customers forget or just don't know. And look to spend 13-20 per plate.
author: Caryl C.

description:
I find it extremely irritating (and perhaps a bit shady) when a restaurant serves you food and wine and then, after you've presented a second non-AmEx credit card, informs you that they don't take credit cards and proceeds to direct you to an ATM secreted around the corner WITHIN the restaurant.  There are absolutely no indications either in the restaurant windows, within the restaurant, or on the menu stating that they do not take credit cards.  I have been to plenty of cash-only restaurants but have always been aware before/during ordering that I was in such an establishment.  Never have I had this information sprung upon me after dining.  I will not be back again.  
P.S.  The food was really just OK to bland--the bruschetta especially was just OK.
author: M. K.

description:
I went there on a Friday night at around 6:30.  Judging by the high reviews for this place, I figured that this place would be pretty full.  To my amazement, it was completely empty.  We stayed until about 7:30, but even then there were no more than 5 people in the restaurant.

A pity, since the food was terrific.  I ordered a pasta of sausage and mushrooms (which was a special, not on the regular menu), and my girlfriend had the lobster ravioli.  I can honestly say that I haven't had pasta like that since I was last in Italy (then again, I don't get to explore restaurants as much as I'd like).  The penne was cooked perfectly, and the dish as a whole wasn't weighed down with any heavy sauce.  What sauce there was consisted mostly of tomatoes and spices.  The lobster ravioli was also good, though it didn't have the combination of flavors that made the pasta dish so great.  The sauce for the ravioli was a bit plain, but still good.

For dessert, we split a tiramisu, which was wonderful.  It was very light, and not cloyingly sweet like other tiramisu I've tasted.

If this place accepted credit cards, it might get 5 stars.  The prices are quite reasonable, the service was prompt, and most importantly, the food was delicious.
author: Sam H.

description: I am sometimes reluctant to share my favorite places on Yelp, but I think Il Borgo is such a gem that it deserves some credit. I would stay the style is classic red sauce and garlic Italian, but I love the fat and doughy homemade noodles. Most pasta dished between $10 and $15, and the wines were mostly Italian and under $35, which I love. Service was gracious and you can usually walk in and sit down without a wait.
author: Lorenzo C.

description: Good quality, reasonable prices, cute atmosphere  Been going here regularly for a few years now.
author: Jay D.

description: Great pizza and wonderful service.  The hostess is graceful and attentive.  This place is very cozy, reminds me of Italy!
author: K K.

description: I would give it 5+ stars for the atmosphere and settings! But 1 star for the food...unfortunately it felt as if it came out of a can. The pizza was good though - if I ever go again for a couple of glasses of house wine, I'm just sticking to the pizza ;-)
author: Anny P.

description: Will not be returning.  What had seemed so good as takeout did not match the dining in experience.  Ambiance was nice, but service and food were mediocre and careless.   If you have a sensitive stomach, do not eat here.
author: Esther R.

description: Nice little neighborhood place with Italian American food (except that steller salad that was straight out of Italy).  Less than attentive staff but they were certainly responsive when flagged.  The food was good, but not knock your sock off good.
author: Ila L.

description: This place pleasantly surprised me, super delicious. Nice ambiance and the service was perfect. I will definitely return the next time I'm in The CIty.
author: Melinda G.

description: I live about 4 blocks away from this place and I'm never disappointed everytime I go here.  The restaurant is owned by a scilian woman who also serves the tables.  It has a very homey feel and doesn't feel pretentious.  Check out the lasgnetta - a thin version of their lasagna.
author: Eric A.

description: A hidden gem just off Hayes Street, some simple but delicious Italian fare in a very relaxed atmosphere. Nothing pretentious here, just some great pasta.
author: Nish N.

description: Wow.... maybe I missed something here, but I don't know where people are getting the "this tastes like it was made by an italian grandmother" reviews. I only had one dish, so my experience is limited, but it basically tasted like canned mushrooms with canned tomato sauce. Based on the Yelp reveiws and the price point (12 bucks or so), I would have expected much better food. Maybe I just need to try other dishes though.
author: Jordan M.

description: Order the Fetuccini del borgo and you wont be disappointed!   Love this spot!  It's a great date restaurant with the candlelight and unique ambiance.  Honestly the best italian food i've had in the city!
author: Nazneen A.

description: Comforting, starchy Italian foods with free-flowing inexpensive wines, sweet staff and reasonable prices. Nothing fancy, which is often the perfect thing.
author: Megan W.

description: Picked this place from Yelp for pre-symphony w/o major price tag or crowd. I would never had noticed this place and I am glad we went. It was so authentic, really felt like some random place in Italy. Even the bread rang true, no salt but you drench it in oil and yum. The antipasto platter was great, and the Prosecco bottle was a mere $29. I had the artichoke ravioli, which was perfect for me. Made with love and detail, but classic Italian fare.  My boyfriend went with the pesto gnocchi based on yelpers galore. However, it was a bit overcooked and the large portion became a bit monotonous (sad that we are so used to getting 5 gnocchi). Kitschy ambience fit well, better than trying to be hip or whatever, loved the cute little kitchen. Overall, a great experience, I would go back for sure.
author: Cassie C.

description:
Our friend who lives in the neighborhood told us about his favorite new restaurant, Il Borgo.  The menu was lacking in seafood.  I usually get seafood, clams and mussels in wine sauce.  I'm allergic to tomatoes and potatoes but I still eat them.

Anyway, I ordered the lamb chops and it came with a full head of steamed broccoli and potato wedges. YUMMY!

They didn't have ice tea nor lemonade available but they refilled the water frequently.

So I'll go again for the chops.
author: Mona B.

description: This place is terrible. I ordered lasagne and I would give it about a 2 -- the sauce was bland and the noodles were gummy. The stale bread was served lukewarm. But worse, far, far worse, my girlfriend ordered a penne pasta dish with pancetta and a white wine sauce. This dish can only be described as terrible. The noodles were about 2-3 minutes shy of al dente, and the sauce was overly acidic, yet flavorless, if such a combination is possible. She was also startled to find large fat globules in the dish -- oh, say the size of a large clove of garlic. We will not be going back.
author: candace j.

description:
This was my favorite Italian restaurant in college. 10 years later (yikes!) and they still deliver. 

Every time I come here, I literally feel like I've been transported to Tuscany. The restaurant is actually pretty decently sized, but it has the appearance and the ambiance of my grandma's cozy Italian kitchen. (I don't actually have a grandma with a kitchen in Italy.. but if I did, it would certainly look like this place).

The staff are all Italian and very attentive. The house red is deeeeeelicious. The gnocchi and the lasagnetta are by far my favorite treats and the tiramisu is to die for if you have room for desert. Everything is very moderately priced -- the lasagnetta is about $13 and a very sizable portion.  

If I ever move back to this area, I definitely see Il Borgo as a staple in my future.
author: A K.

description: We read most of the reviews on Yelp and thought we would give it a whirl.  The Borgo has to be the worst  Italian restaurant in the city.      I had the lobster ravoli and the sauce tasted like it was out of a can.    The carbonara was dry and clumpy.    It seems like the Italian owners think they are in Des Moines, as long as they serve up large portions, it will be a hit.     We had four different Pasta entree's and they were all pretty bad.     All guests had no more than two bites of ea. dish.    $125 later and we ended up at Stellina's for Pesto.
author: phil b.

description:
After being in the jungles of Costa Rica for roughly three weeks, I wanted three things: 1. Find out who won the Home Run Derby, 2. Get my hands on an iPhone, and 3. Have some good italian food. I still need to find someone with an iPhone.

My girlfriend and I decided to try Il Borgo out, seeing that they would be open after the All Star Game ended. I had seen this place many times (especially when the Fell Street freeway exit used to dump you right in front), but never had gone in. Parking can be a pain, which is about usual for this neighborhood, but we found parking right across the street. The place was near empty when we arrived, so we sat immediately and looked over the menu.

I ordered the lobster ravioli while she ordered the artichoke ravioli. Both were very delicious, even though I was jealous of the insane amount of garlic that came with her dish. The ravioli looks handmade, which made it extra delicious for me. We also ordered a bottle of wine and a caprese salad that came with an obscene amount of fresh ground pepper (which to me, is a good thing).

The waitress, who may or may not have been the owner, was very nice and was very good about recommending the wine. The food was quick, as in the second we were done with the caprese our ravioli arrived. When we were done we sat and finished our wine and it was nice. There was some drum and bass playing, which I found a little odd, but I didn't really notice it after a while.

Unfortunately, they are a cash only business. Having to double-check at the door that you have enough cash is a little annoying, but I'd say the food is worth it. Not sure why they do this, though. Also, even though the website says they close at 11:30 Monday - Saturday, we left around 10:30ish and they were closing. So I'm not sure about the time thing.

Just remember to bring cash, for real.
author: Alexis C.

description:
i have been trying to find an italian restaurant for the past 7 years that knows how to make a basic (but not boring) pasta dish similar to what i used to have in my old town. 

although it doesn't look like much from the outside, this restaurant has a really nice, charming interior. their pastas and sauces are made with nice, fresh ingredients and never disappoint.

i also recommend the antipatsi plate, as well as the salads (which are huge). there are some nice vegetarian options on the menu as well.

a nice family-run restaurant with really reasonable prices and fresh, satisfying food.
author: kim g.

description: I'd driven by this place about one hundred times (or more considering it is across from the old Fell St off ramp).  I'd never guess it was worth stopping for until a few friends suggested it.  The atmosphere is adorable.  There are nice murals painted on all the walls and it has a "small Italian village" feel to it.  The food was fantastic.  I was very happy with both my meal and the samples I tried from my friend's plates.  The portions were a good size, not overly huge like some chain Italian restaurants.  The service was fantastic!
author: Jessica B.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in the city. It's always just crowded enough. It's not loud, but you don't feel like you should whisper. It's candle lit, but you can still read the menu. The food is never disappointing and neither is the bill. I've never had a bite of food I didn't like. It's not hip or edgy and I like it that way. For legit italian, this is the place.
author: Kari K.

description: There may be a wait at the Gough and Hayes Italian restaurants, but if you walk 3 blocks west you'll be seated and enjoying a glass of wine before you'd even see a menu at those others.  They cover the bases of Italian basics.  And, if Carbonara is the test, Il Borgo passes with flying colori.
author: L W.

description: Gnochi Gorgonzola has held me hostage. Every time I come here me and my friend Michelle always get it. My Partner is Italian and he loves the Pasta Il Borgo. Whenever his family is all in town they choose to come here. The waitress/hostess is so nice and attentive. Someday I'll try something else from their menu... it's just that such a tasty cheesy doughy goodness cannot be ignored.
author: Eric M.

description: il Borgo is awesome, the food is perfect for a rainy San Francisco day and the owner (I assume he is...) is very funny and friendly.  How often do you walk into a place with 3 people, take a table for 6, and, when you say "the rest are coming soon", have the owner say "oh, sure, here, have something to read while you wait" and then hand you the menu?  Or try to teach your foreign friends how to pronounce the names of Italian dishes?  Oh, and the lasagnette is fabulous!
author: Will A.

description:
I went with 3 other friends NY Eve....what a great experience.  I had Pasta Marciata.  All 4 of us enjoyed simple, fresh, wonderful flavors.  The Gnocchi were delightful, the Lasagnetta and the spag reminiscent of true Italian cooks.

The space is cozy, warm, and not too loud (I'm DONE with scream-arias).  Not a lot of seating, glad we had reservations.  The service was first rate, the owner pleasant, cheerful and very present.

This is easily a 4 star based on space, service, and a delightfully simple menu full of flavor and freshness.  I can't wait to go back and am sending all my folks there.  

Oh!  cash only kids....don't forget!  It was economical too....one of the reasons we chose it.
author: Jeff T.

description: Who knew? Off the main streets in Hayes valley, this place doesn't look like much from the outside. Add to it the oddness of no credit cards accepted (I expect that in North Beach, but  here in Hayes Valley?). Well, on the basis of good reviews we went in. The interior is vastly different from the outside - bright and very fun. The service was polite and quick, with an authentic Italian accent for flavor. The food was simple but good - though the portions are American-size, not European (in other words, portions are HUGE). Prices were reasonable. Skip the espresso and cappuccinos though - they were watery and tasted like the coffee machine had dirt in it.
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
the food was good. the wine was good. the ambiance was good. the prices were good.

being nice to us even though we snuck in 20 minutes before closing was great.
author: Sarah B.

description: Food is good, price is good. You really cannot go wrong with this place. And the pizza is excellent. Be aware that for some reason it is always a million degrees in here, so don't wear a sweater.
author: Stephen W.

description:
We used to live in the neighborhood and unfortunately didn't find it until shortly before we moved away. But we kept going. Then we moved across the Bay, we haven't been back in years but fate took us there tonight and: we still love it. The people are so sweet, the food is really pretty good (if you're into raw food have the carpaccio) and even the decor is really cute. Cheesy cute but cute.
It's not knock-your-socks-off food but pretty authentic, really. Especially the pizza. And consistently good.
author: Cee B.

description: Delicious!  The gnocchi is my absolute favorite, super light and fluffy.  The tiramisu is the best I've ever had.  The atmosphere walks that perfect line between cozy and cheesy.  The only downside is that it's a small place, and if there's a wait you'll likely have to stand awkwardly right next to someone's table.
author: Katie S.

description: Okay so I'm super stuck on this one. I love love love the food and Fredericka... she's fantastic and welcoming and so sweet. The two other gentlemen that work there are SUPER hot and cold. Sometimes they are sweet and accommodating and other days they are super dicks! Go for the food and remember to bring cash. The atmosphere is pretty sweet, kind of corny, but sweet. Oh and the kitchen closes at 10pm so they aren't really open till 11pm.
author: Jessie J.

description:
when a group of us coudn't get into suppenkuche (how do you say that anyway---kukka? cooch?) down the street we mosied our way over here and got seated right away. we were immediately charmed by the homey, low-lit interior, adorable waitress (owner?), and cute busboy. this place is intimate without being fancy. a great spot for a quiet dinner date or catching up with the girls. most importantly, they serve really yummy italian food at really nice prices. and that's kinda hard to find in SF. 

i was a bad bad girl and went for the carbonara--this is the first place i've had it in SF where it tastes the way i want carbonara to taste: creamy, buttery, bacony good. altho i think they used ham instead of bacon, which would typically ruin things for me. this time it didn't. i asked for extra garlic and they let me have it. i was in heaven. the serving was huge, in fact all our servings were quite hefty. we also had two bottles of italian red here, a barbera and a chianti--both were well-priced and lovely.
author: rachel p.

description:
i ordered their pizza.  this was a mistake.  do not order their pizza.  it was soggy & thin, and not the good kind of ny style thin.  it was more of a, "oh look, it's an air bubble.  (after stabbing your air pocket with your fork) hey, there's nothing but the plate?  where's my crust?"  so, you can't really hold up your pizza to eat it because there was no crust for the most part, and if you happen to find crust on your pizza, it'd be soggy.  also, for some reason, i was expecting a decent sized pizza that i would be able to share, but it's was pretty tiny from what i can remember.

not to deter you from this restaurant, their pastas were pretty decent.  my sister ordered the pesto gnocci, which i ended up stealing from her.  my bf ordered some sort of lasagna dish that was good too.  so overall, their pastas are not bad, pretty good, but not mind-blowing.

one thing i didn't like was that it was really really really really dark.  each table had a candle, and that's about the only light you get.
author: H. L.

description:
As I have stated in previous posts, to get 5 stars from me for Italian food, itwould have to be prepared by my great aunt in Naples.  Therefore, with those odds, 4 stars is excellent in my book, and Il Borgo delivers excellent food.

The husband had the gnocchi which rivaled my own, sad to say.  Perfect gnocchi is an amazing combinations of textures in the mouth: something between dumpling and air.  These were perfect, plump, potato pasta nuggets, drenched in a flavorful, though not overbearingly so, meat sauce.  I, not being too hungry (note to self-GO HUNGRY NEXT TIME), had the wonderful Salade Miste del Borgo-a refreshing combination of red cabbage, pine nuts, dried herbs, and gorgonzola cheese tossed with a light italian vinigrette.  Both plates were substantial, and we were served a wonderful hunk of freshly baked italian bread.
Our hostess was a bubbly middle aged Italian woman, who must be the owner, the wife of the owner, or the sister of the owner.  She was great, except (and I use this word with some chagrin as it is difficult to find fault with such a wonderful restaurant) she forgot part of our order (the carpaccio plate) and she greeted everyone with kisses, hugs, joyful waves-which is fine, but we were somewhat ignored-water glasses left empty until we got up to try to fill them ourselves.
We do, however, plan to return at our earliest convenience. Maybe, once we go back a few times, we will be received with the same joyfulness as the other returning customers!
author: Tova S.

description:
This isn't Epcot Center, this is San Francisco.  
I'd give this place a solid three stars with room for improvement.

Very cute and cozy, but kitschy at the same time.  The main dish I had was excellent, pretty much deserving of a five star rating.  I ordered the artichoke raviolis, and they were marvelous, which left me smiling and satisfied.  

Pros:
- delicious entres with perfect portiions
-clean
-reasonably priced
-fast and friendly service

Needs Improvement:
-The music is WAY over the top.  It was cute in Lady in the Tramp for 3 minutes, but not for the duration of a restaurant meal.  
- I should never have to ask for Parmesan cheese at an Italian restaurant.  I mean really, WTF?   
-Why am I getting my soft drink in a can with a straw in it, with no hint of a glass with ice to be found?  In fact, come to think of it,  my water didn't have any ice in it either and was lukewarm.  Is this an English-Italian restaurant?  
-And the Raddicchio salad a la Borgo?  Was my tongue just run over by a car and embalmed in garlic?  I can't understand how or why people are recommending this here on Yelp.  Are you all still bitter from this gastronomical disaster and want others to suffer?  They should credit your bill for eating this.  I am thoroughly convinced that this stuff grows in a patch in the Muni graveyard.  
-Any "cash only" establishment with an ATM in the corner= CHEAP and TACKY.

Needless to say, after the salad I thought surely my taste buds were doomed.  Il Borgo somehow managed to overcome this fell stroke, so it really isn't THAT bad.
author: Marie S.

description: A fantastic evening filled with hot food, warm staff, and burning (in a good way) Grappa.
author: Samantha W.

description:
4 of us ate befoe going to the symphony. had some misgivings, having read some(very few)unflattering reviews.BUT we had GREAT food, service was good, the staff very friendly. We liked it so much we made a return date for the next outing in SF.
The cash only policy was NO problem
author: Marvin E.

description:
I took my younger cousin and her friend her like a year ago. They were so rude! My cousins friend asked for meatballs and spaghetti. Before I could say anything. The waiter reacted in total disgust and raised his voice at her saying, this is authentic italian....ummm yea...whatever buddy...we walked out immediately. 

This past year, my friends have dined here and they were like Eh this isn't authentic, the service is Eh. Don't go!
author: Jag B.

description: The pasta dishes here, while different and more authentic than "Italian" restaurants such as Olive Garden, are very bland.  My $13 penne with sausage and mushroom could have very easily been cooked at home.  The service was nice, the interior was homey..  Just nothing amazing about the food.
author: Wendy T.

description: I wanted to love this place, I really did. It's two blocks from my house and I'd been looking forward to trying it since I moved in. But in the end we had a mediocre experience: While the atmosphere was nice even from our 2x2 table in the corner, the service was bad. Our water spent most of the meal low to empty, they forgot the appetizers entirely and just brought the entres (and didn't apologize) and our waitstaff just generally gave off the rushed cool feeling. The food was good (gnocchi were perfectly cooked) but the sauces weren't great and there was no parmesean to speak of for the pesto gnocci, WTF? It breaks my heart to say that I will probably not be back to the closest restaurant to my apartment. Sigh......
author: M L.

description:
I love this place, I don't even care that my boyfriend thinks it tastes like Chef Boyardee.

I've been going since they first opened and I'm always pleased when I leave. I LOVE the lasagnetta and the gnocci too.

It would be less of a hassle if they took credit cards, but otherwise this is a great place for a non-pretentious, cozy meal.
author: BH ..

description: Great neighborhood italian spot. Fresh pasta and decent wines. Busy on the weekends but the wait is never that bad. Good place for a first date.
author: Jerry M.

description: Everything here is Italian home style: the decor, the food, and the service.  It's very comfortable.  The spicy tomato sauce that I had was very fresh therefore very flavorful.  It's simple and down to earth food with very moderate prices.  So have about 15-20 bucks in your pocket, then you are good for some delicious pasta (cash only)!
author: Vivian H.

description:
I loved my experience here, even though the waiter mixed up my order.
First of all, I loved that the restaurant smelled delicious when we walked in. I also loved the murals, which made me feel transported to the Italian countryside. I loved that we got a booth next to a mural. I loved that in the bathroom sat a very large, white bear. I loved that when I asked the owner whether the bear could sit with us, he said yes. There was no need to feed the bear; it was stuffed already. I also loved that the restaurant was quiet. We shared the mista salad. I loved the herbs on top, the garlicy flavor, though not too strong. I ordered the vegetarian lasagna, and couldn't wait to dig in. Imagine my surprise when I discovered what looked like ham in it. I asked the waiter and he confirmed that it was prosciutto. I said I specifically asked for, and pointed to, the vegetarian lasagna. It turned out he had mixed up my order with that of the previous table's. I was upset. I think he could tell because he brought me a piece of the vegetarian lasagna to make up for mine as well as, first, homemade tiramisu, and, then, Ciao Bella spumoni on the house. I thought his gesture was exceptionally sweet. I was also impressed by the portion size, which was larger than at most places.
I would return, but don't think I'll order the lasagna again.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: I went in by myself at about 6:30 p.m. on a Saturday night. The waiter didn't seem pleased that I was alone and he put me at  a small table off to the side by the ATM machine. I had a glass of chianti and he came with a bottle and filled my glass completely, which I liked. I ordered the lasagnetti which I thought was tasty and a good-sized portion. I spoke to the waiter completely in italian and he seemed to understand me, but hardly said two words to me and when he did, he spoke in English. He was almost surly and barely smiled. He really made me feel unwelcomed. So, I liked the place and hated the waiter. Pasta, wine and tip: $24.00.
author: tom t.

description: Fantasic food, great homey atmosphere, not a speck of attitude, and wonderful service.  Why bother with the symphony crowds in just about every restaurant around Hayes Valley, when this restaurant (only a couple blocks from Stelline,) is in the neighborhood?  Treat yourself to quiet, romantic, relatively inexpensive, meal in this tiny trattoria.
author: Sean M.

description: Great little neighborhood restaurant. Food is very good, and the staff is great. Romantic and cozy.
author: Bob N.

description: I've been going to this small, family-owned neighborhood gem for years and have always had a great experience.  The waitstaff is very friendly and attentive (especially with the ladies).  The food is straightforward Italian fare and everything I have ever tried has been great.  The prices are reasonable but remember to bring cash because they do not accept credit cards.
author: Steven S.

description: Last night I ordered the Veal Scalopinni marsala, the veal was a little tough, but it was in a flavorful sauce, this was hampered by the lazily prepared reheated sauteed zucchini that looked reheated AND tasted reheated; and it came with half a potatoe skinned and cut length wise pan fried ok. Bottom line , $18.75 wil get you this dinner special , about the only thing special was the price: expensive for this quality. The Caprese salad came to our table with roma tomatoes/bufalo mozzarella, the plate was cold and the olive oil was so cold it had gel'd. The tomatoes looked to have been in the refrigerator for a few hours and looked dry , $7.00 is kinda cheap for this dish and the taste reflected the cheap price. What do you expect for $7..00  The house chianti was decent for $6.50 a glass. We got there at 5pm and they played listenable italian music till 6pm, then promptly switched to 1970's era radio commercial grade pop music. Bleck.
author: Bert K.

description:
A neighborhood corner restaurant with surprisingly decent Italian fare. Pros: The Fettuccine del Borgo with chicken, sun dried tomatoes, basil, and capers. With a few dashes of crushed red pepper, this was a satisfying meal with unexpectedly tender white chicken and a tasty sauce. No wait, usually a bonus. 
Cons: Wasn't into the Fettucine Bolognese, but the person who ordered it enjoyed it. The Ensalata Borgo could use another green thrown into it instead of being solely comprised of radicchio. Also could have used a more prominent acidic element in the vinaigrette. It seemed to be dressed only with oil. Cruets of oil and vinegar were on the table, so I just added it myself. The wines by the glass weren't listed on the menu, I prefer to know the origin and price of what I'm ordering. 
The decor abounds with baubles and bric-a-brac as well as those far too often utilized kitschy countryside murals. 
Bitching aside, I actually enjoyed my pasta quite a bit and it seriously was enough for 3 meals for me. Price to value ratio is high, cash only.
author: Candice L.

description: We had a large group attend here for dinner about a week ago, we'd never been before and it was fabulous food. The interior is interesting, and reminded me of being in Italy.  I am looking to go there again tonight, their pizza is the bomb, straight from Italy. I wish I lived in SF! Others that ordered various dishes said their meals were very authentic and delicious as well. Cute area for shopping too, had never been in the area, and really enjoyed the whole experience. Highly recommend if you are looking for great food, and ambience different.
author: Shelley O.

description: Cute, cozy little restaurant.  You feel like you're eating in a secluded piazza in a Tuscan hill town.  The service was friendly but patchy -- it was just one lady serving the whole room. The house radiccio salad was kinda strange and slaw-ish, but the gnocchi were tender and some of the best I've ever had.  I'd definitely go back (and try to remember to bring cash!).
author: Andi T.

description: We were in the mood for Italian. We decided to try something new. The waitress was friendly and really liked us (I think she thought we were Italian too). I ordered the spaghetti cabonara...and it just sat there because my dinner companion ordered the fettucine primavera and I helped him eat his dish. It was a wonderful combination of old and new...I don't know why but I love canned peas. The pasta was fresh and the peas were canned. I really enjoyed my visit to this little neighboorhood establishment. The bread is yummy too. I only wish we didn't order 2 entrees. One is enough to share here.
author: Sherie R.

description: good food... not fantastic but totally gets the job done.. very garlicy! which is what makes the food good...
author: Shannon D.

description: Reliable, not a culinary adventure, probably more like 3.5 stars, but it's a nice little family business and a good atmosphere. Stay simple; fresh salads, spaghetti, and gnocchi. Satisfying tiramisu.
author: Blaine C.

description: Excellent experience. Loved the penne arrabiata. Try it!
author: Whit P.

description: Very fine, high-quality old-school Italian food.  Charming setting and friendly service.  Close to the Opera.  Sparkling clean rest room.
author: Claudia F.

description: The Setting is minimal, but the food is genuine Italian.  It is not your normal American Italian joint,  the food is true to cultural Italian.
author: Austin S.

description:
I remember eating at this place 6-7 years ago and really enjoying it. However, I took 3 friends there last night and we all had pretty negative experiences. The fact that only about 1/3 of the tables had any partons on a Saturday night should have been a red flag. The waitstaff was unfriendly and univiting. We all ordered different dishes, and while the food was ok, there are plenty of places in this city with much tastier Italian food. The Gnocchi I had was decent but monotonous. My boyfriend's pasta primavera hardly had any vegetables in it, just a few peas and tomato chunks. It was overpriced, and the fact that they are cash only was a huge hassle and seems incredibly archaic. The only redeeming part of the dinner was the tirumisu, which was delicious. 

While the food was ok, I would never go back there again, except maybe for tiramisu. Next time I want Italian Food, I'll just head to my other tried and true favorites in the city; Bocce Cafe in North Beach or Valenica Pizzeria and Pasta in the Mission.
author: Alex W.

description: I've been to this neighborhood restaurant a few times.  My most memorable was in celebration of my son Ryan's graduation form USF.  The staff were very accomodating for our large group.  Food was delicious and we drank all their Prosecco!  I returned a few months ago after raving about the food and service.  I wanted to share the experience with a new group of friends.  I must say, we found the food disappointing this time and the service was not friendly or accomodating.  My friend ordered the Carbonara which was made with ham, not bacon. We had to keep asking for bread.  I have rated this restaurant a 3 star because all other visits here have been memorable.
author: Beth N.

description: Walk too fast and you could miss this place. Delicious recognizable foods. Portions big enough to take home and have for another meal. Though we waited ages for a table, as the last to leave, we were treated to a glass of Grappa on the house.
author: Gus J.

description:
i've lived three blocks up the street from this place for a year and a half and just barely tried it for the first time (7:30pm on a monday). it was about 1/3 full and we were able to get a cute booth by the window where we could watch all the haYES valley people walk their tiny tiny dogs.

the matron of the house didn't say much. in fact, she didn't say anything at all until i asked her if there was a key for the bathroom. "there's someone in there," she whispered. we were still convinced she was mute until she opened her mouth a second time to tell my friend his plate was hot.

the food -- really great, and according to my italophile friend, very authentic. pasta alla matriciana is delectable if you like pancetta.

the decor -- kitschy but also sort of authentic with the (real) exposed brick, and candles with millions of layers of colored wax just asking to be broken off.

random -- there's a giant teddy bear sitting on a chair in the bathroom.
author: Christine V.

description: Get the Gnocchi. You will not regret it. Handmade pasta and sauces with a family owned touch.
author: Carl F.

description: Everything I've ever had at il Borgo  was delicious, and I think I've made it about a third of the way through the expansive menu at this point. I actually have to remind myself NOT to go here because 1.) I'm friendly enough with the workers that they throw a glass of wine or some tiramisu my way every once in a while, so I have to make sure I don't wear out my welcome and 2.) it is approximately 15 feet from my front door, and it is a slippery slippery slope towards eating at il Borgo every night. I mean, who wouldn't want to come home every night to a big plate of downy gnocchi or creamy lasagnetta? Sure, the service can be a bit weird at times (especially on weekends) but the woman who works there on weeknights is really sweet and when I walk past on the way home every night she waves and smiles as if she's genuinely glad to see that I made it through another day.
author: Julia G.

description: Il Borgo is a neighborhood gem. It was the first restaurant that I tried when I moved to San Francisco-- and what a great welcome to the city! The staff (presumably the owners as well) were friendly and accomodating. The food was absolutely delicious. The gnocchi was perfect and the margherita pizza prepared in the authentic thin crust style. On my second visit I returned with about 10 of my friends and again the staff was accomodating and the food delicious. I HIGHLY recommend Il Borgo to both locals and tourists looking for an authentic taste of Italia.
author: H. B.

description:
the food here is always very good, and tastes quite fresh. many dishes on the special menu seem to be unique, but of course are delicious. lobster ravioli and "lasagnette" spring to mind. 

I don't really know how much wine is supposed to cost in restaurants, so I can't say whether its priced well or not (most bottles were $25-35?)

there is one crazy dude who works there, and will come to your table and start yammering on about some nonsense, to the bewilderment of you and your friends, but other than that the service is generally good.
author: Dan M.

description: A short walk from the casa and a great setting for dinner. Really choice traditional Italian dishes as well as some great new additions. I love the lobster ravioli in aurora sauce. They have a wonderful selection of wines and the staff makes you feel like family from your first visit. Lax atmosphere makes you feel like your eating in an Italian courtyard complete with laundry drying on the line and light posts. They play great music here I love pavoratti and old Italian love songs... there's always candle light, atmosphere, smiling faces and leftovers to take home. Makes you want to fall in love if your not already!
author: Charlie B.

description: I had a great meal here last night--the carpaccio was delicious and tender, and the gnocchi with bolognese sauce was sensational.  My bf loved the lobster ravioli as well. Nice wine list too.  We had an amazing bottle of sicilian wine for about $30.  Service was leisurely, but attentive.
author: Anna M.

description: The waitress seemed like she wasn't too happy to be working, and we did see at least two couples leave after being seated, though I'm not sure why.  The waitress was also unattentive and mildly rude until I ate the entire pizza I ordered.  It was a good pizza, though.
author: Katie K.

description: Can't say enough good things about this place. The hostess/waitress is the nicest woman. The Lasgnetta is to die for. Can't go wrong for the price. We were the only people in last night around 5:30. Go eat at Il Borgo so that it can stay in business!
author: Jessica R.

description: Ummm this place is amazing. Friendly staff, super delicious, and it helps that it is only 2 blocks from my place. The gnocchi is a must.
author: ally v.

description: I was really bothered by how bad the service at this place was. Even though it wasn't that busy, the service took forever, and was pretty inattentive. In addition, I find it strange that they don't accept credit cards but have an ATM machine in the restaurant. The food was ok - I had gnocchi with pesto, although it was a bit too soft and mushy for my liking.
author: Dana L.

description: I have given this restaurant two chances now...maybe I just don't get it. I am not Italian nor did I grow up eating Italian food. I just don't think the food here is very good! It's cheap and relatively friendly, but there are many other places in the neighborhood I would rather spend my dollar, or someone else's...!
author: Justine K.

description: My husband and I went w/ my mom to this place this past week - a good family friend knows the husband and wife that own the place. I wasn't sure what to expect - but this place is GREAT. The atmosphere is wonderful and the people that own the place are super nice and friendly. They have a good menu selection and the prices aren't that bad - not cheap - but it's not over priced. We had the best time at this place, it's so unexpected and you can't really tell from the outside how cute it is inside. I highly recommend this place - it is romantic, a great date place :) the food was wonderful! And we had some coffee which was great too - and I do have to say the best tiramisu I've ever had! I usually get tiramisu that is too sweet or too runny but this was THE BEST. If you love Italian food this place is a MUST.
author: Kimberly R.

description:
writing buddy and i came on a weeknight and, it being early, we were the only two people in the restaurant.  

the nice lady seated us and took our orders before receiving a phone call from behind the counter.  

for the next 40 minutes as we ate she shouted pretty much nonstop into the phone in a melodic language we couldn't understand, pausing only once to bring us wine.  we didn't mind, plus the food was good.  i left feeling a bit regretful that i couldn't speak italian.
author: Andrew P.

description:
we had a large group to feed on sunday evening, fortunately Il Borgo was happy to do all the work.  very sweet little Sicilian place on a not so busy street.  a very nice alternative if you feel like good Sicilian food but have no interest in the Little Italy crowd.
the waitress was one of the nicest we've had anywhere in a very long time.  the food was perfect.  prices were very reasonable.  definitely will go back.
perfect for kids too.
author: Tammy N.

description:
it's been a couple weeks since i went here and i don't exactly remember what we ordered, which tells you something about the food, i guess. nothing to complain about, nothing to rave about. 

the service was "meh," to quote my friend cass. heavy on the friendly signorina!'s and prego!'s; light on the water and wine refills. the clincher was when i finally caught our waitress' eye and she tried to get me to give her my request from across the room (uh, can you please light our candle?) call me old-fashioned, but i kinda like it when the waitress comes over to the table.

and i'm beginning to resent these places that don't accept credit cards. what an inconvenience -- just so the business can pocket a few extra bucks? think about how many uncomfortable moments happen here each night, as well-intentioned souls slap down their cards to treat, only to learn it's CASH ONLY.  awk-ward!

il borgo is adorable inside, that's true. i'd come here again if someone suggested it, but there are lots of other places i'd want to try first.
author: jean w.

description: This place was ok.  The bread was fresh, the pasta and pizza were good as well.  The service was horrible.  It took forever!
author: Joanna S.

description: First up, the restaurant design looks really nice and cozy. I remember eating garlic bread, mozzarella with tomatoes, and artichoke ravioli but ended up being sick all night. The waiter was harsh and not very welcoming. He rather seemed to be annoyed taking orders and serving food. I have not eaten any pasta since then. It wasn't a pleasant experience at all.  I will never go back. Ever!
author: MS K.

description: i enjoied the food... which in this city keeps me coming back to places that lack in other areas.. yummy food but thats all.
author: Jade M.

description: The atmosphere at il borgo was homey, relaxing and pleasant.  I would have to say that is was a pretty nice place to go and grab some food for a lo-key evening.  We got an app of capese salad that was fresh and tasty.  The dinner was pretty good too.  I really have nothing to complain about here and nothing to rave about.  Il Borgo seemed really average to me.  I think I'm turning into a California wine snob though.  I can remember reading the menu and being bummed that they only had european wines on their list....but that's my problem.
author: Jonathan R.

description: This wasn't exactly a foodie experience--very simple menu with choice of pasta and a few sauces, but this place is extremely cute and quaint. Inside, the tiny little restaurant looks like you are eating on a street at night in a little Italian villa--there is "laundry" hanging from a line and a couple fake windows and balconies. It's a place I would go to if I was craving basic Italian comfort food (pasta, pasta, and pasta), in a semi romantic/kitch-cool place.
author: Sabine S.

description: I wasn't initially impressed with the atmosphere, it seemed kind of cheesy. But it turns out that the food is very authentic and homey. The service is wonderful. Surprisingly, this place delivers great Italian.
author: George M.

description: Good Italian. The last time I was there the service wasn't very good which is why this only get 3 stars instead of 4.
author: Amanda A.

description: Best italian (Tuscan) in the city,  the dishes are simple, flavorful and nicely priced.  My favs are the caprese & carpaccio as appetizers.  Best entrees: penne arriabiata, gnocchi & tagliatelle, to die for!  Be sure to try their thin crust pizza, they make it from scratch and it's delicious.  What a diamond this place is, i've been a faithful customer for 5 years, ain't nothin' mo' better.
author: erica u.

description:
Great restaurant!

Never had a bad meal here.  It is quite popular so plan accordingly if you want to dine here on the weekends (not even sure if they take reservations).  Even without reservations you'll wait less time than at the German place down the street.

The bread is always a great way to start your dinner experience (with olive oil and balsamic dipping sauce), followed by platters that are filling but not too heavy.

It has the feeling of a great "family-style" neighborhood restaurant.
author: Scott S.

description: Food was delicious, but the odd waiter was really, really odd. Had something dripping from his nose when he served our wine. I don't see a reason to go back.
author: marco a.

description: We looked quite a while to find the place because friends had a previous good experience. We were very disappointed. First, the dining room was at least 15 degrees warmer than the cool evening air outside. It was sweltering. The server, assumed owner, had no personality and was actually a bit rude. The female "bus person" was very pleasant and was helpful, but we had to ask for extra table settings. The food was ok, nothing special. The tomato sauce was a bit sweet for my taste, but all meals were fine. At the end we put the credit card in the bill folder then were told they don't take credit cards. We looked the front door, which was propped open, the only sign said "ATM Inside," there was nothing about cash only. We tried the ATM, but it did not work (the card worked a few minutes later in a bank ATM). Fortunately, one of us had enough cash. When we asked the owner and said we didn't see any signs about cash only, he was very rude. We won't  be going back.
author: Rich M.

description: I'm not sure what all these reviews are talking about, but I've been to plenty of Italian restaurants all over the country and this simply does not stack up.  Yes it has a comfortable feel inside, and the staff is nice, but the food simply does not add up.  The sauces for all the pasta dishes in my group were bland and boring.  Aurora sauce especially weak, but the worst was the tortellini bolognese - literally tasted like hamburger helper.  Sorry to say but this restaurant does not get more than one star - and most definitely does not get my business.
author: Roman A.

description: The food is decent and reasonably priced but the wait staff is rude.  Can't decide if it's worth going back.  I WANT to love it because its so cute inside but I just don't! Hmmm... I guess I need to decide how important good service is to me.  Maybe we'll just do take out from now on...
author: Deborah G.

description: Very good Italian food for a very reasonable price! I'm not even a huge fan of Italian but I really like this place. The service is good and very fast!
author: Janelle M.

description:
the hand made pasta is awesome, pizza is very unique. the veggie lasagentta (sp?!?!) with egg plant was excellent.

from chicago, i feel so lucky to have stumbled across this place. it was perfect, charming, and delicious!
author: Kevin T.
