description: Came here to satiate my pasta craving. Really nice, homey ambiance. I got a fettucini with sun-dried tomatoes, capers, and chicken. Tasty stuff, though a bit heavy. It was probably meant to be shared, which meant that I left probably overly satisfied (though not uncomfortably so.) Was one of the pricier meals I've had in San Francisco, though. $13.50 + $1.50 tax + tip. I do regret it; while the meal was very good, it wasn't quite $15+ good.
author: Chris L.

description: I've lived two blocks from this place for almost two years now and have never eaten here until last night. Walking in, it looks like a cliche small italian restaurant with the bricks painted onto the wall overlooking the "Tuscan scenery" with fake plants, dark mood lighting and wax dipped chianti bottles as candle holders. I went on what I assumed would be a quiet night but the place was full, and there was only one waitress working the whole floor, so it took a while to be seated even though there were open tables. This would later affect the meal in that it was just so hard to get her attention, and give the most adequate service as possible. This was my biggest complaint about the whole experience, except for the fact that the kitchen was also behind and no one in the whole restaurant had their meal yet. I ordered the lasgnetta, a rolled lasagna with mozzarella and prosciutto with a tomato cream sauce that was very rich, so I had a hard time finishing my meal which was a bummer. The fresh bread was great but I wish the olive oil and vinegar could have tasted a little fresher. Oh well. Maybe I'm being picky, who knows.
author: Lauren S.

description: I love Il Borgo! My favorite waitress in all of San Francisco works there during the week.  She always greets us with a huge smile and speaks to us in Italiano. The food is delicious.  I highly recommend the Gnocchi with pesto sauce or the lasagna vegetarian.  The bread and the pasta taste homemade.  Yummy!
author: Dana S.

description: The food portions are big, the staff is very helpful and the service is fast.  The food was bearable, tolerable but nothing to write home about.
author: Sailing A.

description:
I really liked this place.. The plates were huge and the gnocci is truly the best I've ever had.. and the atmosphere was so nice.. it's really cheap for the amount of food you get.. 
The location isn't the best.. being right on Fell Street where you just zip by it.. and the owner guy/waiter was a bit on the close side.. like 2 inches from your face (please, I need breathing room....) when taking orders and asking a million times if you love the homemade gnocchi.. a little disturbing.. and the fact that they don't take credit cards.. what is up with that?? get with the digital age, people!! 
but, overall, a really nice experience.
author: Mari K.

description: SF could use more places like this. Good, solid food. Zero pretense. Cheesy decor. The salad sucked but that's my fault. You don't come to a place like this and start dinner with a salad.
author: hart l.

description: I could have made the same at home. Bruschetta starter, Pizza + Lasagnetta. All fine, just nothing special.
author: Gail A.

description: GREAT food!! Totally under-visited restauraant.
author: S H.

description: This little Italian Gem is a sure shot and a recession buster.  It's affordable and the entrees are large, but have a mom and pop home-cooked vibe, not like olive garden cheezy food vibe. Get a big entree and a salad and the house chianti and you've got yourself an affordable date night!
author: Alona E.

description:
"wow, that was suck"-nobu k. on domo

we left Domo hungry and dissapointed, and were thinking about where we were going to get some real sushi when I stopped to check the menu of the small Italian restaurant on the corner near where we parked.
At the top of the menu was carpaccio... Coming from Hawai'i, the only carpaccio i have ever seen was ahi.... so when I saw that they have raw beef carpaccio, i told dad, 
"you know... this right here is good shit" 
i then explained to him that most italian food i have been to in the city would not think of serving raw beef due to their lack of balls and authenticity, and that a restaurant that did not only had balls but was also probably really good. 
"ahhhh" was the response, and when nobu heard that I would eat the carpaccio, we had to go ( I am usually a vegitarian, but when in the city, dad takes me to sushi, and I felt like I needed to try the beef) 
The service was great, good bread, dipping oil and viniger and the food was MARVILOSO! 
We started with carpaccio, and I put a little too much lemon on it, but it was good, just watch the lemon.
then we had the pizza and the fusilli. WOW!!! I am usually a little on gaurd at italian restaurants because of the wack sauce or the over creamyness of stuff :::cough::::(ernestos):::: cough cough but this was AMAZING! it could've been the contrast to GPES sushi at Domo, but i think the fusilli was packed with flavor, and had more than a healthy ratio of sauce to carb... an amazing dish.
 It looks like people who are nice to the wait staff get respect. It doesnt take more than a smile and a thank you...  it might reach all the way to the kitchen? 
four stars... AND this review has inspired me to write on people that are rude.... :)
author: Isao K.

description: My friend and I have been going to this restaurant since they opened (this may have been as many as 10 or 11 years? I can hardly believe it myself. Just the length of time the restaurant has been in business is testament to how good it is). We love it. Of all the neighborhood restaurants, we go to this one the most. The dishes are always consistently flavorful and Sergio, the owner, comes by to chat if there is time. Sergio's wife, Mitra is wonderful and friendly and comes by with her wine glass full of water and sits with us to chat, too, if it's not busy. She helps me practice Italian, French, and more. She is fun. Our menu favorites are the lamb chops, the mista salad, the tiramisu and a cappucino. I love the savory and flavorful dishes. One time we asked Sergio if there was anything different and he brought out a fresh fish to show us. We just said sure we wanted to try something new, and he made us the most wonderful, delicious dinner made from it, not on the menu. Another time, we came over and it was around 10pm, I think. Sergio and the guys from the kitchen (they are nice, too - I always say hello) had cleaned and closed up the kitchen due to it was a slow night. They were sitting at one of the tables winding down. We asked if they were still open and they explained what was going on but they would make us food if we'd like. We asked them if they were sure they didn't mind and they were all really great and smiling and opened the kitchen back up and made us dinner! la mia seconda famiglia! I feel that good when I get up to go home.
author: Lia H.

description: eat the raddichio salad, the lasagnetta or the pasta primavera ,,, primavera meaning add peas to cream sauce w/ prosciutto in it which is totally fine with me. the fettucine is made on site, i think, and had a crazy good al dente "mouth feel" ... lovely young waitress working the water pitcher and bread basket refills ... totally New York-ish waiter, not the owner-y acting one, the other one ... disinterested and heavily accented speech, ah, like NYC for sure.
author: Kevin M.

description: I'd give it a 3.5.  Its quaint and its totally affordable.  I had the sausage, mushroom penne special for the day and I really liked it.  The pasta is cooked al dente and not heavy on the tomato sauce.  Its a HUGE portion for the price ($10).  The bread is fresh, warm and soft.  I love it because its so close to my place and the people who work there (possibly owners?) are so friendly and warm.  It only took them about 15 minutes for my take out order.  Great place.
author: F S.

description: So everyone has a favorite Italian restaurant for whatever reason.  And most of the time, when I go to my friends' favorite Italian joints I'm always reminded that we are all subjective creatures...and oftentimes I'm disappointed by either the quality of the food or the prices, or both.  I work hard for my money and the last thing I want to do is spend it on crap Italian food.  So, that's where Il Borgo comes in.   I have never been disappointed by this place --  either food or price-wise.  The pizza, the gnocchi, the pasta -- all good.  Great, in fact.  I prefer to go during the week when it's less crowded and the marvelous Italian hostess is on duty.  Weekends usually result in a wait (never too long) and a less efficient and pleasant wait staff.  (I think the male host's main tactic in dealing with waiting customers is to ignore them.  Bad tactic.)  There are few restaurants I can go to for an excellent Italian meal that never disappoints and won't wreak havoc on my checking account.
author: G. B.

description: Recommended by a friend, my mom and I had dinner here the other evening and it was perfect! I'm a total sucker for fresh, homemade pasta, so I adored the thick chewy fettuccini with delicious thick Bolognese. The atmosphere was funky and original while being totally authentic. The service made everything very special. The menu includes both healthy and decadent options for a wide range of diners. I whole-heartedly recommend this adorable and savory neighborhood restaurant.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I always wanted to stop here but I was always whizzing down Fell on my way home....

finally last night we stopped in  and had a great dinner.  The bread is excellent, reminds me of Italian Star bread I used to get in an Italian neighborhood back on the East Coast.  We had two helpings and ate it all!  I had the Penne alla Putenesca - the penne was cooked perfectly al dente and the sauce was tangy and delicious.  Lots of olives and capers.  My date had the Saltimbocca - it was excellent, a great Marsala-like sauce, the chicken was just right and there was lots of prosciutto.  The Vegetable medley was not the same old tired and soggy zucchini and carrots.... it was freshly cooked and there were green beans, broccoli and fresh tomatoes. 
Our waitress was very friendly and attentive (it was 5:00 and we were the first in the place for the evening).  this place is just as good and better than anyplace in North Beach and I will return!
And the atmosphere is just perfect for the little neighborhood joint that it is!
author: kris c.

description: yummy and fresh! just bring cash. no credit cards accepted
author: cyndi b.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF, this place is a gem.  Cozy, unpretentious, romantic, you feel like you're in an Italian courtyard.  Food is great - some fresh pastas, tasty sauces, cheap wine, but it's the ambiance that gets me every time.  I get so tired of the giant, converted warehouse type style of a lot of the "fine" SF restaurants, where you are all crammed next to each other, have to scream to your dining companion to be heard above the noise, and yet can hear everything your neighbor is saying.  Whenever I'm tired of that kind of thing, I head over to Il Borgo and have a leisurely 2 hour meal.  Love them!
author: Kristi S.

description: This is a great local place and the staff is very friendly and welcoming.  Because it is so close and has decent food, I get take-out from here often.  I like the bolognese and the radicchio salad.
author: Bobo R.

description: never a wait in this charming low key italian restaurant tucked away from the hustle and bustle of hayes valley. pastas are made fresh and are very delicious - i believe my fave is the fettucine el borgo (spicy tomato sauce -red peppers - and grilled chicken), i also tried thier lasagna which is quite yummy. service might be unattentive at times but guranteed always freindly! wine list is quite mediocre - i suggest bringing your own bottle and paying corkage -PREGO!
author: Christian S.

description: Italian. I'm 1/4 Sicilian. But I was raised close to my Sicilian grandmother and her wondrous cooking so i feel more Italian than i really am. I'm used to smelling sauce on the stove by 6am for a 6pm dinner w/ all the cousins, aunts and uncles. Italian. Yea. Sweet family life. The wife and i love Borgo for this very reason. It's like going to visit the Italian side of the family except all the faces have changed. But the warmth and charm haven't. Plus it's so dang local we can walk there from our place. LOVE the red & white checked tablecloths. The candles dripping onto the wine bottles. The fresh, warm homemade bread sent to your table as soon as you arrive. And the Italian owner started singing a tarantella behind the counter for his own pleasure which soon became ours. The penne con salsiccia w/ mushrooms is a personal fave of mine. (Penne pasta, sweet homemade sausage, and mushrooms drenched in a rich, red tomato sauce.) Sprinkle some fresh parmesan on that baby and you're transported to the boot-shaped country that kicked it all off. The wife had a 'molte bene' homemade fettucine smothered in a more gravy-like meat sauce w/ mushrooms. We looked right outta "The Lady and the Tramp", eating off each other's plates, damn near slurping up the same piece of fettucine, one of us on each end. We walked outta the place stuffed and satisfied, paying around $30 bucks. This place is simple. Real simple. Like me. Like the wife. You don't have to get all dressed up but you can if you want to. They treat you the same either way: Like family. Desidera in tensione la famiglia di Borgo!!! (Long live the Borgo family!!!)
author: Mark A.

description:
ok--i really wanted to like this place.

the first time i ate here my husband and i both did not like it for a bunch of reasons.

so.... i waited  a year and tried it again.  nope, don't like it, not going back.  i just don't understand the hype.  i don't feel the food is as good as most of the italian restaurants in the city.  in hayes valley alone cafe delle stelle and stelline's are both WAY better with prices that are at least the same if not better.
author: n. h.

description:
if you grew up in small towns in pennsylvania or have seen _the lady and the tramp_, you'll recognize this restaurant.  candles in chianti bottles covered in wax, red and white checked table covers, frescoes on the walls and a bas relief in the bathroom, baskets of bread.  i wouldn't have thought it existed in san francisco, and certainly not in hayes valley.

the food was tasty and simple--i had the pesto gnocchi which was smooth and not overwhelming.  i would skip the bruschetta, at least until better tomatoes are in season (or perhaps they don't know how to select well).  i didn't taste it because there was sausage on it, but one of my companions raved about the pizza, especially the thin crust.

stop by and support this friendly owner-run (it seems) establishment.
author: H H.

description: I still can't decide whether this place is cheesy and weird or authentic and fun. This place is funky, in so many ways. Things you should know before you venture through the doors. They only serve wine, and the wine list is all italian and very limited in selection. We tried four different bottles of red wine (eight of us...), there are only about eight choices of reds, even fewer of white, and one prosecco. I think we only enjoyed the last bottle we ordered (Nero D'Avila) because we were fairly buzzed by then. The wines were all dry and some even tasted effervescant like flat champagne, very off, even maybe "corked" per se. They don't serve beer or liquor. The service was one haughty looking italian woman who pretended for quite awhile that the eight of us were just some mirage in her way. We had to flag her down and ask her to take our orders etc.... This is a small place, one room schoolhouse type joint. The chairs are very heavy iron outdoor type chairs that my boyfriend had to haul aside everytime I needed to get up. They do have some wood booths that looked fun to sit in. They don't take credit cards but they do have an on-site ATM machine so they can charge you a frickin fee for cash, I hate that scam. The one shiny spot was the food. I had artichoke ravioli, it was fresh and just right, I actually ate every bit of it. My boyfriend has penne with sausage and mushrooms and he liked it. Everyone liked their food. It was my friend's birthday and they brought her tiramusu with candle in it, that was a nice touch. The prices are not bad and you get quite a bit of food. I don't know if I would choose to come back here just because the wine list and lack of liquor choices, those things matter too much to me. There are so many amazing wines in California, there really is no excuse for a bad selection of off tasting wines...
author: Samantha J.

description: start with the antipasto misto, then get the lasagnetta.  you'll be stoked.
author: stephen a.

description: I pass this place on fell street all the time and it attracted me with its cute quaint storefront. I finally made the trip out there one day and I have to say the ambience inside is definitely nice, definitely romantic. However, I remember the food being not so memorable. I was definitely disappointed after dinner because I had such high hopes given the atmosphere. Maybe I will have to give it a try again some other day.
author: Luke F.

description: I want to give this place 3.5 stars but since I have to round up or down, I'm going with down.  Not because it isn't a good lil' place...it is.  But, the wine was kinda crap for the price and it is just a tad too cheesy to give 4 stars.  That said, the Pasta Primavera with light cream sauce and peas is very good.
author: Joseph S.

description: i took my sister on monday evening, july 14. the place is small with a nice atmosphere, but our italian female server didn't offer bread (nor parmesan when our entrées arrived), was extremely slow and seemed to care more about drinking her glass of wine near the serving area than helping the 16 or so of us dining in the restaurant. perhaps it's an italian thing? as others have already stated, i was pissed off that they don't accept cards and their atm machine was out of order and i was forced to run to another cash machine outside the restaurant. i probably won't be back as there are hundreds of other more worthy italian restaurants in sf i want to enjoy.
author: Torrpedo T.

description: the homemade tiramisu is AMAZING. i love the atmosphere of this place--you walk in from fell street and feel like you're in a different world. i tried the carbonara and the pizza with mushrooms and sausage and both were yum nom nom. bonus points for the very sweet and attentive woman who works there and speaks to everyone in bits of italian. lovely!
author: stella k.

description: A very nice rustic Italian restaurant. They have good food, are not too expensive, and best of all the atmosphere is great. It's quiet and somewhat romantic, the perfect place to take your date out for dinner.
author: Mr. S.

description: We've been going to this neighborhood restaurant for years.  Great food, although the service is a little spotty.  The gnocchi are to die for!
author: Michael H.

description: Il Borgo is amazing! i'm not a huge lasagna fan (more of a gniocchi kind of girl) but it's an absolute must if you go to il borgo. Tender homemade pasta with thinly sliced prosciutto and gorgonzola cheese -- yummy! And it's not saturated with cheese making you feel all heavy -- it's got a pink sauce that's just right. Highly recommended. Cheap and altho the wait staff aren't the greatest -- who cares? They're not in Italy either ;)
author: amanda t.

description: As a former New Yorker and half Sicilian I have high standards for Italian food. Borgo is my favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco. I give it five stars - in spite of a cash only policy and a decor that is on the cheesy side - because the food is always authentic, fresh, flavorful and perfectly cooked. The menu doesn't vary much - which allows the kitchen to maintain a wonderful consistency. My favorites include spaghetti with salmon, chicken saltimboca and their signature dish - lasgnetta. This consists of delicate spirals of fresh pasta rolled with cheese and fresh tomato sauce, rather than layered top to bottom like traditional lasagna. My husband loves the crispy pizza that is cooked on a fire, as well as the spicy Penne Arrabbiata. Service is wam and friendly - it seems like a family is running the place, so if you go often you'll meet all the relatives of the owner Sergio.  When you take our next stroll through Hayes Valley, don't overlook this hidden gem.
author: rosemary p.

description: if you really, really like garlic, go here. i happen to love garlic, so this worked out well for me. we started with the antipasti with roasted garlic, proscuitto, artichokes, olives, and mozzerella. yum! god i love roasted garlic. i had a bite of bruschetta (i'm pretty sure i'm mangling the spelling of these words but whatevs. je parle francais), which, in addition to tomato and basil, was topped generously with - you guessed it - garlic. raw. intense! i love it! they were out of lamb, which is what i really wanted. i got salmon instead and i have to say, it was good! i was surprised. it was served with vegetables and potatoes for a hearty, well balanced meal. had a bite of bf's creamy pesto, which lacked seasoning but was ok. our dining companions seemed happy with their selections. what really makes this place is a very cozy, cute authentic family feel. i left longing to go to tuscany.
author: Mary V.
